2824

Abandoned Buildings (Special Provisions) Ordinance, 1985

Citation: 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 191, 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 345, 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 438, 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 313

Case Year: 1985

Subject: Abandoned Buildings

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Abandoned Buildings (Special Provisions) Ordinance, 1985

Abandoned Buildings (Special Provisions) Ordinance, 1985— (Ord No. 54 of 1985)— Section  7— Release  of abandoned buildings from the "Ka" list-Section     5(2)—     Presumption     of correctness of the list— its rebuttal—

The owner of the building in question was althrpugh in Bangladesh and as a retired government servant drew his pension from the exchequer of the Government till before his death in August, 1981 and as such it can not be said that his whereabouts were not known. In that view of the matter the presumption of correctness of the "Ka" list stands rebutted. The apex court declared the enlistment of the, said building as abandoned illegal and directed to release the same in favour of the writ petitioners. Sirajul Hue] and others Vs. Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Works and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 191.

 

Abandoned Buildings (Supple­mentary Provisions) Ordinance, 1985— Section 5— The abandoned character of the property is the determining factor as to whether the same is abandoned or not— Enlistment of the property either in the 'Ka' or 'Kha' list is immaterial— Fraud vitiates everything—

Decree for specific performance of contract has no bearing, on the question of determination of the disputed property as to whether the same is abandoned property or not. The petitioner who claims the suit property has to prove by valid documents that it is not abandoned property. Golam Rabbani Vs. Chairman, Court of Settlement and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 345.

 

Abandoned Buildings (Supple­mentary Provisions) Ordinance, 1985— Section 5(1)— List of abandoned buildings has presumption as to its correctness   until   rebutted   by   the claimant—

Decree of specific performance of contract does not confer any title to the suit property. Such decree is no bar against inclusion of the property in the list of abandoned properties. The onus to rebut the presumption lies on the person who claims the property. Government has no obligation. Moreover transfer of ownership of the abandoned building through court is null and void as per provision of article 6 of P.O. No. 16 of 1972. Amena Kha tun (Mrs.) Vs. Chairman, Court of Settlement and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 438.

 

Abandoned Buildings (Supple­mentary Provisions) Ordinance, 1985— Section 7(1)— Release of abandoned buildings from the Ka list—

List of abandoned buildings prepared and published under section 5(2) of the Ordinance, 1985 in the Official Gazette has the presumption of correctness and is a conclusive evidence that the property included in the list is abandoned property and vested in the Government. Government is not required to disclose the basis of the list. When it is established that the Government has once taken over the control and management of the abandoned property, the onus lies upon the  claimant  that  it  was  never     an abandoned property. AH AshrafMia Vs. Chairman, First Court of Settlement and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 313.

2825

Abandoned Property (Management, Control and Disposal) Order 1972 (P.O. No. 16 of 1972)

Citation: 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 82, 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 229, 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 242

Case Year: 1972

Subject: Abandoned Property

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Abandoned Property (Manage­ment, Control and Disposal) Order, 1972 (P.O No. 16 of 1972)

Abandoned Property (Management, Control and Disposal) Order 1972 (P.O. No. 16 of 1972) Enlistment of abandoned building in 'Kha' list-When it is found that  the original lessee left Bangladesh during the war of liberation leaving behind the building in question uncared for and thereafter did not return back, the said property has rightly been enlisted in the 'Kha' list of abandoned property. Creation of spurious  documents  and  the exparte decree not in respect of the enlistment can not be bar to the inclusion of the building in the 'Kha' list. Abul Kalam Khan (Md.) Vs. Government of Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Works and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 82.

 

Section 2— Property can not be held to be abandoned by reason of temporary absence of its owner—

It has been consistently held by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court that a property can not be treated as abandoned by reason of temporary absence of its owner and staying in a country or when he was not national of the country with which Bangladesh was at war and his such absence was not prejudical to the interest of Bangladesh. In that view the High Court Division directed the Respondents to release the shares of the petitioners in the Eastern Tubes Ltd. after proper verification which the apex court held perfectly justified. Arif A. Shekha and others Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Industries and another 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 229.

 

Section 5-— Presumption of correctness of the list of abandoned property—

The list of abandoned property duly prepared has a presumption of correctness until such presumption is rebutted by showing the contrary. The Appellate Division found the petitioner bonafide purchaser of the disputed property for valuable consideration without notice of the defect in the title of the transferor and got over possession of the same. Since the said property is abandoned and duly included in the list as such, the title did not pass to the petitioner. However the apex court observed the petitioner should be given preference as and when the respondents dispose of the said property and meanwhile directed the respondent no 4 not to disturb the possession of the petitioner therein. Shadharan Bima Corporation Vs. First Court of Settlement and. others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 242.

 

2826

Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982

Citation: 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 176, 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 265, 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 27, 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 184, 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 373, 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 233, 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 332, 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 81, 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 41

Case Year: 1982

Subject: Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Acquisition and Requisition

of Immovable Property

Ordinance, 1982

Sections 3, 6, 7 and 11— Acquisition process when reaches its finality— Government can exclude any land from acquisition— Court has no such power—

Court has no power to exclude any land from acquisition. Only the government can exclude any land from acquisition. Ameena Ahmed Vs. Government of Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Land and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 176.

 

Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982— Section 6 and 11— Acquisition of land for public purpose becomes final and the land so acquired vests in the Government after notification published in the official Gazette under section 11 of the Ordinance—Writ petition filed long after the acquisition is not maintainable—

By majority decision the apex court held that writ petition filed long after the acquisition is not maintainable and disputed fact can not be decided in the writ jurisdiction. The acquisition of land for public purpose becomes final and vests in the Government after the publication of notice under section 11 in the official Gazette. However the apex court further held that if the requiring body fails to utilise the land for the purpose it is acquired and the land remains unutilised for long time, the original owners may, approach the Government for the return of the same. M/S Mallah Industrial Estate and Government of Bangladesh and others Vs. Khaivja Mohammad Arifullah and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 265.

 

Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982— Section 8B— Release of Property on de-requisition—

Immovable property under acquisition can only be released before payment of compensation. Appropriate authority may withdraw any such property before payment of compensation upon de-requisition by notification published in the official Gazette. Impugned order is declared illegal and passed without any lawful authority. Khalilur Rahman being dead his heirs Abdur Rahman and others Vs. Executive Engineer, Roads and Higliwai/s and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 27.

 

Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982— Section 13— Is not a bar against acquisition of part of Homestead Land— Evidence Act, 1872— Photostat copy of document without authentication is not an evidence—

Original documents were never produced before the court. Instead only the photostat copies of those documents without any authentication _ were produced which the learned judges of the High Court Division held carry no evidentiary value under the Evidence Act. Alhaj Abdul Maleque Gazi Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 184.

 

Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982— Section 13— Acquisition of part of home-stead—

There is no legal bar against the acquisition of part of homestead as provided under section 13 of the Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982. The learned judges of the High Court Division further held that the photostat copies of documents without authentication when the originals are not produced are not admissible in evidence and as such those do not have any evidentiary value in the eye of law. Alhaj Abdul Maleque Gazi and others Vs. Government of Bangladesh represented by the Deputy Commissioner, Chandpur and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 373.

 

Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982—

Section 31— Arbitration revision case is maintainable not-withstanding the awardee having received , the compensation money—

When arbitration revision case is filed by the awardee after he had received the compensation money, this fact shows that he received the compensation money under protest and did not agree to the correctness of the award. The mere receipt of the compensation money by the awardee does not by itself render the arbitration revision case not maintainable. The apex court held the arbitration revision case so filed quite maintainable. Government of Bangladesh represented by the Deputy Commissioner Dhaka and another Vs. Abdur Rahman and others. 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 233.

 

Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982—

Section 44—Ousts the jurisdiction of court in matters of acquisition of immovable property—

On the completion of acquisition the property so acquired absolutely vests in the government. Non-utilisation of such property does not create any vested right in favour of the original owner to get back the property in qustion. Section 44 of the Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982 expressly ousts the jurisdiction of the court in matters of acquisition of immovable property and as such the suit instituted by the plaintiff respondent is not maintainable. Rajdhani Unnayan Kartipakha Vs. Abdul Jakir and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 332.

 

Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982 (Ord No. II of 1982)—

Section 46— Provides for framing Rules for carrying out the purpose of the law—

Acquisition of Immovable Property Rules, 1983—

Rule 8(3)— Provides for assessment of compensation of land and buildings acquired under Ordinance No. II of 1982 in consultation with the Public Works Department—

In the instant arbitration case the Arbitrator allowed the prayer for appointment of a Private Engineering firm for assessment of the compensation of the land and building acquired under the Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982 instead of directing the Public Works Department to assess the compensation as required under rule 8(3) of the Acquisition of Immovable Property Rules, 1983. The apex court held the assessment should have been made by the Public Works Department and the Arbitrator was required strictly to act in accordance with law and such an action of the Arbitrator being opposed to law was not to be taken into consideration and upheld the judgment and order of the appellate court and setaside the decision of the High Court Division being erroneous. The apex court further held the principle of waiver with regard to performance of state functionaries will be disastrous to discipline and create anarchy and as such disapproved the proposition. Land Acquisition officer, Pubna and others Vs. Alhaj Md. Abdul Latif Biswas and another 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 81.

 

Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982—

Section 36— An arbitrator is deemed to be a civil court for limited purpose. As such arbitrator can not review its award in exercise of power under Order 47 rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure 1908—

Section 34 of the Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982 provides for appeal against an award passed by Arbitrator. An arbitrator is deemed to be a civil court for limited purpose as contemplated under section 36 of the Ordinance and as such arbitrator has no power to review the award passed by him under Order 47 Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908. The review petition is held by the apex court not maintainable. Atiqullah (Md.) Vs. Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh represented by Land Acquisition Collector and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 41.

 

2827

Administrative Tribunals Act, 1980

Citation: 8BLT (AD)-43, 9BLT(AD)-36 , 9 BLT(AD)-92

Subject: Administrative Tribunals

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 

 

Administrative Tribunals Act, 1980

 

Section-4(2)

The departmental appeal was rejected on 5.6.88 by the higher administrative authority and the case was filed before the Administrative Tribunal on 24.5.85. Hence it is barred by limitation as the provision of Section 4(2) contemplates filing of the case within six months from the disposal of the appeal by the higher administrative authority. [Para-4]

A. K. M. Any ad Hossain Vs. Superintending Engineer & Ors. 8BLT (AD)-43

 

Section-4(2)

In the instant case the jurisdiction of the Administrative Tribunal in entertaining the case without performing any appeal before a higher administrative authority was not in fact raised before the Administrative Tribunal and Administrative Appellate Tribunal. Respondent No. 1's representation for getting ante-dated seniority was being considered by the relevant authorities namely, the National Board of Revenue, the ministry of Establishment and Public Service Commission from 2.1.90. Ultimately National Board of Revenue passed the impugned order dated 29.7.91 refusing to grant ante-dated seniority to the petitioner in spite of the recommendations of the Ministry of Establishment and the Public Service Commission. This impugned order is in fact the order of a higher administrative authority as because the officers of the taxation department are under the administrative control of the National Board of Revenue and the National Board of Revenue is in fact the final higher administrative authority for the purpose of granting ante-dated seniority to respondent No. 1. Hence the question of filing any appeal to higher administrative authority for the purpose of granting ante-dated seniority to respondent No. 1 does not arise. The representation of respondent No I having been turned down by the National Board of Revenue, which is the higher administrative authority in the case of respondent, the question of preferring any further appeal does not arise in the facts of this case.

Govt, of Bangladesh & Anr. Vs. Md.. Nurul Haque Miah &Ors. 9BLT(AD)-36

 

Section-4(2) read with Limitation Act, 1908

Section-14

Section-14 of the Limitation Act is not applicable to the proceeding before the tribunal.

Ahal Bashar Vs. Investment Corp. of Bangladesh & Ors. 9 BLT(AD)-92.

 

2828

Admiralty Court Act, 2000

Citation: 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 113, 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 156

Subject: Admiralty Court Act, 2000

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Admiralty Court Act, 2000

(Act No. 43 of 2000)

 

Admiralty suit—  Limitation  of  the claim— Exempted from liability when the damage is caused by act of God-Limitation Act, 1908— Limitation for a suit claiming damage is one year from the date of delivery of goods. When the damage is caused by act of God, the ship is exempted from the liability, in the instant case the suit is instituted beyond the  period    of limitation and as such the suit is held barred  by  limitation.  The  High Court Division i.e the Admiralty Court in the facts and circumstances released the vessels from arrest which the apex court held perfectly justified. H.R.C Shipping Limited Vs. M.V Lady Fatema and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 113.

 

Admiralty Courts Act, 2000—Section 4(4)(a)— No claim for damage lie when caused by force majeure—Carriage of Goods by Sea Act, 1925—Carrier is not liable for the loss or damage caused by act of God—

Tsunami of 26th December 2004 which caused unprecedented damage and colossal loss of life and property was certainly an act of God and as such the carrier vessels can not be liable for any such damage which are exempted under the force majeure clause. Therefore the learned judge of the Admiralty Court directed the immediate release of the M.V. vessels from arrest.HRC Shipping Limited Vs. M.V. X-press Manaslu and MV. X-press Resolve and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 156.

2829

ANTI-CORRUPTION ACT, 1957

Citation: 19BLD (AD)97

Subject: ANTI-CORRUPTION

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 

 

ANTI-CORRUPTION ACT, 1957

 

Section—3

Anti-Corruption Manual

Paragraph—59

Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (V of 1898)

Section—561A

In view of the provisions of section 3 of the Anti-Corruption Act, 1957 and paragraph 59 of the Anti-Corruption Manual the investigation held by an Assistant Inspector of the Bureau of the Anti-Corruption was not illegal and without jurisdiction.

The investigation by an Assistant Inspector does not per se become illegal and without jurisdiction. A proceeding cannot also be quashed merely because there is irregularity, if any, in the investigation.

 Md. Abul Hossain Vs The State, 19BLD (AD)97.

 

2830

Anti-Corruption Commission Act, 2004


Anti-Corruption Commission Act, 2004

 

Anti-Corruption Commission Act, 2004

Section 26(a) Lodging F.I.R initiation andcontinuation of criminal proceedings and conviction and sentence ate declaredillegal and are quashed.

When in a number of inquiries nothing was detectedas regards acquisition of property disproportionate to the known sources ofincome of the petitioner, the lodging of P.1K initiation of prosecution, thetrial, conviction and sentence impugned in the writ petition are declared bythe learned judges of the High Court Division as illegal and are thus quashed.

Abul Kalam Shamsuddin (Md.) Vs. Anti-CorruptionCommission, represented by its Chairman and others 14 MLR  (2009) (HC) 87 .


Anti-Corruption Commission Act, 2004

Section 27(1) Conviction and sentence Bail inappeal on humanitarian ground

In the instant case the convict- appellant wasconvicted and sentenced to 3 (three) years simple imprisonment. In appeal theHigh Court Division allowed him the bail on humanitarian consideration whichthe apex court found justified and held the High Court Division committed noillegality.

Anti-Corruption Commission, represented by itsChairman, Dhaka Vs. Barrister Mir Mohammad Helal ZJddin and another 15 MLR(2010) (AD) 216.

Anti-Corruption Commission Act, 2004

Section 26 and 32 Authority of the Commission toissue notice requiring a person to submit statement of his assets andliabilities.Requirementof sanction for the prosecution to be accompanied with the charge-sheet.

Requirement of the law is that the person asking tosubmit statement of his assets and liabilities must be given reasonable timeand opportunity. Directing to submit the statement at the time the person wasin detention is not a legal notice in the eye of law. Proceedings initiated onsuch invalid notice and the conviction and sentence passed therein is illegaland not sustainable in law. Only one sanction of the Commission is necessary.

Anti-Corruption Commission, represented by itsChairman Vs. Dr. Mohiuddin Khan Alamgir and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 406.


Anti-CorruptionCommission Act, 2004

Section 32 - Sanction given in prescribed form heldproper Anti-corruption Commission Rules, 2007.

Rule 10 Time limit held directory When trial of thecase has already began and some witnesses are examined and cross-examined, thelearned judges of the High Court Division found no cogent ground to quash theproceedings at this stage.

Habibur Rahman Motlah Vs. The State 14 MLR (2009)(HC) 94.


Anti-CorruptionCommission Act, 2004

Section 32(2) Does not apply to cases prior to theAct coming into operation No res-judicata.

There is no res-judicata in the Criminaljurisdiction except the bar provided under section 403 Cr.p.c. When steps undersection; 6(5) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act,1958 were duly taken, there wasno legal requirement to obtain sanction any more. Section 32 of theAnti-Corruption Commission Act,2004 has no manner of application to the casesprior to the Acts coming into force.

Mostafa Kamal and others Vs. Salahuddin Ahmad andothers 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 412.

 

Anti-CorruptionCommission Rules, 2007

Rule 16-To lay and conduct trap to catch hold of anaccused red handed and the requirement of the officer so conducting trap to beempowered by the Anti-Corruption Commission.

To empower an officer by the commissionerin charge of, investigation lay trap and conduct the proceedings required underrule 16 of the Anti-corruption Commission Rules, 2007 ismandatory requirement of law. In absence of such empowerment or authorisation the learned judges held proceedings’ illegal and abuse of the court and as such quashed the same.

R Kabir (Md.) Vs.State and another 14 MLR (2009)(HC) 482.

 
2831

Arbitration Act, 1940

Citation: 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 162, 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 366

Case Year: 1940

Subject: Arbitration

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Arbitration Act, 1940

Section 14(2)— An award made after 4 months of entering into the reference held valid—

In the absence of any different intention contained in the arbitration agreement, where the parties participated without any objection in the proceedings continued beyond 4 months of entering into the reference in which the arbitrators made the disputed award, the apex court held the award valid. Ahmed Rashid (Mohd.) and others Vs. Mohammad Shafi and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 162.

Section  34-   Provides   for   stay   of proceedings    of    suit    for    arbitral reference—

Defendants in a suit before taking, any steps may seek for staying further proceedings of the suit and referring the dispute for resolution through arbitration. After certain steps are taken by the defendants upon submission to the jurisdiction of the Civil Court, further proceedings of the suit can not be stayed as contemplated under section 34 of the Arbitration Act, 1940. Popular Biscuit Limited Vs. Biximco Bremer Export Contor Brand and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 366.

2832

Arbitration Act, 2001

Citation: 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 265, 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 441, 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 153,

Case Year: 2001

Subject: Arbitration Act

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Arbitration Act, 2001 

Section   10—   Equally   applies   to international  commercial  arbitration whether    held    in    Bangladesh    or outside—

Section 10 of the Arbitration Act, 2001 provides for stay of judicial proceedings and referral of dispute arising out of commercial contracts for resolution by arbitration where there is agreement between the parties to that effect. In such a case when the defendant before filing written statement applies, the court shall stay of the proceedings and refer the dispute to arbitration. The provisions of section 10 applies equally to international commercial arbitration whether held in Bangladesh or in any other country. HRC Shipping Ltd. Vs. MV X-Press Manaslu and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 265.

Sections 23, 25, 42 and 43— Arbitral Tribunal is mandatorily required to follow the procedure and deal with the issues at      dispute  fairly and impartially—

Award by majority does not mean exclusion of the other member from the participation in deliberation. Where Arbitral Tribunal is composed of more than one member all the members must participate in the deliberation of the arbitral proceeding before the finalisation and signing of the award. Award made by violating the mandatory provision is not sustainable in the eye of law. M/S Saudi Bangladesh Services Company Ltd. Vs. Saudi Arabian Airlines Corporation 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 441.

 

Sections 42 and 43— Setting aside the arbitral award on ground of being opposed to law and public policy—

Section 73— Counter claim based on remote and indirect consequence is not admissible—

The dispute in the instant case was referred to a three-member arbitration tribunal which made the impugned award. The third member gave a dissenting note as he was not given the opportunity of participation in the deliberation. The Arbitration Tribunal did not allow the counter claim based on remote and indirect consequences as provided under section 73 of the Contract Act, 1872 with which the apex court concurred, but held that in order to be sustainable the award must be by majority upon participation of all the members of the tribunal which is the requirement of law. As the impugned award has not been passed in accordance with law and is opposed to public policy the High Court Division set-aside the same which the Appellate Division upheld. Saudi Arabian Air Lines Corporation, represented by its Country Manager Vs. M/S Saudi Bangladesh Services Company Ltd, represented by its Managing Director 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 153.

Sections 42 and 43— Setting aside arbitral award on the grounds enumerated u/s 43—

Contract Act, 1872—

Section 73— Not attracted in the instant case—

The appellant claimed compensation on account of delay in. completion of the project. The Arbitration Tribunal did not allow compensation on account of the delay. The District Judge refused to set aside the award as there was no such ground as enumerated under section 43 of the Arbitration Act, 2001. The High Court Division held section 73 of the Contract Act, 1872 is not attracted in the instant case. It is further held arbitral award can only be set aside when it is opposed to law and public policy, excessive, malafide and not based on materials on record. As the arbitral award does not suffer from any infirmity the learned judges of the High Court Division dismissed the appeal. Bangladesh Power Development Board and others Vs. M/s Arab Contractors (BD) Ltd. and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 153.

2833

Arms Act, 1878

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 224, 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 121

Case Year: 1878

Subject: Arms Act

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Arms Act, 1878

 

 Section 18(a)(b)— Cancellation of fire arms licence when there is no valid ground— Licence cannot be cancelled merely on the ground of instituting a case—

A person cannot be treated as guilty of an offence unless he is convicted in a criminal case by a court of competent jurisdiction. Merely because a criminal case has been filed against him, he can not be treated as guilty. When there is no case of conviction of an offence under the Arms Act, 1878 and when there is no allegation of using the firearms in illegal activities against the respondent his licence cannot be cancelled. The High Court Divison declared the cancellation order as illegal which the apex court held perfectly justified. Government of Bangladesh and others Vs. Md. Shahjahan Gazi 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 224.

 

Arms Rules, 1924 Rules   43 —   Provisions   of   appeal against   cancellation    of    fire    arms licence —

For reasons to be recorded fire arms licence may be cancelled by the appropriate authority empowered in this behalf. Rule 43 provides for an appeal to the higher authority against such cancellation. Writ petition in respect of cancellation of fire arms licence is not maintainable without exhausting the statutory remedy by way of appeal. Bashirur Rahman Khan Chowdhiiry & Yahia Chowdhiiry Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 121.

2834

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990

Citation: 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 198, 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 194, 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 343, 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 73, 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 281, 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 234, 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 308, 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 409, 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 1, 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 266, 15 MLR (2010) (A

Case Year: 1990

Subject: Artha Rin Adalat Ain

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990

 

Definition of loan — Loan includes the principal and interest etc —

The controversy as to the definition of the term "loan" has been settled by the Appellate Division which includes the principal, interest and penal interest etc. Fazle Kader Mukul (Md.) Vs. Bangladesh and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 198.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 Section 4(2)(3)— Held by the Apex Court— Not ultravires the constitution—

The legislature in its wisdom made provisions in section 4(2) and (3) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 for the establishment of the Artha Rin Adalat and appointment of the judge thereof which are not inconsistent with and violative of the provisions of article 55(2), 115 and 116 of the Constitution and as such the suit filed in the Artha Rin Adalat for recovery of loan money of the financial institution is quite maintainable. A.R.A Jute Mills Ltd. Vs. Janata Bank and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 194.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990— Section 5 and 6— Imposes restriction against appeal  and revision against interlocutory   order   of   Artha    Rin Adalat— Section   7—   Provides   for   appeal against order and decree of Artha Rin Adalat—

Constitution of Bangladesh—

Article 102 and 109— Extra ordinary power of the High Court Division of judicial review— Under article 102 High Court Division is invested with power of judicial review of certain orders against which there is no provision of appeal or revision. Power of High Court Division under article 109 is of administrative nature.

The apex court held the power of High Court Division under article 102 of the Constitution can not be taken away or curtailed by subordinate legislation i.e. the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 and as such the writ petition against interlocutory order passed by Artha Rin Adalat quite maintainable. Harun-or-Rashid (Md.) Vs. Pubali Bank Ltd. and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 343.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990— Section 6— Provides for bar against filing separate suit for setting aside exparte  decree passed  by Artha  Rin Adalat—

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Order 7 rule 11— Rejection of plaint in suit barred by law—

It is well settled that no separate suit shall lie against exparte decree passed by Artha Rin Adalat as provided under section 6 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990. The remedy against exparte decree is available under Order 9 Rule 13 of the Code of Civil Procedure upon deposit of 50% decretal dues. The rejection of plaint in the suit is held perfectly justified. M. Tariqullah Sikder Vs. Sonali Bank 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 73.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990— Section      6(ka)—      Excludes      the application of rule 3, 5, 6, 7, 8 and 9 of Order 21 but does not exclude the application of section 65 of the Code of Civil Procedure— Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Section 56— Applies against arrest and   detention   of   woman   in   civil prison—

Since the application of section 56 of the Code of Civil Procedure has not been excluded by section 6(ka) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990, the prohibition againt arrest and detention of woman in civil prison in execution of decree of Artha Rin Adalat shall apply. Hazera Begum Vs. Artha Rin Adalat and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 281.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990— Section  6(2)— Provides  for setting aside exparte decree—

Since specific provisions are there under section 6(2) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 for setting aside ex­parte decree, inherent jurisdiction of the court under section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure can not be invoked for setting aide the same. Goden Re-Rolling Industries Ltd. Vs. Subordinate Judge, Artha. Rin Adalat No. 1 Dhaka and another 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 234.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990— Section   7—   Provides   for   appeal against the judgment  and  decree  of Artha  Rin  Adalat  and  as  such Writ Petition does not lie thereagainst— Constitution of Bangladesh— Article  102— Writ Petition  against judgment and  decree  of Artha  Rin Adalat is not maintainable—

Alternative efficacious remedy is available against the judgment and decree of the Artha Rin Adalat by way of appeal as provided under section 7 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain 1990 and as such Writ Petition under article 102 of the constitution does not lie against such judgment and decree. Therefore the law on this point is well settled. Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation (BADC) represented by Chairman Vs. Artha Rin Adalat, Court No. 3 Dhaka and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 308.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990—

Section 7— Order, judgment and decree passed by Artha Rin Adalat are appealable against which no revision lies—

Law is well settled that appeal lies to the High Court Division against an order, judgment and decree passed by the Artha Rin Adalat as provided under sections 6 and 7 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 and as such no revision thereagainst under section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 is maintainable. Bulbul Electric Market (M/S) and others Vs. Rupali Bank Ltd. and another 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 409.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990— Section 41— Provides for an appeal against an order or decree passed by Artha Rin Adalat to be filed within 30 days of the date thereof together with deposit of 50% decretal amount—

Requirement of the deposit of 50% decretal amount as provided under section 41 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 is mandatory prerequisite and the statutory period of 30 days for filing appeal is special limitation which cannot be extended. Memorandum of appeal accompanied with the document showing deposit of 50% decretal amount must be filed within 30 days of the date of an order or decree appealed against. An appeal filed within 30 days without the deposit of 50% decretal amount but the deposit is made subsequently after the statutory period though under the direction of the High Court Division is held by the apex court not entertainable. Peninsular Shipping Service Ltd. Vs. M/S Faruque Paint and Varnish Manufacturing Co. Ltd. and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 1.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990—

Section 60(3)— Transfer of Execution case from one Artha Rin Adalat to another Artha Rin Adalat in the same district— held not illegal—

The Appellate Division found nothing wrong with the transfer of the Money Execution case from one Artha Rin Adalat to another Artha Rin Adalat of the same district and refrained from interfering with the impugned order. M/S. Llttara Steel Corporation Limited and another Vs. judge, Artha Rin Adalat and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 266.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Writ petition is held not maintainable against stay of all actions for registration of two buses purchased by the loan of the bank— The impugned action of BRTA cropped up out of the proceedings relating to suit for recovery of loan. The High Court Division held the writ petition not maintainable. The Appellate Division also concurred with the impugned decision of the High Court Division. Monir Hossain Vs. The Artha Rin Adalat No. 4, Dhaka and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 236.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003— Execution proceedings ends with the completion of the auction process—

Auction of the mortgaged property was held at the instance of the decree-holder bank. Auction sale was confirmed by the court and the decree-holder bank had withdrawn the bid money in consequence whereof the execution proceedings came to an end. Thereafter the continuation of the proceedings shall be redundant. Sonali Bank, Shilpa Bhaban Corporate Branch Dhaka Vs. Artha Rin Adalat Nami/anganj and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 20.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003— Remission of interest—Writ petitioner can not get the advantage of wrong committed by bank official in calculation of interest. The writ petitioner cannot get the benefit of remission in respect of the interest paid before grant of such remission. The interest so paid shall be adjusted with the principal. Ebrahim Steel Re-Rolling Industries Pvt Ltd Vs. Bangladesh and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 190.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003— Necessary parties in suit for recovery of loan—

Shareholder of a company is not liable for repayment of loan and as such is not necessary party. The Chairman or the directors who executed the charge documents and mortgaged property as security against the loan are necessary parties in a suit for recovery of the loan. The chairman if did not execute any charge document or stood as guarantor, is not necessary party merely by reason of his being the chairman. Bakul Akter (Mrs.) Vs. Bangladesh and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 225.

 

 Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003— Section 6— Provisions of the Code of Civil   Procedure,   1908   applicable   to proceedings of the Artha Rin Adalat so far not inconsistent therewith— Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Section 148 and 149— Power of the Adalat to enlarge the time for putting in deficit court fee—Order 7 rule ll(c) Rejection of plaint for non-payment of deficit court fee within specified time—

To put in deficit court fee within 21 days is not the mandatory requirement of law and as such the Adalat can enlarge the time under section 148 and 149 of the Code of Civil Procedure. When the deficit court fee is subsequently paid and the Adalat accepted the same there is no ground for rejection of the plaint. Apparels Limited and another Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 149.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003—

Section 12(8)— Deposit of the rest of the auction money within next 10 (ten) days is not mandatory and the provision of sub-section (2) of section 33 is not applicable to the auction sale held under section 12—

The provision of section 33(2) is applicable to the cases of auction sale held in pursuance of the execution of decree of the court and not to the cases of auction sale held under section 12. Zinnatul Ara and others Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 185.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003— Section 33(5)—

Issuance of certificate of sale of the mortgaged property in favour of the decree-holder when the auction sale could not be held due to low price offered by the bidders, terminates the execution proceedings leaving behind no scope of stay of further proceedings and to grant instalment in payment of decretal amount. Mohiuddin (Sk.) Vs. Joint District Judge and Artha Rin Adalat No. 3, Dhaka and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 356.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003—

Section 33(7)— Conferment of title of the mortgaged property to the decree holder bank when auction sale could not be held despite taking all necessary steps—

In exercise of the power vested in it under section 33(7) of the Artha  Rin Adalat Ain, 2003, the Artha Rin Adalat upon an application can pass an order conferring    title    of    the    mortgaged property upon the decree holder bank and issue a certificate to that effect when after taking all the necessary steps the auction sale could not be held due to no bidder coming up  to  participate. The j learned   judges   of   the   High   Court Division   held   the   impugned   order perfectly justified. Setara Begum (Mosammat) Vs. Al-Arafa I Islami Bank Ltd. and others 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 480.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003—

Section 34— Empowers the Artha Rin Adalat to pass order for civil imprisonment against the judgment-debtor—

Section 34 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 empowers the Artha Rin Adalat to pass order for civil imprisonment against the judgment-debtor to compel payment of decretal dues, section 34 is not dependent on section 33. When inspite of steps taken by the decree-holder, no auction purchaser came up the Artha Rin Adalat was competent to pass order for civil imprisonment. The civil imprisonment is not the alternative provision and as such it does not absolve the liability of paying the decretal dues. The Appellate Division held the High Court Division was perfectly justified in passing the impugned judgment and order. Proval Kumar Das Vs. Manager Agrani Bank, Main Branch Shahcb Bazar, Rajshahi and another 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 96.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003— Section 34— Empowers the Artha Rin Adalat to pass order for civil imprisonment against judgment-debtor when auction sale of the mortgaged property could not be held for any reason—

In the instant case the Artha Rin Adalat on the prayer of the decree- holder, directly passed order for civil imprisonment against the judgment-debtor to compel him to pay the decretal amount when inspite of steps taken, auction sale of the mortgaged property could not be held due to non-availability of bidders. The learned judges of the High Court Division in view of the position of law held the impugned order passed by the Artha Rin Adalat is perfectly justified. Pravat Kumar Das Vs. Manager, Agrani Bank, Main Branch, Shaheb Bazar, Rajshahi and others 15 MLR (2010) (HO 122.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003— Section 34(1)— Issue of warrant to compel the judgment-debtor to pay the outstanding decretal dues—

In the execution proceeding all the provisions relating to auction sale of the mortgaged property were exhausted but without any positive result. Thereafter on the prayer of the decree-holder, the Adalat issued warrant u/s 34(1) of the Ain to compel payment of decretal dues with which the learned judges of the High Court Division found no fault. M.A Jaher and others Vs. Sonali Bank and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 283.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003— Section 34(1)— Issue of warrant of arrest to compel the judgment-debtor to    pay    the    decretal    dues    is    not improper—

As the land under mortgage was diluvated into the river, there was no scope for the decree-holder bank to sell the same. In such situation on the prayer of the decree-holder the Artha Rin Adalat issued warrant of arrest against the judgment-debtor to compel to pay the decretal dues as provided under section 34(1) of the Ain with which the learned judges of the High Court Division found nothing wrong. Bashirullali Master Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 269.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003— Section 34(1)— Provisions are held not ultravires of the Constitution—

Issuance of warrant of arrest against the judgment-debtor before compliance with the provisions of section 34(9)(10) held illegal. It has already been decided in a number of cases that the provision of sub-section (1) of section 34 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 since amended are not inconsistent or ultravires of the Constitution. Before issue of warrant of arrest the decree-holder bank is required to take steps under section 34(9)(10) of the Ain for sale of mortgaged property. In the instant case the learned judges of the High Court Division having found the impugned order violative of the provisions of section 34(9) and (10) set aside the same. Jaliangir Chowdhun/ (Mohd.) alias Jahangir Alain Chowdhun/ Vs'. Judge, Artha Rin Adalat No. 1, Chittagong and another 14 MLR (2009) (HO 293.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003—

Section 34(1)— Issuance of warrant of arrest against judgment-debtor is not dependent on the prior compliance with the provisions of sub-sections (5), (6) and (7) of section 33—

In the instant case warrant of arrest was issued against the judgment-debtor in execution proceedings under section 34(1) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 in a situation when no intending purchaser was forth coming pursuant to the attempts to sell the pledged property, the learned judges of the High Court Division found nothing wrong with the impugned order and held that the issuance of warrant of arrest against judgment-debtor to compel him to pay the decretal dues is not dependent on the compliance with the provisions of sub-sections (5), (6), and (7) of section 33. M.A Jaher and others Vs. Sonali Bank and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 64.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003—

Section 34(2) Exemption of the substituted heirs of the mortgagor and guarantor from arrest and civil imprisonment—

Sub-section (2) of section 34 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain provides for the exemption of the substituted heirs of the judgment-debtor from arrest and civil imprisonment in connection with the execution of the decree of Artha Rin Adalat. The learned judges of the High Court Division held the provisions of sub-section (2) of section 34 are equally applicable to the substituted heirs of the mortgagor and the guarantor. Akramuzzaman (Md.) alias Babu Vs. Artha Rin Adalat No.l, Rajbari and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 1.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003— Section 37— Time limit for disposal of Artha Rin Execution case is directory and not mandatory—

Since section 37 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain 2003 does not provide for any consequence in the event the execution case is not disposed of within the time limit, the learned judges of the High Court Division held the provisions of section 37 as directory and not mandatory. Abul Basher (Md.) Vs. Judge 1st Artha Rin Adalat, Chittagong and others 13 MLR (2008) (HO 208.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003

Section 41 — Appeal against order passed by Artha Rin Adalat in Execution case without deposit of 50% decretal money is not maintainable —

Artha Rin Adalat Ain being a special statute shall prevail over all other laws including the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908. Appeal against order of rejection of application for setting aside auction sale on ground of low valuation without deposit of 50% decretal amount is held by the Appellate Division as no appeal in the eye of law. Korea-Bangladesh Food Products Ltd. Vs. National Bank Limited and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 253.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 — Section 41 — Held not ultravires of the    constitution    and    violative    of fundamental rights — Constitution of Bangladesh — Article 102 — Writ petition does not lie  against judgment  and  decree  of Artha Rin Adalat. As there is specific provision of appeal under section 41 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 Writ Petition under article 102 of the Constitution does not lie against judgment   and   decree   of   Artha   Rin Adalat. Anisur Rahman @ K.M. Ziaul. Hague Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 75.

 

Artha Rin Adalat Am, 2003— Section 44— Provides that no appeal or revision lies against interlocutory order passed by Artha Rin Adalat— Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Order XXI, rule 90-— Application for setting aside auction sale—

In the instant case the appellant filed the miscellaneous appeal against an interlocutory order passed by the Artha Rin Adalat rejecting an application for setting aside auction sale in execution case without complying with the requirements of section 41 and as such the learned judges of the High Court Division dismissed the appeal as being one not maintainable. Awlad Hossain Vs. Bangladesh Shilpa Bank, Maijd.ee Branch and others 15 MLR (2010) (HO 444.

 

2835

Bangladesh Abandoned Property (Management, Control and Disposal) Order 1972 (P.O. No.16 of 1972)

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 116

Case Year: 1972

Subject: Bangladesh Abandoned Property

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh Abandoned Property

(Management, Control and Disposal) Order 1972 (P.O. No.16 of 1972)

 Article 10— Monthly tenancy right in the premises continues and remains unaffected when the land lord accepted the rents from the legal heirs after the death of the original tenant—

So long the tenancy is not terminated in accordance with law the tenancy right in the premises remains unaffected. The tenancy in the premises was created, by the Abandoned Property Authority as the Custodian thereof and the said authority accepted rents from the petitioner after the death of his father and as such the tenancy right continues as before even after transfer of the premises if any validly made under the new transferee. Jaimil Abedin Jamal Vs. Qais Hilda and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 116.

2836

Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation (Employees Service) Regulations, 1990

Citation: 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 44, 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 197

Case Year: 1990

Subject: Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation

(Employees Service) Regulations, 1990

Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation (Employees Service) Regulations, 1990

Promotion of employees is based on the principle of seniority-curn-efficiency— Introduction of viva-voce examination not provided in the Regulations is held illegal— Seniority of the petitioner restored—

BADC was following the practice of promoting its employees on the basis of seniority-cum-efficiency based on service record. Suddenly the system of viva voce examination was introduced not provided in the service Regulations which was declared illegal by the Appellate Division in a previous case of similar nature. Following the said I decision the learned judges of the High : Court Division declared the introduction of viva voce examination for promotion illegal and directed the respondent to restore seniority of the petitioner. Abdur Rouf (Md.) Vs. Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 44.

Bangladesh Agricultural Develop­ment Corporation (Employees Service) Regulations, 1990—

Regulation 55(2)— Termination of service— Authority's power is not uncontrolled—

Relationship between the employer and employee of the BADC being the statutory authority is not that of a master and servant. The High Court Division refrained from going to declare regulation 55(2) ultravires of the Constitution as the relief sought for could be allowed without striking down the law which the Appellate Division appreciated. Though the authority can terminate the service of undesirable and inefficient employee, the procedure to be followed must be in accordance with law and should not be arbitrary. Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation, represented by the Chairman and another Vs. Md. Shamsul Haque Mazumder and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 197.

2837

Bangladesh Bank Order, 1972

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 377

Case Year: 1972

Subject: Bangladesh Bank Order

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh Bank Order, 1972

Article 42(b)— defines the term borrower—

The petitioners in the instant writ petitions are held by the learned judges of the High Court Division not defaulter borrowers within the meaning of article 42(b) of the Bangladesh Bank Order, 1972 read with section 5(GaGa) and 27 KaKa of the Bank Companies Act, 1991. Since the petitioners transferred their shares in the companies in question with the consent of the lending financial institutions and ceased to be directors of the said companies, they are not liable to be included in the report of defaulters of the Credit Information Bureau of the Bangladesh Bank merely by reason of their being guarantors in the capacity of directors at the time when the companies obtained the loan and subsequently defaulted in the payment thereof. The companies which are defaulter barrowers are liable to be included in the list of defaulters but not the petitioners who have no subsisting interest therein. Mostafa Kamal (Md.) and others Vs. Bangladesh Bank represented bi/ its Governor and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 377.

2838

Bangladesh Biman Corporation Employees (Service) Regulations, 1979

Citation: 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 1, 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 357

Case Year: 1979

Subject: angladesh Biman Corporation Employees (Service) Regulations

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh Biman Corporation Employees (Service) Regulations, 1979

 

Regulation 11A(2)— Biman authority has no power to retire its employee on completion of 25 years of service— Public Servants (Retirement) Act, 1974—

Section 9(2)— Government has power to retire public servant in the public interest on completion of 25 years of service—

The power of the Government under section 9(2) of the Public Servants (Retirement) Act, 1974 has not been delegated to the Biman authority and as such the Biman authority as held by the apex court, can not retire its employee on completion 25 years of service resorting to the provision of Regulation 11 (A) (2) in the manner as contemplated under sub-section (2) of section 9 of the Public Servants (Retirement) Act, 1974. Mir. Mazharul Huq (Capt.) Vs. Bangladesh Biman Corporation and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 1.

 

Bangladesh Biman Corporation Employees (Service) Regulations, 1979—

Regulation 11A(2)— Amendment of Regulations does not take retrospective effect—

Pendency of Review Petition does not provide for any moratorium nor it does render the impugned judgment inoperative. The learned judges of the High Court Division held the amendment of the Regulation has no retrospective effect and as such the impugned retirement of the writ petitioners who joined the service long before the said amendment is illegal and passed without jurisdiction and of no legal effect. Emdad Hossain (Md.) and another Vs. Bangladesh Biman Corporation and others 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 357.

2839

Bangladesh Civil Service Recruitment Rules, 1981

Citation: 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 281, 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 333, 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 138

Case Year: 1981

Subject: Bangladesh Civil Service Recruitment

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh Civil Service Recruitment Rules, 1981

Amendment of clause (d) of schedule II part XX—

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Rule framed in conflict with article 18 declared unconstitutional and void—

The higher qualification for appointment to the post of professor or Associate professors must be maintained in order to ensure high standard of professionalism, which is concerned with the right of people to get satisfactory treatment and medicare. As the amendment of clause (d) of schedule II part XX of the Bangladesh Civil Service Recruitment Rules, 1981 stands in conflict with the constitutional mandate, the learned judges of the High Court Division declared the same as unconstitutional and void. Proffessor D. A. F.M. Ruhul Haque & others vs Bangladesh 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 281.

Rule 7 — Confirmation in service on fulfilment of certain conditions —

eyywbqv`x cÖwk¶b Ges wefvMxq cix¶vq mdjfv‡e DËxY© nIqv wewa 7 Gi Aaxb PvKzix‡Z ¯’vqx Ki‡Yi c~e© kZ© hvnv mKj PvKzixi K¨vWwi‡ii m`‡m¨i †¶‡Î mgfv‡e cÖ‡hvR¨| ïaygvÎ mvavvib wk¶v K¨vWv‡ii AbyËxY© m`‡m¨i PvKzix‡Z ¯’vqx Ki‡Yi my‡hvM m„wói Rb¨ wewa ms‡kvab Ab¨vb¨‡`I †ejvq ˆelg¨g~jK nB‡e weavq ivóªcwZ GBi“c wewa cÖbqb Kwi‡Z cv‡ib bv| ZvQvov f’Zv‡c¶ Kvh©KvwiZv w`qv ˆelg¨g~jK wewa cÖbqb msweav‡bi cwicwš’ weavq nvB‡KvU© wefv‡Mi gvbbxq wePvicwZ ZwK©Z ms‡kvabx wewagvjvwU AeBa ewjqv †NvlYv K‡ib| we.Gg.gwneyi ingvb Ms ebvg evsjv‡`k Ms 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 333.

Bangladesh Civil Service (Recruitment) Rules, 1981 —

Rule 8(l)(dd) — Exemption from appearing in examination of certain persons held not unconstitutional —Constitution of Bangladesh —Article 141C(D— Declaration of emergency by the President suspending the enforcement offundamental rights is not subject of scrutiny by the court—

The Appellate Division held the High Court Division was wrong in disposing of the writ petitions seeking enforcement of fundamental rights during the continuance of the emergency when the fundamental rights were suspended. Declaration of emergency does not come within the scope of scrutiny by the court. The apex court held the Rule 8(l)(dd) of the Bangladesh Civil Service (Recruitment) Rules, 1981 not ultravires of the constitution nor discriminatory or class legislation. Alaur Rahman (Md.) and others Vs. B.M Mahibur Rahman and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 138.

2840

Bangladesh House Building Finance Corporation Order, 1973

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 29

Case Year: 1973

Subject: Bangladesh House Building Finance Corporation

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh House Building Finance Corporation Order, 1973 (P.O. No.7 of 1973)

 

Recovery of loan money by sale of mortgaged property —

Where in a case the outstanding loan money is admittedly due and the petitioner did not contest in the misc. petition even after service of notice, the order passed by the District Judge in accordance with the provisions of the P.O. 7 of 1973 and having been affirmed by the High Court Division, the apex court held the said order perfectly justified and found nothing to interfere. Syed Ehsanul Hossain and another Vs. Bangladesh House Building Finance Corporation 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 29.

2841

Bangladesh Krishi Bank Employees Service Regulations, 1988

Citation: 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 298

Case Year: 1988

Subject: Bangladesh Krishi Bank Employees Service

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh Krishi Bank Employees Service Regulations, 1988

Regulation 47— Contains clear bar to the imposition of penalty in a departmental proceedings during the pendency of criminal case on the self same allegations—

When additional charges are brought in a departmental proceedings the accused must be given the opportunity to show cause against those charge failing which the enquiry proceedings shall be vitiated and the penalty imposed in such proceedings will be illegal. Again when departmental proceedings and criminal case are started on the self same allegations the authority shall withhold the imposition of penalty in the departmental proceedings till the disposal of the criminal case as contemplated in Regulation 47, the violation of these mandatory provisions renders the penalty so imposed illegal and not sustainable in law. Bangladesh Krishi Bank represented by its Managing Director and others Vs. Md. Saidul Haque 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 298.

2842

Bangladesh Petroleum Act, 1974

Citation: 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 322

Case Year: 1974

Subject: Bangladesh Petroleum Act

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh Petroleum Act, 1974

Sections 2(e) and 4(2)—When these two sections are read together, it appears that no agreement or clearance of the Government or the Petroleum Corporation are required to import High Speed Diesel—

Import of Petroleum are shown in the free list. On the other hand there is no provision either in the Import and Export Control Act or in the import policy requiring any agreement with Government or clearance from the Petroleum Corporation for import of High Speed Diesel. Such agreement is required only when the petroleum products are brought within Bangladesh. Accordingly their Lordships of the Appellate Division declared the impugned order illegal and of no legal effect. Secretary, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources, Government of Bangladesh and others Vs. Q.C Petroleum Ltd. and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 322.

2843

Bangladesh Public Service Commission (Conduct of Business) Rules, 1981

Citation: 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 314

Case Year: 1981

Subject: Bangladesh Public Service Commission

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh Public Service Commission

(Conduct of Business) Rules, 1981

Rules 16 and 17— These two rules provide for distinctly two separate procedure for selection of candidates by the Public Service Commission (PSO)—

 

The procedure for selection of candidates for recruitment at the entry level through written examination has been specified under rule 16 while that for   the   selection   for   appointment/ promotion to  the higher position in specialised  subject through viva voce test has been defined under rule  17. Their    lordships    of    the    Appellate Division of the Supreme Court held the procedure of rule 17 is applicable to the instant case and as such further held the impugned selection was properly made by the P.S.C. Accordingly the apex court allowed the appeals arid set aside the judgment of the High Court Division. Dr. Mohammad Sanvar Ramiz and others Vs. Dr. Shyam Sundar Kunda and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 314.

2844

Bangladesh Rifles (Special Provisions) Ordinance, 1976

Citation: 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 515

Case Year: 1976

Subject: Bangladesh Rifles

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh Rifles (Special Provisions) Ordinance, 1976

Section 8— Competent authority to dismiss a Havildar from service—

The writ petitioner challenged the order of his dismissal from service on ground that the said order was not passed by the competent authority. The High Court Division allowed the writ petition. The apex court found that the writ petitioner did not produce the order of his dismissal from service. But from the papers produced by the respondent it is found that the impugned order was passed by the competent authority and as    such    set    aside    the    impugned judgment and order. Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs Vs. Md. Anwar Hossain 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 515.

2845

Bangladesh Service Rules Part I

Citation: 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 460, 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 12

Subject: Bangladesh Service Rules

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh Service Rules Part I

Rule 34— A Government servant ceases to be in service in consequence of his continuous absence from duties for more than five years without leave—

In the instant case the respondent filed the application u/s 4(1) before taking any decision by the departmental higher authority and as such the application is held not maintainable. Moreover the respondent tendered his resignation and remained absent from duty for more than 25 years without leave and in consequence whereof he ceased to be in the government employment as provided under rule 34 of the BSR Part-I. The apex court held the impugned judgment of the Administrative Tribunal and Administrative Appellate Tribunal illegal and set-aside the same. Government of Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Food and others Vs. A.B.M Siddique Mia 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 460.

 

Rule 52— Also provides for the penalty of reduction to be for specified period—

As provided under rule 52 of the Bangladesh Service Rules Part I read with rule 4 (3)(a) of the Government Servants (Discipline and Appeal) Rules 1985 the authority while imposing the penalty of reduction in rank must specify the period during which such penalty shall exist. When the period is not specified in the order the penalty itself where the charges are established, can not be set aside but be modified. Anwar Hossain (Md.) Vs. Government of Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Finance and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 12.

2846

Bangladesh Sheikh Mujib Medical University Act, 1998

Citation: 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 334

Case Year: 1998

Subject: Bangladesh Sheikh Mujib Medical University

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh Sheikh Mujib Medical University Act, 1998

Section 5—Provides for the procedure of appointing teacher after the approval of the Syndicate on the recommendation of the selection committee—

Appointment of respondent No 6 as Professor of Neuro Surgery without the approval of the Syndicate and having been made in violation of the set criteria and provision of law has been declared illegal and  made without any lawful authority. Dr. Kanak Kanti Barua Vs. Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujib Medical University and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 334.

2847

Bangladesh Shilpa Rin Sangstha Order, 1972

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 329

Case Year: 1972

Subject: Bangladesh Shilpa Rin Sangstha

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh Shilpa Rin Sangstha Order,

1972 (P.O. No.128 of 1972)

Article 33(5)—Notice requiring payment of the money before passing decree is mandatory requirement of law—

District Judge is mandated under article 33(5) of the P.O. No.128 of 1972 to issue notice to the other party to make payment of the money in question before passing the decree which is the mandatory requirement of law. As the District Judge passed the decree without issue of such notice the decree so passed being illegal was set aside by the High Court Division which the apex court found perfectly justified. Bangladesh Shilpa Rin Sangstha BSRS   j Vs. Mrs. Monozvara Begum being dead her heir Mir Md. Iqbal Hossain and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 329.

2848

Bangladesh Supreme Court (Appellate Division) Rules, 1988

Citation: 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 296, 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 38, 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 167, 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 239

Case Year: 1988

Subject: Bangladesh Supreme Court (Appellate Division)

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh Supreme Court (Appellate Division) Rules, 1988

 

Rule  26—  Grounds  for review  of judgment—

Unless there is ground of error of law apparent on the face of the record occasioning failure of justice, Review Petition cannot be entertained. Despite the ouster clause of jurisdiction Civil Court can scrutinise the impugned order to see as to whether the same is passed in accordance with law. An issue which was never raised earlier cannot be raised for the first time at the stage of review before the Appellate Division. Sena Kalyan Sangstha and another Vs. Hazi Sufi Fazal Ahmed being dead his heirs Nazir Mohiuddin and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 296.

 

Rule 26— Review of judgment does not mean rehearing of the matter already decided on merit—

Where the issues were finally decided upon consideration of evidence on record, the review of the judgment in such a case can not be allowed. Review of judgment does not mean rehearing of the matter already finally decided on merit. Shamima Akhtar Vs. Md. Tofazzal Hossain and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 38.

 

Section 26— Review of judgment— scope and ground—

Review of judgment can only be made on the ground of error apparent on the face of the judgment or on the discovery of important evidence which could not be produced inspite of exercise of due diligence. When the grounds raised were already answered in the judgment the review thereof is not maintainable. Mozaffar Ahmed Miah (Mohd.) Vs. The State and another 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 167.

 

 Rule 26 — Review of judgment —

Review is not meant for rehearing the matter already finally decided by pronouncement of judgment. Except in exceptional circumstances on ground of error aparent on the face of the record or discovery of new and material evidence and error in interpretation of law, review of judgment can not be entertained. General Manager, Postal Insurance and another Vs. A.B.M Abu Taher 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 239.

2849

Bangladesh (Taking over of Control and Management of Industrial and commercial Concerns) Order, 1972 (Acting President Order No.l of 1972)

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 86

Case Year: 1972

Subject: Bangladesh (Taking over of Control and Management of Industrial and commercial Concerns)

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh (Taking over of Control and Management of Industrial and commercial Concerns) Order, 1972 (Acting President Order No.l of 1972)

Article 2 — Taking over the control and management of Industrial concern by the Government when the owner and management are not available —

The disputed industrial concern was being run by the Managing Director who is son of the owner at the relevant time and as such there was no situation for the government to take over the same as abandoned property. The conditions as contemplated under the Acting President Order, 1972 (Acting President Order No.l of 1972) were not at all present and as such the impugned taking over is illegal and without jurisdiction purported to have been made by colourable exercise of the authority. Again when the owner never reliquished his citizenship and was temporarily absent from Bangladesh in connection with performing holy haj his citizenship was never lost. Chairman, Sena Kalayan Sangstha Vs. Haji Sufi Fazal Ahmed being dead his heirs Nazar Mohiuddin and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 86.

 

2850

Bangladesh Telecommunications Act, 2001

Citation: 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 369, 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 114, 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 65, 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 201

Case Year: 2001

Subject: Bangladesh Telecommunications

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bangladesh Telecommunications Act, 2001 

Section 3(2)— Excludes the application of the law to grant licence for Radio and Television Broadcasting—

Unless there is any ambiguity in the language of an enactment, the court is not authorised to import any meaning different and inconsistent with the plain meaning thereto by interpretation. Section 3(2) of the Bangladesh Telecommunications Act, 2001 clearly excludes the application of the Act and the authority of the Bangladesh Telecommunication Regulatory Commission (BTRC) to grant any licence for Radio and Television Broadcasting. However the BTRC has the power to allocate frequency spectrum to those who are granted licence or no objection certificate by the Ministry of Information for Radio and Television Broadcasting. Chairman, Bangladesh Telecommunication Regulatory Commission and others Vs. Ekushey Television Ltd. and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 369.

Bangladesh Telecommunications Act, 2001—

Section 36— Grant of licence and allocation of frequency by the BTRC and their cancellation—

Bangladesh Telecommunications Regulatory Commission (BTRC) has the exclusive jurisdiction to grant licence for telecom system and services under section 36 of the Bangladesh telecommunications Act, 2001. But it can not grant licence for broadcasting and telecasting programmes through satellite channels. In the instant ease the Ministry of Information issued "No Objection Certificate"(NOC) which is not a licence in the true sense of the term. BTRC allocated the frequency and NOC for importing equipments in favour of the Jamuna Television which was subsequently cancelled without affording any opportunity of defence. The Appellate Division held the cancellation of allocation and NOC during the validity period without issuing any show cause notice illegal and without jurisdiction. Ministry of Information, represented by its Secretary, Government of Bangladesh and others Vs. Jamuna Television Limited and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 114.

Bangladesh Telecommunications Act, 2001 (Act No. 18 of 2001)—

Section 37(3)(g), 89 and 90— Monopoly in providing telecom Services by particular operator being opposed to the National policy is prohibited and the Bangladesh Telecommunication           Regulatory Commission is vested with the power to amend the licence condition.

Contract Act, 1872—

Section 23— Agreement opposed to public policy is void—

The Bangladesh Telecommunication Regulatory Commission (BTRC) is empowered under sections 89 and 90 of the Bangladesh Telecommunications Act, 2001 to amend any condition of licence or licence agreement which'are inconsistent with the provisions of the Act. The co-exclusivity agreement of the World Tel for 4 years in the Dhaka Multi-Exchange area in disregard of the huge unmet demand of the customers having been found opposed to public interest has been cancelled by the BTRC in exercise of its power under the law. The High Court Division upon scrutiny of the relevant provisions of the law held the impugned order of cancellation perfectly justified. The Appellate Division having found nothing wrong in the findings and decision upheld the judgment and order of the High Court Division and dismissed the civil petition for leave to appeal. World Tel Bangladesh Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary Ministry of Post and Telecommunications and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 65.

 

Bangladesh Telecommunications Act, 2001

Section 90— Power of the Bangladesh Telecommunication  Regulatory Commission (BTRC) to amend/cancel condition of licence—

The Bangladesh Telecommunication Regulatory Commission in exercise of its power under section 90 of the Bangladesh Telecommunications Act, 2001 cancelled the exclusivity clause of the licence of the World Tel prohibiting the entry of the other operators for 4 (four) years in the Dhaka Central Zone  as the clause being monopolistic was opposed to law and National policy. The High Court Division held the impugned order to be perfectly justified. The court further held there is no provision in the BT Act, 2001 which provides for any such monopoly to any particular operator and that the right accrued under the previous regulation can not be taken away by subsequent regulation. World Tel Bangladesh Ltd. Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 201.

2851

BANGLADESH WATER DEVELOPMENT BOARD (EMPLOYEES) SERVICE RULES, 1982

Citation: 7 BLD (HCD) 89

Case Year: 1982

Subject: BANGLADESH WATER DEVELOPMENT BOARD

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 

 

BANGLADESH WATER DEVELOPMENT BOARD (EMPLOYEES) SERVICE RULES, 1982

 

Rule—20(1)

Whether an employee shall be deemed to have been promoted to a higher post from the fact that he was allowed to hold a higher post for long 14 months without specification as to whether he was holding the same on a current charge or on an officiating basis—Promotion is an act of volition—A matter of positive action to be taken by the appropriate authority—It must be achieved by a process of selection, nomination and communication as per rules—One cannot import a legal fiction in a service matter.

Monirul Huq Vs. Government of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh, through the Secretary, Ministry of Irrigation, Water Development and Flood Control and others; 7 BLD (HCD) 89.

 

RuIe—33(e)

Status of an additional post—What happens to an employee when he is allowed to hold current charge of an additional post for a period exceeding three months—In the absence of any consequences provided for in the Rule the Court allow the status of a post to undergo a radical transformation—After the expiry of three months the additional post shall neither be deemed to be a substantive post nor that the employee holding current charge of an additional post shall be deemed to be promoted to the additional post.

Monirul Huq Vs. Government of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh, through the Secretary, Ministry of Irrigation, Water Development and Flood Control and others; 7 BLD (HCD) 89.

 

2852

Bank Companies Act, 1991

Citation: 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 74, 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 353, 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 377, 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 434

Case Year: 1991

Subject: Bank Companies Act

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Bank Companies Act, 1991

 

Section 2— Other existing laws are not affected— Local Government (Union Parishads) Ordinance, 1983— Section 7(2)(Chha)— Bank loan defaulter— failure to repay any of the instalments makes the loanee a defaulter—

Section 2 of the Bank Companies Act, 1991 provides that the other provisions of the existing laws are not affected by the provisions of Act, 1991 and as such a loanee who defaulted in the repayment of any of the instalments of the loan money within specified date is a defaulter and disqualified to contest in election as provided under section 7(2)(Chha) of the Local Government (Union Parishads) Ordinance, 1983. Belal Hossain Vs. Kazi jane Alain and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 74.

 

Section 5(gaga) and section 27kaka— Guarantor is not a loan defaulter and as such his name can not be included in the CIB list—

Although the financial institution can pursue against the guarantor when the principal borrower fails to repay the loan money for recovery of the same, he is not a loan defaulter as defined under the Bank Companies Act, 1991. Therefore the learned judges of the High Court Division held the name of the guarantor cein not be included in the CIB list and as such declared the impugned CIB list as illegal and of no legal effect. Mahmudur Rahman and another Vs. Bangladesh Bank and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 353.

 

Bank Companies Act, 1991— Section   5(GaGa) and 27 KaKa— the names of defaulter  borrowers   are required to be included in the report of the Credit Information Bureau— Bangladesh Bank Order, 1972— Article   42(b)—   defines   the   term borrower—

The petitioners in the instant writ petitions are held by the learned judges of the High Court Division not defaulter borrowers within the meaning of article 42(b) of the Bangladesh Bank Order, 1972 read with section 5(GaGa) and 27 KaKa of the Bank Companies Act, 1991. Since the petitioners transferred their shares in the companies in question with the consent of the lending financial institutions and ceased to be directors of the said companies, they are not liable to be included in the report of defaulters of the Credit information Bureau of the Bangladesh Bank merely by reason of their being guarantors in the capacity of directors at the time when the companies obtained the loan and subsequently defaulted in the payment thereof. The companies which are defaulter barrowers are liable to be included in the list of defaulters but not the petitioners who have no subsisting interest therein. Mostafa Kamal (Md.) and others Vs. Bangladesh Bank represented by its Governor and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 377.

 

Bank Companies Act, 1991— Section 27 kaka— Inclusion of the name of Bank loan defaulter in the CIB Report—

The petitioner took loan from the Bank and thereafter failed to repay the same in terms thereof. The Bank concerned instituted suit in the Artha Rin Adalat for recovery of the loan against which the petitioner resorted to various litigations. The Bank in turn furnished information to the Bangladesh Bank whereupon the petitioner's name was included in the CIB Report. The High Court Division found nothing wrong with such inclusion. Sultana Jute Mills Ltd and another Vs. Bangladesh Bank and others 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 434.

2853

Bankruptcy Act, 1997

Citation: 8 BLT (AD)-175

Subject: Bankruptcy

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 

 

Bankruptcy Act, 1997

 

Section-28(b)

In an application under Section 28(b) of the Act the defendant in a bankruptcy suit must undisputedly satisfy the Court that he has sufficient ability to repay the debts for which he stands guarantee on behalf of the loanee and that he is not a willful defaulter. Merely because he stands as guarantee he is not entitled to an order for dismissal of the suit. 5

Emdadul Haque Bhuivan Vs. Bankruptcy Court & Ors 8 BLT (AD)-175.

 

2854

Board of Intermediate and Secondary Education (Non-Government Secondary School Teachers Service) Regulations, 1979

Citation: 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 145

Case Year: 1979

Subject: Board of Intermediate and Secondary Education

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Board of Intermediate and Secondary Education

(Non-Government Secondary

School Teachers Service) Regulations, 1979

A   teacher   under    suspension    is entitled to subsistence allowance—

High Court Division in consideration of the facts and circumstances held the respondent teacher entitled to the subsistence allowance during the period under suspension which the apex court upheld as one perfectly justified. Fatema Jinnah Multilateral High School represented by its Chairman, Llpazila Nirbahi Officer, Chandanaish Vs. Aradhana Chowdhury and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 145.

2855

Building Construction Act, 1952

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 288

Case Year: 1952

Subject: Building Construction

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Building Construction Act, 1952
