Section 3B— Construction of building without approved plan of the RAJUK is illegal-Town Improvement Act, 1953—Master plan   of  the   city   is   made keeping  in  view  regard  to  healthy environment—

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article   21—   Right   to   life   means meaningful life in healthy environment—

Construction of multi-storied building on the space kept earmarked for open car parking by the Dhaka City Corporation in violation of the master plan and without approval of the plan by the RAJUK is held by the apex court illegal and as such directed demolision of the said construction as being opposed to the spirit of article 21 of the constitution. Sharif Nuntl Ambia Vs. Dhaka City Corporation represented by the Mayor and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 288.

 

Building Construction Act, 1952— Section 3— Provides for granting sanction/approval of plan by the RAJUK for construction of building in the Metropolitan City subject to certain terms and conditions—

 

Section 3B— Prescribes the procedure of removal of unauthorized construction on the cancellation of sanction on the ground of breach of any of the terms and conditions specified therein—

 

Section 9— Empowers the authorised officer/committee of the RAJUK to cancel the sanction only on the ground of violation of any of the terms and conditions subject to which the sanction/approval of plan was accorded and or on the making of statements which are incorrect—

 

Section 15— Provides for appeal to specified authority against cancellation of sanction—

Cancellation of sanction by the authorised officer is a quasi-judicial function which has to be exercised judiciously and fairly strictly in accordance with law. As provided under section 9 of the Building Construction Act, 1952 the sanction can only be cancelled on the ground of violation of the terms and conditions subject to which the sanction was granted and or on the ground of making statements which are incorrect. In the instant case there is no allegation of violation of any terms and conditions and or making any incorrect statements. In that view of the matter the learned judges of the High Court Division held there was no valid ground for cancellation of sanction and for directing removal/demolition of the disputed Rangs Bhaban from above the 6th level. The learned judges further held RAJUK can cancel sanction only on the ground of breach of the terms and conditions thereof or making of incorrect statements in obtaining the sanction and on no other consideration. RAJUK must exercise its statutory powers independently and its decision must not be influenced by outside interference or dictation of any other authority whatsoever. The learned judges upon an elaborate discussion of all the aspects agitated held the cancellation of the sanction and the order directing removal/demolition of the building above the 6th floor illegal and arbitrary and declared the same to have been passed without any lawful authority and of no legal effect.

2856

Carriage of Goods by Sea Act, 1925

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 156

Case Year: 1925

Subject: Carriage of Goods by Sea Act

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Carriage of Goods by

Sea Act, 1925

Carrier is not liable for the loss or damage caused by act of God—

Tsunami of 26th December 2004 which caused unprecedented damage and colossal loss of life and property was certainly an act of God and as such the carrier vessels can not be liable for any such damage which are exempted under the force majeure clause. Therefore the learned judge of the Admiralty Court directed the immediate release of the M.V. vessels from arrest. HRC Shipping Limited Vs. M. V. X-press Manaslu and MV. X-press Resolve and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 156.

2857

Children Act, 1974

Citation: 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 205

Case Year: 1974

Subject: Children Act

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Children Act, 1974

Sections 51, 52 and 67— Provide for punishment of child offenders by detention in certified institute and release on attaining the age of 18 years—

Even in a case involving the offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life or imprisonment, a child offender can not be sentenced to imprisonment unless in the opinion of the trial judge the child is of unruly nature or of depraved character. Child offenders must not be associated with the adult offenders. A child offender can be detained in certified institute for not more than 10 years but he or she should be released on attaining the age of 18 years as per provisions of section 67. The learned judges of the High Court Division expressed extreme dissatisfaction as to the awareness and level of understanding of the police, probation officer and the judges who happen to come in contact with the child offenders about the law and their application. Fahima Nasrin Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 205.

2858

Chittagong Hill Tracts Regulations, 1900

Citation: 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 242

Case Year: 1900

Subject: Chittagong Hill Tracts Regulations

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Chittagong Hill Tracts Regulations, 1900

Section 7— Vests the Deputy Commissioner, Rangamati Hill District with all the civil, criminal and revenue powers—

The writ petitioner a financial institution instituted money suit for recovery of loan money of the Bank which the Deputy Commissioner dismissed. The Additional Divisional Commissioner also dismissed the appeal by a single sentence without discussing the materials on record and showing any ground. The learned judges of the High Court Division disapproved such type of cryptic non-speaking order passed without application of judicial mind and as such declared the impugned order as illegal and passed without any lawful authority and sent back the appeal for disposal afresh in accordance with law and write out a proper judgment. Bangladesh Krishi Bank Vs. Govt of Bangladesh 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 242.

2859

Chittagong Hill Tracts Regulations (Amendment) Act, 2003

Citation: 13 MLR (2010) (HC) 413

Case Year: 2003

Subject: Chittagong Hill Tracts Regulations (Amendment)

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Chittagong Hill Tracts Regulations

(Amendment) Act, 2003

Section 2 clause(b)- Provides for establishment of the court of District and Sessions Judge in the hill districts—

Chittagong Hill Tracts Regulation (Amendment) Act, 2003 Øviv cve©Z¨ †Rjv ev›`ieb, LvMovQwo Ges iv½vgvwU‡Z †Rjv `vqiv RR Av`vjZ Ges bvix I wkï wbh©vZb `gb AvBb, 2000 Gi aviv 26 Øviv †`‡ki cÖ‡Z¨K †Rjvq bvix I wkï wbh©vZb `gb UªvBe¨ybvj cÖwZôvi weavb _vwK‡jI miKvi `xN©Kvj hveZ cve©Z¨ †Rjvmg~‡n GB mKj Av`vjZ cÖwZôv Kwi‡Z e¨_© nBqv‡Q| d‡j †`‡ki Ab¨vb¨ GjvKvi bvMwiK‡`i b¨vq cve©Z¨ †Rjvi bvMwiKMb wePvi cÖvwßi mvsweavwbK AwaKvi nB‡Z ewÃZ nB‡Z‡Qb| gvbbxq wePvicwZ g‡nv`q ivq cÖ`v‡bi ZvwiL nB‡†Z D‡j­wLZ †Rjvmgy‡n mswk­ó AvB‡bi weavbymv‡I †RjvI `vqiv RR Ges bvix I wkï wbh©vZb `gb UªvBe¨ybvj ¯’vc‡bi Rb¨ miKvi‡K wb‡`©k cÖ`vb Kwiqv‡Qb|

2860

Cinematograph Act, 1918

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 110

Case Year: 1980

Subject: Cinematograph Act

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Cinematograph Act, 1918

Section 5— To grant no objection certificate for constructing Cinema House is the discretion of the authority which must be exercised reasonably having regard to the surrounding circumstances and strictly in accordance with the law. Bijoy Kumar Chakraborty Vs. Mohammad Mozaffar Hossain being dead his heirs Most. Hamida Begum and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 110.

 

2861

Civil Service Recruitment Rules, 1981

Citation: 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 196

Case Year: 1981

Subject: Civil Service Recruitment Rules

Delivery Date: 2018-03-11

Civil Service Recruitment Rules, 1981

Public Service Commission is not authorised to make any recommendation for appointment of person to the post of Professor and Assistant Professor in different discipline in the running process without fresh advertisement of those posts subsequently requisitioned. Dr. Mir. Jamaluddin and others Vs. Nawazesh Farid and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 196.

2862

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908

Citation: 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 35, 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 405, 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 197,11 MLR (2006) (AD) 179, 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 287, 11 MLR (2006) (HO 409, 14 MLR (2009) (EC) 476, 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 281, 11 MLR (2006) (HO) 1, 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 500, 11 MLR (2006) (HC)

Case Year: 1908

Subject: Code of Civil Procedure

Delivery Date: 2018-03-12

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908

Section 9— Every dispute of civil nature unless barred under any enactment shall be decided by the Civil Court of competent jurisdiction —

Companies Act, 1994 —Section 95 — Dispute relating to matters as contemplated under section 95 being of civil nature are to be decided by the civil court

Section 2(g) of the Companies Act, 1994 confers jurisdiction upon the civil court to decide disputes under section 95 and as such the Company Court of the High Court Division can not decide such dispute. Abdul Mohit and others Vs. Social Investment Bank Ltd. and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 35.

 

 

Section 9— Jurisdiction of civil court can be exercised notwithstanding the ouster clause where there is allegation of violation of the rules of procedure—

Section 115— New plea can not be raised at the stage of revision— Binding effect of finding of fact on the revisional court—

Employees of Water Development Board are entitled to gratuity and other pensionary benefits. The dispute relating thereto can be decided by the civil court and not by the Labour Court. Concurrent findings of fact arrived at by the trial court as well as the court of appeal unless the same suffer from any legal infirmity, are binding upon the revisional court. Chairman, Bangladesh Water Development Board Vs. Md. Abdur Rahman and another 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 405.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908—Section 11—Principle of res-judicata applies to subsequent suit on the same subject matter decided in a previous suit between the same parties—Order 9 rule 13— Exparte decree can be set aside under Order 9 rule 13 or in a subsequent suit on ground of non-service of summons and not otherwise—

It is well settled that an exparte decree may be set-aside in a subsequent.

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Section 11— Do not operate against— Partition Suit—

Subsequent suit for partition of suit land is maintainable where the plaintiff was not allotted any saham in the previous suit. Mere payment of rent by one co-sharer does not extinguish the title of other co-sharers in joint possession. Meheron Nessa alias Most Meheronessa Khanom Vs. AH Ahmed Khan and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 197.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908—

Section 20— Suit shall have to be filed in a court of competent jurisdiction— Order 7 rule 10— Return of plaint in suit filed in a wrong court—

Originally the suit was filed in the Artha Rin Adalat, Rangpur which was decreed exparte and the property of the plaintiff of the subsequent suit filed in the Court at Dhaka was sold in auction. The subsequent suit challenging the decree and auction sale should have been filed in the Court at Rangpur. In view of having the subsequent suit filed in Dhaka Court the plaint of the suit should have been returned to the filing advocate as per provision of rule 10 of Order 7 instead of rejecting the plaint under Order 7 rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure 1908. The apex court upheld the decision of the High Court Division directing return of the plaint. Habibur Rahman (Md.) Vs. M/s Uttara Bank Ltd. represented- by the Managing Director and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 179.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908—

Section 21 and 99— Suit when decided on merit, cannot fail on account of misdescription of the plaintiff—

The nature of relief shall be determined in reference to the averments made in the plaint and not on the basis of allegations of the written statement. When does not affect the merit the suit does not fail on account of mis-description of the plaintiff. Divisional Forest Officer, Dhaka Vs. Md. Shahabuddin and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 287.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Section    24— Transfer of suit from one district to another on sufficient ground—

Court's power to transfer a suit from one district to another is discretionary which has to be exercised judiciously. The grounds which are considered sufficient have by now been clearly , specified by series of pronouncements of the superior courts. That the opposite party is influential is not a sufficient ground for transfer of a suit from one district to another. The party seeking the transfer must prove the grounds to the satisfaction of the Court. Jamal Hossain (Md.) Vs. Md. Mazid 11 MLR (2006) (HO 409.

 

Section 24— Power to withdraw a suit or case and transfer it from one court to another is discretionary power of the court—

The allegation on the basis of which the transfer is sought must be proved by the party concerned to the satisfaction of the court. Power to transfer of a suit or a case from one court to another of competent jurisdiction either by the High Court Division or the District judge as the case may be, within their respective jurisdiction being discretionary shall be exercised judiciously. Shafiqul Alam (M) and others Vs. Qazi Rafiq Ahmed and others 14 MLR (2009) (EC) 476.

 

Section 56— Applies against arrest and   detention   of   woman   in   civil prison—

Since the application of section 56 of the Code of Civil Procedure has not been excluded by section 6(ka) of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain,.1990, the prohibition againt arrest and detention of woman in civil prison in execution of decree of Artha Rin Adalat shall apply. Hazera Begum Vs. Artha Rin Adalat and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 281.

 

Section  75 and  Order 26  rule  9— Provides for local investigation—

Court is empowered under section 75 and Order 26, rule 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 to issue commission for local investigation in a proper case where certain issue can not be resolved by oral evidence. In the instant case where the plaintiff claimed to have acquired the suit land on the basis of registered kabala deeds of the time before the C.S. operation and the identity of the suit land is disputed, the trial court in all fairness of the things ought to have allowed the prayer of the plaintiff to issue commission to relay the suit land with that of the disputed kabalas. The learned Judges of the High Court Division having found the impugned order passed erroneously under misconception of law and without application of his judicial mind set aside the same and directed to issue commission in accordance with law. Gopesh Chandra Ghosh, Vs. Sree Sree Radha Krishna Jew and others 11 MLR (2006) (HO) 1.

 

Specific Relief Act. The onus lies heavily upon the subsequent transferee to prove that he on good faith purchased the suit land and paid the consideration money and he had no knowledge of the original agreement. Joynab Begum and others Vs. Shaheb AH Akunji and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 337.

 

Section 115— Concurrent findings of fact arrived at by the trial court as well as the appellate court are binding upon the revisional court—

In the instant case the trial court decreed the suit and the appellate court below upheld the decision of the trial court on concurrent findings. The High Court Division also affirmed the decision of the courts below. The Appellate Division held that the concurrent findings of the trial court as well as the appellate court are binding upon the revisional court unless there is a case of misreading or non-consideration of material evidence on record. Mohar All Bhuiyan Vs. Michir All Bhuiyan and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 500.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Section 115— Scope of interference with the findings and decision of lower appellate court— Setting aside exparte decree on ground of non-service of summons— Onus lies upon the plaintiff who obtained the exparte decree to prove the service of summons—

Suit for declaration of title to joint property in ejmali possession without seeking partition is not maintainable—

The trial court setaside the exparte decree with the finding that the summons upon the defendant-plaintiffs were not served. The onus to prove that the summons upon the defendants were duly served lies upon the plaintiff. When this onus was not discharged and it was evident from the record that there was no service of summons the High Court Division held the lower appellate court was wrong in setting aside the judgment of the trial court in respect of setting aside the exparte decree and accordingly setaside the same. The part of the judgment of the lower appellate court dismissing the suit for declaration of title to the joint property in ejmali possession as being one not maintainable without seeking partition is up held by the High Court Division. Amiruddin Mondal (Md.) and others Vs. Md. AshrafAli and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 49.

 

Section 115—Concurrent findings of fact of the trial court as well as the appellate court can not be interfered with by the revisional court unless there is a case of non-reading or non-consideration of material evidence on record or an error of law in the decision-making—

The consistent views of our apex court is that the concurrent findings of facts of the court of appeal as well as of the trial court can not be interfered with unless the said findings suffer from any illegality arising out of non-consideration or misreading of any material evidence on record or an error of law in making the decision. In a partition suit where the defendants did not lead any evidence or could not substantiate by any specific evidence during trial the objection as to non-joinder of parties and properties, subsequently the defendants cannot agitate the defect of the suit for non­joinder of parties or properties. Muslem Fakir and others Vs. Md. Moniruddin Khondaker and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 92.

 

Section 115— Scope of interference with findings of fact of the appellate court is limited—

Evidence Act, 1872—

Section 103— Burden of proof lies upon the person who asserts the existence of certain thing—

Section 67 and 68— Documents when not proved in accordance with law cannot be admitted into evidence—

Transfer of Property Act, 1882—

Section 48— Transfer earlier in point of time takes precedence over the subsequent one—

Findings of facts of the appellate court when do not suffer from any legal infirmity do not call for interference by the revisional court. Except copies of the judicial records all other documents in order to be admissible in evidence, shall have to be proved in the manner as provided under the law. When the original Kabala deeds are not produced and are not proved in accordance with law the copy thereof can not be admitted into evidence. Rent receipts, mutation khatian and record of rights may be evidence of possession but they do not create any title. As provided under section 48 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882 the transfer earlier in point of time shall prevail over the subsequent one. Tajul Islam and others Vs. Chini Miah and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 1.

 

Section 115— Findings of fact arrived at by the appellate court on proper appreciation of evidence on record are binding upon the High Court Division—

Unless there is perversity in the findings due on non-consideration or misreading of material evidence occasioning failure of justice the findings of fact arrived at by the court of appeal on proper appreciation of evidence, cannot be interfered with by the High Court Division in exercise of its revisional jurisdiction. Salina Begum Vs. Mojibar Rahman and others 13 MLR (2008) (HO) 58.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Section 115— Scope of interference with findings of fact of lower appellate court—

Suit for a mere declaratory decree is not maintainable without seeking consequential relief for recovery of possession when the plaintiff is out of possession of the suit land as required under section 42 of the Specific Relief Act, 1877. Appellate Court is required to advert to the findings of fact of the trial court with reference to the evidence on record while reversing those findings. The revisional court in exercise of jurisdiction under section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure can not interfere with the findings of fact of the appellate court unless they suffer from non-consideration or misreading of evidence on record or perversity. Abdul Jabbar Bhuiyan and others Vs. Kulsum Banu Bibi and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 212.

 

Section 115— Findings of facts of the appellate 'court based on materials on record are binding on revisional court—

That the defendants denied the title and possession of the plaintiff in some part of the suit land does not render the partition suit to be converted into a suit for declaration of title and recovery of possession. While reversing the judgment and decree of the trial court, the appellate court is required to discuss the evidence on record and advert to the findings of the trial court. But in case of affirming the same it is not required to make the detail discussion of evidence. Abdul Latif (Md.) being dead his heirs Mosammat Zahura Bewa and others Vs. Mohammad AH and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 131.

 

Section 115— Findings of fact arrived at by the appellate court on proper appreciation of evidence on record can not be interfered with in revisional jurisdiction—

In the instant case the learned judge of the High Court Division found the impugned judgment and decree of the appellate court based on proper appreciation of the evidence on record and as such finding no illegality or perversity therein, discharged the rule. Abdul Mannan Mathbar Vs. Nazmul Hocjiie Mazumder and others 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 317.

 

Section 115— Findings of fact arrived at by the court of appeal on proper appreciation of evidence on record cannot be interfered with by the revisional court—

In the instant case the plaintiff of suit No. 64 of 1995 obtained a decree in a previously instituted suit bearing No. 226 of 1982 declaring his title to the suit land whereupon the vested property case started there against was dropped and the suit land was released in favour of the plaintiff Mostafa Ahmed. The said contested decree still subsists. The court of appeal after discussing the evidence on record decreed the title suit No. 64 of 1995. The revisional court found on reviewing the evidence on record that the appellate court was perfectly justified in decreeing the title suit No. 64 of 1995 infavour of the plaintiff. Mostafa Shahrwr Vs. Mostafa Ahmed and others 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 362.

 

Section 115— Interference with the findings of fact arrived at by the appellate court in exercise of revisional jurisdiction—

Title under the defective title deeds is perfected by long possession. Law is well settled that the court of appeal is the last court of fact. Findings of fact arrived at by the appellate court on proper appreciation of evidence on record are binding on the revisional court unless the same suffers from legal infirmity arising out of misapplication of law and non consideration of material evidence on record. In the instant case the learned judge of the High Court Division found the lower appellate court reversed the findings of the trial court without proper appreciation of material evidence on record.- Accordingly the learned judge of the High Court Division set aside the impugned judgment and order and restored those of the trial court. Syeda Bibi and others, Vs. Helaluddin & Monsur All and others 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 400.

 

Section 115— Finding of fact arrived at by the appellate court is binding upon the revisional court unless the same is perverse—

Evidence Act, 1872—

Section 73— Power of the court to compare the handwritting under dispute—

In the instant case the trial court dismissed the suit for specific performance of contract on the ground the disputed signature was not examined by handwritting expert. In appeal the appellate court himself compared the disputed signature with the specimen signature and decreed the suit. The learned judges of the High Court Division found nothing wrong with the impugned judgment and decree and as such dismissed the revision. Abu Tara (Most.) Vs. Md. Abdur Rahim Khan and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 449.

 

Section 115(1)— Concurrent findings of fact of the lower appellate court is binding upon the revisional court—

Lessee of the Government has no locus standi to challenge the judgment passed againt the Government against which no appeal was preferred. Concurrent finding of fact of the lower appellate court as well as the trial court which are bassed on correct appreciation of evidence on record are binding upon the revisional court. Abdul Sattar Vs. Gazi Golam Mohammad and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 326.

 

Section 115(2)— Power and jurisdiction of the District Judge in entertaining revisional application is confined to the limit of pecuniary jurisdiction relating to appeal—

A Full Bench of the High Court Division decided that the District Judge's power to entertain revisional application shall be confined to the limit of his pecuniary jurisdiction relating to appeal. Statement of valuation of the subject-matter wherefrom the revision arises shall be given in the revisional application for the purpose of jurisdiction. Revisional application arising out of the suit or proceedings in respect of property having valuation upto five lacs taka shall lie to the District Judge. All other revision having valuation exceeding taka five lacs shall lie to the High Court Division. Apex court affirmed the decision of the Full Bench. Government of Bangladesh, represented by the Deputy Commissioner, Chittagong Vs. A.H.M Khurshed All and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 57.

 

Section   148—  Has   no   manner  of application in respect of cases under section 96(4) of the SAT Act, 1950—

Section 96(4) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 provides for special limitation for a person to become co-applicant for proportionate pre­emption within 2 (two) months of the service of notice to make application and deposit the proportionate consideration together with compensation within the period as may be directed by the court. Section 148 of the Code of Civil Procedure as to extension of time has no manner of application in such case. Chan Miah (Md.) Vs. Md. Dabind Mm @ Maku Miah and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 26.

 

Section  148—  Has  no  manner of application in respect of cases under section 96(4) of the SAT Act, 1950—

Section 96(4) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 provides for special limitation for a person to become co-applicant for proportionate pre­emption within 2 (two) months of the service of notice to make application and deposit the proportionate consideration together with compensation within the period as may be directed by the court. Section 148 of the Code of Civil Procedure as to extension of time has no manner of application in such case. Chan Miah (Md.) Vs. Md. Dabind Mm @ Maku Miah and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 26.

 

 Section 148— Extension of time to deposit fee within specified time passed by conditional order with a default clause— not permissible—

When the High Court Division directed the commissioner's fee to be paid within certain date with a default clause, the trial court cannot extend such time beyond the limit so fixed. On the expiry of the specified time in case of default the consequence automatically takes effect and no further order is required to be passed. Government of Bangladesh represented by the Deputy Commissioner, Patuakhali Vs. Md. Nurul Haque and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 257.

 

Section 148 and 149— Power of the Adalat to enlarge the time for putting in deficit court fee—

Order 7 rule ll(c) Rejection of plaint for non-payment of deficit court fee within specified time—

To put in deficit court fee within 21 days is not the mandatory requirement  of law and as such the Adalat can enlarge the time under section 148 and 149 of the Code of Civil Procedure. When the deficit court fee is subsequently paid and the Adalat accepted the same there is no ground for rejection of the plaint. Apparels Limited and another Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 149.

 

Section 151— Temporary injunction in mandatory nature can be granted in appropriate case— Partition suit— Possession of a co-sharer in specific portion of land can be maintained in a partition suit—

It is well settled that a co-sharer in possession of specific portion of suit land in a partition suit can maintain his possession. In the instant suit the trial court passed an order of status-quo against the defendant not to change the nature of the suit land who by violating the order of status-quo made construction. The trial court upon prayer of the plaintiff and upon consideration of the reports of Advocate Commissioners passed order of temporary injunction in mandatory nature directing the defendant to demolish the construction and restore the suit land to its original position. The High Court Division and the Appellate Division upheld the impugned order as one deemed to have been passed under section 151 C.P.C. Azizur Rahman Chowdhitn/ (Md.) Vs. Touhiduddin Chowdhury and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 160.

 

Section 151— Dismissal of the miscellaneous case on the basis of forged solenama can well be set-aside on an application under section 151 C.P.C—

The miscellaneous case was dismissed on the basis of a forged solenama. The respondent filed application under section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure, alleging forgery of the solenama and sought to setaside the dismissal and restoration of the miscellaneous case. The learned Assistant Judge compared the signature and primafacie having found the alleged solenama as forged restored the miscellaneous case and referred the forged solenama to the competent Magistrate for trial according to law. The High Court Division as well as the Appellate Division found the impugned order perfectly justified. Haleha Begum and others Vs. Nisaruddin anl others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 342.

 

Section    151—   Where    alternative remedy in law is available resort to section 151 is not permissible— Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990— Section  6(2)— Provides  for  setting aide exparte decree— Since  specific  provisions  are there under section 6(2)  of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 for setting aside ex­parte decree, inherent jurisdiction of the court under section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure can not be invoked for setting aide the same. Golden Re-Rolling Industries Ltd. Vs. Subordinate Judge, Artha Rin Adalat No. 1 Dhaka and another 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 234.

 

Section 151— Court can rectify its i   wrong order in exercise of its inherent power—

Law is well settled that a party to a proceedings can not suffer due to ex-fade wrong order of the court. The court can well rectify its wrong order in exercise of its inherent power and restore the possession of the suit property in favour of the plaintiff dispossessed during pendency of the suit pursuant to a wrongorder with the help of police force. The learned judges of the High Court Division held the restoration of possession by the trial court by issueing temporary mandatory injunction as perfectly justified since the same secured the ends of justice. Fulbaria Adarshaya Market Dokandar Malik Samity and another Vs. Fulbaria Adarsha Market Khatigrastha Dokandar Kallayan Samabaya Samiyt Ltd. and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 106.

 

Section 151— Power under this section can not be invoked where there is alternative remedy available under specific provision of law— Artha Rin Adalat Ain— Is a special statute—

Artha Rin Adalat Ain specifically provides for appeal against judgment, decree and order passed thereunder and as such power under section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 cannot be invoked by the Artha Rin Adalat for review, modification or setting aide its own judgment, decree or order. Halima Akter Vs. Sub-judge, Artha Rin Adalat, Bogra and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 78.

 

Order    1    rule    8—    Suit    in    the representative capacity— Specific Relief Act, 1877— Section 42— In a suit for declaratory decree plaintiff  to   prove   his   legal character— The plaintiff in this suit challenged union parishad office. The decision to shift the union parishad office is the business of the Government which is a policy decision. The plaintiff has nothing to do with such decision and as such he has no legal character and locus standi. In that view of the matter the suit in the representative capacity is held not maintainable. Since the plaintiff has no legal character and locus standi, the suit is also not maintainable. The apex court held the High Court Division was pefectly justified in passing the impugned judgment and order. Abdul Motaleb Sarker (Md.) and others Vs. Md. Laskar AH and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 230.

 

Order 1 Rule 10— Sub-lesee is not a necessary party to the suit for eviction of a monthly tenant—

An unauthorised occupant of the premises under the monthly tenant having no locus-standi is not a necessary party and as such need not be impleaded in a suit for eviction of a monthly tenant. Abdur Rahim (Md.) Vs. Bengal Bricks Industries Ltd. and another 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 81.

 

Order 1 rule 10— Person who is not lessee under the Government though in possession is not a necessary party—

Law is well settled that for complete and effectual adjudication of dispute persons having interest in the subject-matter shall be impleaded as party to the proceedings. But a person though in [ possession who is merely a trespasser has no locus standi and as such is held by the apex court not a necessary party and need not be added as party to the proceedings as provided under Order 1 rule 10 C.P.C. Matinr Rahman Vs. Habibur Rahman and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 417.

 

 Order    1    rule    10—    Impleading , necessary parties—

In a suit particularly for partition all the persons having interest in the suit property must be impleaded in order to adjudicate the dispute effectively and to avoid multiplicity of suits. The learned judges of the High Court Division in [ exercise of revisional power directed for I impleading the left out persons. Abdul Awal and others Vs. Rata-n Bibi and  others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 41.

 

 decision of the Government to shift the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Order 1, rule 10(2)— Addition of parties at the stage of revision—

A lessee of permanent lease who paid the entire lease money and obtained possession and duly registered lease dead having right, title and possession in the leasehold property is a necessary party to the proceedings. Although the petitioner was not made party in the miscellaneous case and the appeal arising therefrom, he can well be impleaded to the proceedings at the revisional stage. Tabibullah being dead his heirs Fatema Begum and others Vs. Government of Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Works and Urban Development and others 13 MLR (2008) (HO 393.

 

 Order 1 rule 10(2)— To struck off names   of   defendant   in   Admiralty suit—

The defendants 1 and 2 of the Admiralty suit prayed for striking off their names from the plaint on the ground that they are not necessary parties though they issued letter of Guarantee meaning thereby to "pay to be paid." The learned judge of the Admiralty court held that the liability of the guarantor is coextensive with that of the principal debtor and as such the defendants 1 and 2 are necessary parties for the purpose of effectual adjudication of the dispute and accordingly rejected the petitions. United Edible Oil Limited Vs. London Steam Ship Owners Mutual Insurance Association Ltd and others 14 MLR (2009) (HO 349.

 

 Order 1 rule 10(2)— Addition of a stranger as party to a suit for specific performance of contract—

For the purpose of complete and effective adjudication of a dispute and avoid multiplicity of suit, a stranger to the contract who was constituted attorney in respect of the suit land is a necessary party to the suit for specific performance of contract and as such he should be made defendant in the suit. The learned judges of the High Court Division having found the impugned order illegal set aside the same and allowed the constituted attorney to be added as defendant in the suit. Jahura Begum (Most.) alias Most Johara Begum Vs. Alhaj Abdur Rob Bhuiyan and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 409.

 

Order 1  rule  12(2)— Deposing on behalf of several plaintiffs when there is community of interest—

In a suit in which there are several plaintiffs who have common interest and where all of them signed the plaint Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Order 1, rule 10(2)— Addition of parties at the stage of revision— A lessee of permanent lease who paid the entire lease money and obtained possession and duly registered lease dead having right, title and possession in the leasehold property is a necessary party to the proceedings. Although the petitioner was not made party in the miscellaneous case and the appeal arising therefrom, he can well be impleaded to the proceedings at the revisional stage. Tabibullah being dead his heirs Fatema Begum and others Vs. Government of Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Works and Urban Development and others 13 MLR (2008) (HO 393.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Order 1 rule 10(2)— To struck off names   of   defendant   in   Admiralty suit—

The defendants 1 and 2 of the Admiralty suit prayed for striking off their names from the plaint on the ground that they are not necessary parties though they issued letter of Guarantee meaning thereby to "pay to be paid." The learned judge of the Admiralty court held that the liability of the guarantor is coextensive with that of the principal debtor and as such the defendants 1 and 2 are necessary parties for the purpose of effectual adjudication of the dispute and accordingly rejected the petitions. United Edible Oil Limited Vs. London Steam Ship Owners Mutual Insurance Association Ltd and others 14 MLR (2009) (HO 349.

 

 Order 1 rule 10(2)— Addition of a stranger as party to a suit for specific performance of contract—

For the purpose of complete and effective adjudication of a dispute and avoid multiplicity of suit, a stranger to the contract who was constituted attorney in respect of the suit land is a necessary party to the suit for specific performance of contract and as such he should be made defendant in the suit. The learned judges of the High Court Division having found the impugned order illegal set aside the same and allowed the constituted attorney to be added as defendant in the suit. Jahura Begum (Most.) alias Most Johara Begum Vs. Alhaj Abdur Rob Bhuiyan and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 409.

 

 Order 1  rule  12(2)— Deposing on behalf of several plaintiffs when there is community of interest—

In a suit in which there are several plaintiffs who have common interest and where all of them signed the plaint never tendered to him or there was no reason for him to refuse to accept the same. Abdur Rob Mollah Vs. Sahabuddin Ahmed and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 319.

 

Order 5 rule 12— Summons upon defendants shall be served personally. Service upon agent not duly authorised in writing is not valid—

Suppression of summons amounts to fraud which vitiates the proceedings—

Non-examination of mokabila witness renders the service unacceptable—

Findings of fact arrived at by the court of appeal which is the last court of fact shall be binding upon the revisional court. Momin Miah and others Vs. Md. Shafiullah Patwari and others 12 MLR (2007) (HO 289.

 

 Order 6 rule 4— Allegations of fraud and forgery to be specifically mentioned in the pleadings—

Though the party making the allegations of fraud or forgery of certain documents is required under Order 6 rule 4 of the Code of Civil Procedure, to specifically mention the particulars thereof in his pleading, the court is not precluded from scrutinising such document to ascertain the genuineness or otherwise of the same even if the particulars of forgery are not stated in the pleadings. Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh, represented by the Deputy Commissioner, Rajshahi and others Vs. Md. Abdul Jabbar Sheikh 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 119.

 

Order 6 rule 17— Provides for amendment of pleadings to rectify error, mistake or omission for effective adjudication of dispute and to avoid multiplicity of suits—

The purpose of rule 17 of Order 6 of the Code of Civil Procedure is to advance the cause of justice rather than to stifle it by allowing liberally amendment of pleadings for effective adjudication of disputes between the parties and to avoid multiplicity of suits. When the amendment sought for does not change the character of the suit the court should allow the same. The order refusing the amendment should contain reasons and must be speaking one in order to be sustainable in law. Afsaruddin Mina (Hazi) and others Vs. Alhaj Sk Sultan All being dead his heirs Selina Begum @ Rani and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 41.

 

Order 6 rule 17— Amendment of plaint when it does not change the nature and character of the suit, should be allowed for the purpose of effective adjudication of the dispute between the parties—

In a suit for declaration of title and recovery of possession of part of the suit land, the apex court held the amendment sought for incorporating the alternative prayer for partition as perfectly justified since the same does not change the nature and character of the suit, rather it would be necessary for effective adjudication of the dispute between the parties. The courts below misunderstood the suit as one under section 9 of the Specific Relief Act, 1877. Shafiqul Islam Chowdhury (Md.) and others Vs. Mustafizur Rahman and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 147.

 

Order 6 rule 17—Amendment of pleadings—Amendment of plaint may be allowed at any stage of the proceedings—

Law on amendment of plaint is well settled that amendment of plaint may be allowed at any stage of the proceeding including the stage of appeal for the purpose of effectively adjudicating the controversy between the parties provided the same does not change the nature and character of the suit and does not introduce new cause of action. Abdul Aziz Sheikh Vs. Kachuran Bibi and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 241.

 

Order—6 rule  17— Amendment of pleadings—

Amendment   of   pleadings   can   be : allowed at any stage of the proceedings  I provided the same does not change the nature and character of the suit and is I necessary for the purpose of determining the    real    question    of controversy between the parties. Ershad All and others Vs. Md. Ruhul Amin and others 11 MLR (2006) (PIC) 325.

 

 Order VI rule 17— Amendment of plaint at the appellate stage—

Amendment of plaint can be made at the appellate stage provided the same is not barred by limitation.     The amendment of the plaint in the instant case has been rejected on the ground of limitation and vagueness. Abdul Wadud and others  Vs.  Abdul Wahed   and   others    14   MLR   (2009) (AD) 107.

 

 Order 7 rule 3— Plaintiff is required to clearly describe the suit land—

In order to succeed in a suit the plaintiff must describe the suit land specifically. No relief can be granted inrespect of any unspecified and vague land. Ershad AH Hoivlader being dead his heirs Naznil Islam (Babul) and others Vs. Santi Rani Dhupi and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 105.

 

Order 7 rule 3— Suit land must be specific and ascertained—

It is required as provided under Order 7 rule 3 of the Code of Civil Procedure that the suit land must be specific and ascertained and should not be vague and indefinite. The objection as to the identity of the suit land must be raised at the earliest opportunity. When no objection was taken by the defendant during trial, such objection cannot be raised for the first time in revision. Abdul Khaleque and others Vs. Akhteruzzaman Mia and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 193.

 

 Order 7 rule 10— Rejection of plaint is not permissible when it is properly constituted and filed in the court of competent jurisdiction—

Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 is a special law which shall prevail over all other laws—

The Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 has clearly defined the term (^H) loan which includes interests of all kinds by whatever name they are called. Accordingly the learned judges of the High Court Division found nothing wrong with the impugned order and discharged the rule. Shrimp and Fish Processing Plant Ltd, represented by its Managing Director Vs. National Bank Ltd and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 55.

 

 Order 7 rule 11— Rejection of plaint in suit barred by law—

It is well settled that no separate suit shall lie against exparte decree passed by Artha Rin Adalat as provided under section 6 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990. The remedy against exparte decree is available under Order 9 Rule 13 of the Code of Civil Procedure upon deposit of 50% decretal dues. The rejection of plaint in the suit is held perfectly justified. M. Tariqullah Sikder Vs. Sonali Bank 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 73.

 

 Order 7 rule 11— Rejection of plaint on ground of maintainability of the suit is not permissible before filing of written statement—

Specific Relief Act, 1877—

Section 42 and 56F— Preliminary issue as to maintainability of suit can not be decided before filing of written statement—

Whether a suit is maintainable or not under section 42 read with section 56F of the Specific Relief Act, 1877 is a matter which can be decided upon consideration of the materials contained in the pleadings and as such neither the plaint of a suit can be rejected under Order 7 rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 nor the preliminary issue thereon can be decided before filing of written statement and some evidence are led in support thereof. The apex court directed the trial court in the facts and circumstances to decide all the issues after filing of the written statement and evidence taken. Ismat Zerin Khan Vs. The World Bank and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 58.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 — Order 7 rule 11— Rejection of plaint of a suit when barred by limitation —

The Plaintiff for the self same matter in a suit fought upto the Appellate Division and was unsuccessful. In a subsequent suit on the same matter the plaint was rejected as being barred by the principle of res-judicata. The apex court held the rejection of plaint perfectly justified. Serajud-Dowla (Alhaj Mohammad) and others Vs. The Secretary, Ministry of Works 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 169.

 

Order 7 rule 11— Rejection of plaint when the suit is barred by law—

Plaint of a suit is liable to be rejected when the suit is barred by law—

Public Demands Recovery Act, 1913— Section 37—Ousts the jurisdiction of civil court when the auction sale is challenged in suit by a stranger to the certificate proceedings.—

Section 37 of the Public Demands Recovery Act 1913 provides in clear terms that auction sale in a certificate proceedings can only be challenged either by the certificate holder or certificate debtor or by their representatives which shall be decided by the certificate officer. No stranger can challenge such auction sale except on ground of fraud. In the instant case the Revenue authority set aside the auction sale after 12 years on an application of a stranger which was challenged in the suit. The apex court setaside the impugned order of the High Court Division rejecting the plaint as being illegal and held the suit was quite maintainable that in view of the legal position the civil court was perfectly competent to see how far the Revenue authority was justified in setting aside the auction sale. Marfat Alt Miah (Md) being dead his legal heir Few] Ahammed Bhulu Vs. Sree jagadish Chandra Sheel and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 313.

 

 Order 7 rule 11— Rejection of plaint and the grounds therefor—

Plaint can not be rejected on the ground of maintainability of the suit or vagueness of the subject matter or non-production of documents as required under Order 7 rule 14 of the Code. Again plaint also cannot be rejected on the question of lack of personal interest of the plaintiff in the subject matter of the suit. Mohammad All Vs. It. Col. (Reid.) Habibullah Bahar and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 405.

 

Order 8 rule 1— Provision for filing written statement within 2(two) months are directory and not mandatory—

Since no consequence is provided for the non-compliance within the specified period, the provisions of Order 8 rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure to file written statement within 2(two) months is held by the apex court directory and not mandatory. The court has the discretion in appropriate case to grant extension of time to file written statement beyond the period of two months. Khan Md. Firoj Kabir Vs. Rupali Bank Ltd. and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 186.

 

Order 8 rule 6 and Order 20 rule 19— Set-off and counter claim arising out of same transaction and when such claim can be treated as plaint in cross suit—

When the claim raised by the defendant as set-off does not exceed the claim of the plaintiff and when such counter claim filed along with the written statement exceeds the claim of the plaintiff and requisite court fees are paid thereon, this can well be treated as plaint in a cross suit particularly when the plaintiff withdraws his suit. Loyal Shipping Ltd. Vs. Castrol U.K. Ltd and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 291.

 

Order   9   rule   9—  Applicable  to restoration of pre-emption  case dismissed for default— State  Acquisition  and  Tenancy Act, 1950—

Section 96(13)— Does not bar the applicability of Order 9 rule 9 C.P.C in respect of restoration of pre-emption case dismissed for default—

The Appellate Division held in series of cases that Order 9 rule 13 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 is applicable to an application for setting aside exparte order passed in  pre-emption case. Keeping in line with the same view the apex court also held that Order 9 rule 9 C.P.C is equally applicable to the restoration of pre-emption case dismissed for default and section 96(13) of the SAT Act shall not be a bar. Shafiqur Rahman (Mvi. Md.) and another Vs. Ambia Khatoon and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 19.

 

Order 9 rule 9— Provides for setting aside dismissal of suit—

Section 151— Not applicable where there is specific provisions for alternative remedy—

Law is well settled that section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure is not applicable in the case for setting aside dismissal of suit for default of the plaintiff as there is specific provision under Order 9 Rule 9 of the Code. The inherent power of the court under section 151 C.P.C can not be invoked where there is specific provision of law for alternative remedy. Ohiruddin Pramanik and others Vs. Bhadi Bibi being dead her heir Md. Khabiruddin Pramanik 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 14.

 

Order 9 rule 9— Precludes the plaintiff from instituting fresh suit on the same cause of action after dismissal of the previous suit—

Remedy against dismissal of suit passed under Order 9 rule 8 C.P.C lies in an application under Order 9 rule 9. Fresh or subsequent suit on the same cause of action being barred by law is not maintainable and as such the learned judge of the High Court Division dismissed the suit. Kamaluddin Vs. Md. A. Aziz Mondal and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 321.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Order 9, rule 9(1)— Partition suit subsequently instituted after the dismissal of the former one in default is maintainable—

Order 7 rule 11— Plaint of subsequent partition suit can not be rejected on ground of resjudicata—

Fresh partition suit can be instituted after the previous one was dismissed for default in view of the legal position that the possession of one co-sharer is, the j possession of another co-sharer in the suit property and the cause of action is recurring one. Civil Revision No. 2171 0/2005 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 170.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Order  9  rule  13—  Application for setting aside exparte decree must be filed within 30 days—

Where in a suit decreed exparte the petitioner-defendant was contesting by filing written statement, the application for setting aside the exparte decree ought to have been filed within 30 days and in the case of the expiry date falling during civil court vacation, on the reopening date. Mazu Bibi and others Vs. Mossammat Rabeya Begum and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 34.

 

Order 9 rule 13— Exparte decree may be setaside on ground of non-service of summons— Summons served by hanging on outer fencing of the dwelling huts of the defendant is good service— Laches of Advocate to be proved by evidence—

Order 41— Power of appellate court to reassess evidence on record—

It is well settled that while reversing the judgment and decree the appellate court must advert to the findings of the trial court and in doing so the appellate court shall have all the powers of the trial court to reassess the evidence on record. Service of summons by hanging on the outerfencing of the dwelling hut of the defendant when established is held by the apex court a good service. Laches of advocate when taken as a ground of non-appearance must be established by evidence. Sudhir Kumar Das and another Vs. Abdul Malek Mia and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 57.

 

Order 9 rule   13—   Setting   aside exparte  decree on ground   of  non-service of summons and fraud—

In the instant case the petitioner was residing in the house of her husband when the summons of the suit was served upon her by hanging in the house of her father and an unsigned vokalatnama purported to have been signed by her was fraudulently submitted in the court. The learned judge of the High Court Division held there was no service of summons upon the petitioner and set aside the exparte decree to the extent of her interest in the suit property. Shilu Begum (Most) Vs. Md. Roshan Akter Rahman 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 48.

 

Keeping in line with the same view the apex court also held that Order 9 rule 9 C.P.C is equally applicable to the restoration of pre-emption case dismissed for default and section 96(13) of the SAT Act shall not be a bar. Shafiqur Rahman (Mvi. Md.) and another Vs. Ambia Khatoon and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 19.

 

Order 9 rule 9— Provides for setting aside dismissal of suit—

Section 151— Not applicable where there is specific provisions for alternative remedy—

Law is well settled that section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure is not applicable in the case for setting aside dismissal of suit for default of the plaintiff as there is specific provision under Order 9 Rule 9 of the Code. The inherent power of the court under section 151 C.P.C can not be invoked where there is specific provision of law for alternative remedy. Ohiruddin Pramanik and others Vs. Bhadi Bibi being dead her heir Md. Khabiruddin Pramanik 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 14.

 

Order 9 rule 9— Precludes the plaintiff from instituting fresh suit on the same cause of action after dismissal of the previous suit—

Remedy against dismissal of suit passed under Order 9 rule 8 C.P.C lies in an application under Order 9 rule 9. Fresh or subsequent suit on the same cause of action being barred by law is not maintainable and as such the learned judge of the High Court Division dismissed the suit. Kamaluddin Vs. Md. A. Aziz Mondal and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 321.

 

Order 9, rule 9(1)— Partition suit subsequently instituted after the dismissal of the former one in default is maintainable—

Order 7 rule 11— Plaint of subsequent partition suit can not be rejected on ground of resjudicata—

Fresh partition suit can be instituted after the previous one was dismissed for default in view of the legal position that the possession of one co-sharer is, the j possession of another co-sharer in the suit property and the cause of action is recurring one. Civil Revision No. 2171 0/2005 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 170.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Order  9  rule  13—  Application for setting aside exparte decree must be filed within 30 days—

Where in a suit decreed exparte the petitioner-defendant was contesting by filing written statement, the application for setting aside the exparte decree ought to have been filed within 30 days and in the case of the expiry date falling during civil court vacation, on the reopening date. Mazu Bibi and others Vs. Mossammat Rabeya Begum and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 34.

 

Order 9 rule 13— Exparte decree may be setaside on ground of non-service of summons— Summons served by hanging on outer fencing of the dwelling huts of the defendant is good service— Laches of Advocate to be proved by evidence—

Order 41— Power of appellate court to reassess evidence on record—

It is well settled that while reversing the judgment and decree the appellate court must advert to the findings of the trial court and in doing so the appellate court shall have all the powers of the trial court to reassess the evidence on record. Service of summons by hanging on the outerfencing of the dwelling hut of the defendant when established is held by the apex court a good service. Laches of advocate when taken as a ground of non-appearance must be established by evidence. Sudhir Kumar Das and another Vs. Abdul Malek Mia and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 57.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Order   9   rule   13—   Setting   aside exparte   decree   on  ground   of  non-service of summons and fraud—

In the instant case the petitioner was residing in the house of her husband when the summons of the suit was served upon her by hanging in the house of her father and an unsigned vokalatnama purported to have been signed by her was fraudulently submitted in the court. The learned judge of the High Court Division held there was no service of summons upon the petitioner and set aside the exparte decree to the extent of her interest in the suit property. Shilu Begum (Most) Vs. Md. Roshan Akter Rahman 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 48.

 

Order XX Rule 18— Partition of e/mali property by mets and bounds and allotment of Saham— Exclusive possession of cosharers need to be maintained—

Where the trial court in the preliminary decree has given certain direction for making partition of the joint property among the cosharers and allowed saham for their shares, the Advocate Commissioner can not go beyond the direction of the preliminary decree. Where the Advocate commissioner allotted saham by violating the term and direction of the preliminary decree and disturbed the possession of the respective cosharers, the learned judge of the High Court Division setaside the final decree and remanded the suit with direction to issue fresh writ to the advocate commissioner to effect partition and allot the saham as per the preliminary decree. Dilshad Hossain being dead his heirs Nur Alam and others Vs. Majibar Rahman. 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 164.

 

Order XX rule 18(2)— Suit for partition and allotment of saham. Purchaser having purchased land in excess of share of his vendor is not entitled to get saham—

Defendant who purchased part of suit land in excess of the share of his vendor who had no subsisting salable interest and who did not contest the suit and challenge the rafanama/compromise by filing written statement having acquired no right, title and interest thereby is not entitled to get saham for his said purchased land. Abdul AH Bhuiyan (Md) Vs. Jahura Khatun and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 143.

 

Order XLI rule 22—Respondent can file Cross objection— Time limit is not inflexible --

It is well settled that a respondent may file cross objection against the decree within one month of the service of notice. The time limit is not inflexible. The appellate court may allow further time as it may consider proper to file such cross objection. Keshowam Begum (Musammat) and another Vs. Khaleda Ahsan and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 48.

 

Order 21 rule 99— When no objection as to bonafide possession is raised before the executing court— Order 39 rule 1— Temporary injunction against execution proceedings intended to delay or defeat the decree obtained 30 years back is refused—

The execution proceedings in respect of a decree obtained 30 years back were at the fag end. The petitioner did not raise objection or obstructed on the bonafide claim of possession before the executing court as provided under Order 21 rule 99 of the Code of Civil Procedure. The apex court held such belated move for temporary injunction at this stage is designed to delay or defeat the decree obtained 30 years back and accordingly refused the same. Joirunnessa and others Vs. Abdul Motalib being dead his heirs Alia Begum and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 73.

 

Order 21 rule 29— Third party is not entitled to seek for stay of execution proceedings—

The High Court Division discharged the rule with the finding that application of a third person who is not a party to the decree is not maintainable. The Appellate Division affirmed the decision of the High Court Division in enunciating the proposition of law with regard to stay of the execution proceedings of decree. Faruque Reza (Md.) and another Vs. Most Hossena Am Begum 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 14.

 

Order 21 rule 11—Execution of decree and the limitation thereof—

Limitation Act, 1908—

Article 182(3) and (5)— Applicability of article 182(3) to execution proceedings—

Limitation for execution of decree is three years. Execution case filed within the period of limitation can well be continued after disposal of appeal and the dismissal of review. Article 182(5) is applicable when the decree is altered or modified in revision. But when revision is dismissed article 182(3) of the Limitation Act, 1908 shall be applicable and as such the pending Execution case can well be continued. Kazi Shamsul Huq and others Vs. Rebeya Begum and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 399.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Order 21 rule 58— Release of property from attachment—

Disputed property has been attached in Execution case for realisation of decretal dues. Uttara Bank contested the suit by filing written statement. Since Uttara Bank was not stranger to the proceedings the application under Order 21 rule 58 C.P.C. is held by the Appellate Division not maintainable. However the claim of the Uttara Bank has been left to be decided by the Executing Court. Uttara Bank Ltd. Vs. Subordinate Judge and Artha Rin Adalat No.4, Dhaka and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 328.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Order XXI, rule 90— Application for setting aside auction sale—

In the instant case the appellant filed the miscellaneous appeal against an interlocutory order passed by the Artha Rin Adalat rejecting an application for setting aside auction sale in execution case without complying with the requirements of section 41 and as such the learned judges of the High Court Division dismissed the appeal as being one not maintainable. Awlad Hossain Vs. Bangladesh Shilpa Bank, Maijdee Branch and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 444.

 

Order 22 rule 1— Suit against several defendants of whom one died before filing of the suit is held not a nullity—

Suit filed against dead person is held not a nullity where there are other defendants alive and the right to sue survives. The direction given by the trial court to the surviving defendants to furnish the particulars of the legal representatives of the deceased defendant for the purpose of substitution is held by the Appellate Division perfectly justified. A.F.M Wahid Shahajahan Vs. Subordinate Judge (now Joint District Judge), third court Dhaka and others) 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 203.

 

Order 22 rule 9— Provides for substitution of the legal heirs of deceased appellant upon setting aside of abatement of the appeal—

Limitation Act, 1908— Section 5— Applicable to an application seeking setting aside abatement— But filing separate application u/s 5 for condonation of delay when the court is satisfied on the materials on record may be waived in exceptional circumstance—

Order 22 rule 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 provides for substitution of legal heirs of deceased plaintiff/appellant or defendant/ respondent, as the case may be, where the right to sue survives after setting aside abatement. Section 5 of the Limitation Act, 1908 has been made applicable to such case. In certain exceptional circumstances the apex court held that necessity of filing separate application u/s 5 of the Limitation Act may be waived where the court is satisfied on the basis of the materials on record to secure the ends of justice and set aside the abatement and-allow substitution based on the principles that the right of a party cannot be defeated by mere technicalities. Hazi Habibur Rahman Vs. Ayub Alt Saivdagar being dead his heirs Most Kamrun Nahar and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 14.

 

Order 23 rule 1— Withdrawal of suit with permission to sue afresh at the appellate stage on ground of formal defects not allowed—

The plaintiff did not take any steps for amendment of plaint although the defendants in their written statement raised objection as to the vagugeness of the suit land and allowed the suit to be disposed of on contest. Since the plaintiff did not take steps at the earliest opportunity to amend the plaint nor sought for the withdrawal of the suit on grounds of formal defect with permission to sue afresh on the same cause of action, the learned judge of the High Court Division held the impugned order of the Subordinate judge rejecting the prayer for withdrawal perfectly justified. Sekander Alt and others Vs. Md. Seraj Mia and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 154.

 

Order 23, Rule (1) and (2)— Withdrawal of suit with permission to sue afresh at the revisional stage on ground of formal defect—

Section 100 has in fact, been replaced by sectionllS by the Law Reforms Ordinance, 1979—

Civil proceedings include suit, appeal and revision—

In appropriate case a suit may be withdrawn with permission to sue afresh at the revisional stage on ground of formal defects. Amendment of plaint may not always be proper substitute for formal defects.

 

In a partition suit all the ejmali properties must be brought into the hotchpoch. Noor Jahan and others Vs. Abdiir Rahman alias Kacha and others 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 49.

 

 Order 26 rule 9— Report of advocate commissioner—

Report of advocate commissioner when not objected to at the time of trial and when it was used in evidence it can not be subsequently challenged. Shamsul Alam (Hazi) Vs. Dr. Ashim Barker and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 199.

 

Order 26 rule 9— Local investigation may be allowed even after closure of evidence for effective adjudication of dispute—

Limitation Act, 1908— Articles 152 and 156— Limitation for a revisional application "before the District Judge is 30 days under article 152 while that of before the High Court Division is 90 days under article 156—

The identity of the suit land or the mouza shall have to be ascertained and the local investigation must be made at the earliest opportunity. In appropriate case the local investigation may be allowed even after closure of evidence for effective adjudication of dispute. The learned judge of the High Court Division held the limitation for a revision before the District Judge is 30 (thirty) days as in the case of appeal under article 152 and the limitation for revision before the High Court Division is 90 (ninety) days under article 156 of the Limitation Act, 1908. In the instant case the District Judge entertained the revisional application after two years of the impugned order at the time when the same was already barred by limitation and a second application for the self same matter was pending before the trial court. In that view of the matter the learned judge of the High Court Division allowed the revision. Golam Hossain Talukder (Md.) Vs. Md. Abdul Gafur and others 15 MLR (2010) (HO 213.

 

Order 26 rule 14(2)— Report of the advocate   Commissioner   when   the commissioner is not examined in court, is not admissible in evidence-Partition Act, 1893— Section 4— Suit for partition among the     cosharers     is     maintainable— Amicable partition is no bar—

Suit for partition of the shares of suit properties among cosharers by mets and bounds is maintainable notwithstanding that there was amicable partition. A cosharer in possession of land in excess of his share is bound to part with the excess land. Abdul Noor (Md.) @ Chunnu Mia and another Vs. Makhan Mia @ Md. Laisuzzaman and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 347.

 

 Order 38 rule 5— Attachment before judgment— power to be exercised with utmost care and caution—

Unless the conditions specified in rule 5 of Order 38 of the Code of Civil Procedure are satisfied no order for attachment before judgment should be made which can be used as a weapon of coercion or oppression. Again no order of attachment before judgment can be passed before leave to sue as pauper is finally decided. Rina Aktar Vs. Md. Shahidul Islam 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 194.

 

Order 39, rule 1— Temporary injunction against Government development scheme can not be allowed—

In a case where greater national interest is involved and the Government development scheme is likely to be interferedwith, the apex court held temporary injunction should not be granted. Executive Engineer, Water Development Board, Nilphamari and another Vs. Md. Moktarnddin and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 297.

 

Order 39, rule 1 and 2— Injunction in a partition suit—

In a partition suit both the parties are co-sharers in the suit land. The apex court held the ends of justice will be met if both the parties are directed to maintain status-quo till disposal of the partition suit. Asadid Haque (Md.) and others Vs. Md. Anisuzzaman and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 111.

 

Order 39,  rules  I and 2— Unwarranted and irrelevant observation made by the High Court Division in the order portion of the judgment in incidental proceedings are held not binding upon the trial court—

The single bench of the High Court Division in the instant case made some observation in the order portion of the judgment which are uncalled for and unwarranted while deciding the dispute in incidental proceedings. The Appellate Division dis-approved such observation and held that the same shall not be binding upon the trial court in deciding the dispute between the parties. Quazi Faruqne Ahmed (Dr.) Vs. M.A Wadud and others 15. MLR (2010) (AD) 467.

 

Order 39 rule 1 and 2— Order of status-quo being an injunction of temporary nature is appealable— Revision does not lie against such order—

Law is settled that an order of statusquo restraining the parties from changing the nature and character of the suit property is in fact an injunction of temporary nature which is an appealable order as contemplated under Order 43 rule l(r) C.P.C. against which revision does not lie. Doulat Ahmed Vs. Md. Shafiqul Islam i Chowdhury and others 11 MLR (2006)  (AD) 48.

 

Order   39   rules   1   and   2—   Not applicable to cases of payment under L.C relating to international trade—

A letter of credit when issued by a bank becomes an independent contract between the issuing bank and the negotiating bank apart from the contract for sale of goods between the seller and buyer. When documents of shipment are presented before the bank which issued the L.C it is bound to make the payment unless the documents so presented ex-facie appear to be forged and fraudulent. No prohibitory order or an injunction can stop such payment which will seriously affect international trade. Dutex Enterprise Co. Ltd. Vs. RMS Textile and Apparels Ltd and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 393.

 

 Order 40 rule  1— Appointment of receiver should be made very sparingly in exceptional circumstances—

In a partition suit receiver cannot be appointed without the consent of the other co-sharer defendants in possession of the suit land. Unless there is imminent danger of waste or destruction of the suit property receiver should not be appointed. Salahuddin Khan (Md.) Vs. Most. Halima Akhter Khatoon and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 77.

 

Order 39, rules 1 and 2— Necessary requirements  in  granting temporary injunction—

In order to get an order of temporary injunction the plaintiff must prove his primafacie title and possession in the suit land and also must show that the balance of conveniance and inconvenience is in his favour. When it is found that the plaintiff is not in possession of the suit land, no injunction can be granted

 

Code Civil Procedure, 1908— Order 41, rule 21— Rehearing of appeal— Dispensing with the requirement of service of notice on non-contesting defendants is not a bar to rehearing the appeal—

In an appropriate case the court of appeal is not precluded from allowing rehearing of the appeal by reason of dispensing with the necessity of serving notice upon the non-contesting defendants. The learned judge of the High Court Division found no illegality in the impugned order allowing rehearing of the appeal. Abdus Shahid @ Shahid and others Vs. Anowara Begum and others 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 308.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Order 41 rule 23— Remand cannot be granted as a matter of course to provide opportunity to fillup lacuna—

When a suit was decided on contest without any material issue undecided or left out, the suit cannot be remanded for providing opportunity to the plaintiff to fillup the lacuna. The apex court deprecated such a belated move and dismissed the appeal. Aslam Khan (Md.) Vs. Haji Abdur Rahim and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 149.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Order 41 rule 27— Admission of additional evidence at the appellate stage-In this case the plaintiff could not through inadvertence produce the vital document of contract before the trial court. The plaintiff however produced the deed of contract before the appellate court which after examining the necessary witness admitted the same as additional evidence with which the apex court found nothing wrong and dismissed the leave petition. Kamaluddin Ahmed Sarwar @ Alhaj Kamaluddin Sarwar being dead his heirs Hasina Banu and others Vs. Mohammad Shahjahan and another 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 421.

 

 Order    41    rule    27—    Additional evidence at the stage of appeal- when can be admitted—

Law governing the question of admission of additional evidence oral or documentary at the stage of appeal is now well settled. Only the evidence which was tendered but refused by the trial court and the document or witness could not be produced during trial inspite of due diligence which the appellate court considers necessary for adjudication of the dispute between the parties having direct bearing on the result of the suit may be admitted at the appellate stage of the proceedings upon recording the reason therefor, as envisaged under Order 41 rule 27 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908. Tahedul Islam (Md.) being dead his heirs Asma Bewa and others Vs. Md. Mojibar Rahman being dead his heirs Jabeda Bewa and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 385.

 

 Order 41 rule 27— Admissibility of evidence at the belated stage of the proceedings at appellate stage—

Appeal   against   final   decree   of a partition suit without challenging the preliminary decree is held defective. However separate suit for partition and saham of the party having not been granted the saham in a previous suit shall not be barred. When the defendants' did not pray for saham before the trial court the High Court Division did not allow them to adduce additional evidence by producing certain documents at the belated stage of the proceedings of the appeal which was held defective as the appellant did not challenge the preliminary decree granting saham to the plaintiff. Jarina Khatun (Most.) and another Vs. Md. Nabab All Mia and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 269.

 

Order 41— Power of appellate court to reassess evidence on record—

It is well settled that while reversing the judgment and decree the appellate court must advert to the findings of the trial court and in doing so the appellate court shall have all the powers of the trial court to reassess the evidence on record. Service of summons by hanging on the outer fencing of the dwelling Irmt of the defendant when established is held by the apex court a good service. Laches of advocate when taken as a ground of non-appearance must be established by evidence. Sitdhir Kumar Das and another Vs. Abdul Makk Mia and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 57.

 

Order XLI rule 21— Applicable to appeal but not to revision—

Lawyers of the parties are required to remain present in the court when judgments and orders are passed. When the judgments and orders are posted in the daily cause list, there is sufficient compliance with the requirement of informing the parties thereof. Court officers are not found to call the lawyers of the parties and inform them the judgment and orders of the court by taking their signature on the margin of the note sheet. Provisions of Order XLI rule 21 C.P.C are applicable to appeal but not to revision. Once a revision is disposed of on merit by a regular judgment, there is no further scope of rehearing the same. Manirunnessa Khanam and another Vs. Syed Madassir All and another 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 51.

 

Code of Civil Procedure 1908— Order 41 rule 23— Remand cannot be ordered   when   there   are   sufficient evidence on record to effectively decide the issue under controversy—

A court of appeal is empowered to send a suit or case on remand to the trial court where it omitted to frame a material issue and give its finding thereon or where the evidence on record are not sufficient for effective adjudication of the issue under dispute. But where the evidence on record are sufficient the appellate court cannot send,the suit or case on remand as a matter of course. The learned judge of the High Court Division set aside the impugned order of remand without issuing any rule and directed the appellate court below to decide the appeal on merit. Nilchuni Bibi being dead her heirs Ayub All and others Vs. Nedu Sheikh and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 174.

 

Order 41 rule 27— Admissibility of additional  evidence  at  the  appellate stage-Evidence Act, 1872— Section 73— Comparison of disputed handwriting by court—

In appropriate case additional evidence may be accepted at the stage of appeal in order to advance the cause of justice—

Though section 73 of the Evidence Act, 1872 empowers the court to compare by itself disputed handwriting and signature, yet the apex court discouraged such practice as unsatisfactory and insisted upon getting the disputed signature and handwriting examined by handwriting expert. The learned judges of the High Court Division also opined that in view of the continuing advancement of the science and technology of examination of handwritings, it is the safe course to obtain the opinion of the expert on the disputed signature and as such upheld the impugned order passed by the appellate court below allowing examination of the disputed documents by expert. Abdur Rashid Miah and another Vs. Md. Zami Shah Neiuaz and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 317.

 

Order 41 rule 27— Amendment of plaint and recalling P.W.I at the appellate stage to fill up lacuna— Cannot be allowed—

In the instant case the appellant sought for the amendment of the plaint after 7 years and prayed for recalling the P.W.I at the appellate stage to fill up the lacuna which the appellate court below rejected. The learned judge of the High Court Division held the impugned order perfectly justified and dismissed the revision. Abdul Khair Mollah (Moulavi) Vs. Golafernessa and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 203.
