Section 44A(1)— Filing of certified copy of decree passed by a superior court of foreign country in the court of District Judge for execution—

The decree in question was passed by the Kolkata High Court which the decree-holder filed in the court of the District Judge, Dhaka for execution. The District Judge started an execution case and transferred the same to the court of joint District Judge for disposal. The judgment-debtor filed an application for dismissal of the execution case which the joint District Judge rejected. The judgment-debtor preferred revision which was also dismissed by the Additional District Judge. Against the said order the judgment-debtor preferred revision before the High Court Division. The learned judges of the High Court Division upon analysis of the provisions of the law relating therewith found nothing wrong with the impugned order and directed to dispose of the execution case within 4 months. Al-Arafah Islami Bank Ltd. Vs. M/s Nobel Enterprise 15 MLR (2010) (HO) 351.

 

 Order 47 rule 1— Grounds for review of judgment— Supreme Court Appellate Division Rules, 1988— Order 26— Procedure of review— State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950— Section 3(2)— Hat and Bazar land and its periphery are not retainable—

A review of judgment may be made by the Appellate Division only on the grounds enumerated under Order 47 rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 and in the manner as required by Order 26 of the Supreme Court Rules, 1988. But review of its judgment where the grounds raised were all answered in the judgment in question is not permissible. Hat and Bazar land and the periphery thereof being non-retainable as contemplated under section 3(2) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 vested in the Government free from all encumbrances after the notification dated 14.4.1956. Nurul Islam Bhuiyan and another Vs. Government of Bangladesh represented by the Deputy Commissioner, Netrokona and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 33.

 

Order 47 rule 1— Review of judgment on the grounds specified therein— Bangladesh Supreme Court (Appellate Division) Rules, 1988— Rule 26— Grounds for review of judgment—

Unless there is ground of error of law apparent on the face of the record occasioning failure of justice, Review Petition cannot be entertained. Despite the ouster clause of jurisdiction Civil Court can scrutinize the impugned order to see as to whether the same is passed in accordance with law. An issue which was never raised earlier cannot be raised for the first time at the stage of review before the Appellate Division. Sena Kah/an Sangstha and another Vs. Hazi Sufi Fazal Ahmed being dead his heirs Nazir Mohiuddin and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 296.

 

Order   47—   rule   1—   Review   of judgment   can   only   be   made   for correcting error apparent on the face of record-Supreme        Court        Appellate Division Rules, 1988— Order 26— Review of judgment of the Appellate Division can be made on similar grounds as under Order 47 rule 1 C.P.C—

Review of judgment or order of the Appellate Division can only be made on the grounds of correcting error apparent on the face of the record as provided under Order 26 of the Supreme Court Appellate Division Rules and Order 47 rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure. When the points raised were answered in the impugned judgment, no review thereof is permissible. Review can not be resorted to for rehearing of the appeal concluded by pronouncement of a regular judgment. Abdul Halim Miah (Md.) and others Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary Ministry of Establishment and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 209.

 

Order    47    rule    1—    Review    of judgment   or   order   on   ground   of discovery of new facts or evidence—

When the fact of the alleged ground taken for the review of a decree or order was already within the knowledge of the defendant and the same was stated in the written statement, the provisions of Order 47 rule l.C.P.C are not attracted in the instant case. Matiar Rahman being dead his heirs Shahajada Hosstiin Mallik and others Vs. Assistant Custodian of Enemy Property Lands and Buildings, Bakerganj and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 305.

 

Order    47,    rule    1—    Review    of judgment can be made only on grounds enumerated thereunder—

Judgment can be reviewed on the grounds enumerated under Order 47 rule 1 of the C.P.C. Similar grounds for review are also contained in Order 26 of the Supreme Court Appellate Division Rules, 1988. The apex court is not required to answer any academic question however important the same may be. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and another Vs. Mostafizur Rahman 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 316.

 

 Order 47 rule 1— Review of judgment can be made only on the specific limited grounds— Bangladesh Supreme Court (Appellate Division) Rules, 1988— Order 26 rule 4—Requirements of rule 4 must be fulfilled—

Law is well settled that review does not mean reopening the matter and rehearing of the appeal concluded by pronouncement of judgment. Appeal is a right while review is not. Unless the conditions of rule 1 of Order 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure and the requirements of rule 4 of Order 26 of the Bangladesh Supreme Court (Appellate Division) Rules 1988 are fulfilled Review Petition is not maintainable. The instant review petition having been found not satisfying the above mentioned conditions is dismissed. Azizullnh & Azizur Rahman Vs. Abu Taker Chowdhury and oliters 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 129.

 

 Order    47    rule    1—    Review    of judgment   can   not   be   allowed   for affording opportunity of rehearing— Supreme Court of Bangladesh (Appellate Division) Rules, 1988— Order XXVI (part IV) rule 4— Requirement   of   filing   the   Review petition—

Review is not intended to reopen and rehear the matter finally decided by a judgment. After a matter/dispute has been finally decided by pronouncement of judgment it can not be reopened for rehearing except on the ground enumerated under Order 47 rule 1 and upon fulfilling the requirement of rule 4 of the Supreme Covirt of Bangladesh (Appellate Division) Rules, 1988. Shafiqne Ahmed (Md.) Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 174.

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908— Order 47 rule 1— Review of judgment on ground of non-application or wrong interpretation of law is not permissible—

Where remedies are available under specific law, review of its judgment by the same court on the ground of non-application or wrong interpretation of law is not entertainable. Executive Engineer, Roads and Highways, Noakhali Vs. Naderuzzaman and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 136.

 

2863

Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898

Citation: 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 52, 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 351, 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 17

Case Year: 1898

Subject: Code of Criminal Procedure

Delivery Date: 2018-03-12

Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898

Section 195(l)(c) and 476— Power of appellate  court  to  lodge   complaint against forgery of documents used in connection with judicial proceedings—

As provided under section 107 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 the court of appeal has all the powers of the trial court. It is competent to do what the trial court failed to do. It can make complaint under section 195(l)(c) read with section 476 of the Code of Criminal Procedure in respect of forgery of document used in the judicial proceedings before it. Messers N.F.M Universal Estate Ltd. represented by its Managing Director Abdul Awal Minto Vs. A.N.M Obaidul Islam being dead his heirs Gidshan Begum and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 52.

 

Section 403(1)— Provides that a person tried and convicted by a court of competent jurisdiction shall not be tried and punished again for the same offence— Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 35(2)— Prohibits trial and conviction of a person twice for the same offence— General Clauses Act, 1897— Section 26— Contains similar provision against trial and conviction of a person more than once for the same offence—

From the above provisions it is abundantly clear that a person once tried and convicted by a court of competent jurisdiction for a particular offence shall not be tried and punished for the second time for the same offence. The appellant upon conviction by a Special Martial Law court though having no jurisdiction, had already served out the most part of the sentence and was then released on amnesty. The apex court held it inappropriate and against the interest of justice to reopen and restart the case afresh after lapse of long period and in that view set aside the order of the Sessions Judge. Mohammad Ullah Vs. Sessions ]udge, Noakhali and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 351.

 

Section 561A— Quashment of proceedings—

Unless there is a situation as contemplated under section 12 a Chairman can not be placed under suspension. Where in a proceedings under section 561A Cr.P.C for quashment of conviction and sentence a rule has been issued and the convict-petitioner is released on bail the criminal proceedings against him is held still pending and in that view of the matter the apex court declared the impugned suspension order illegal and of no legal effect. Government of Bangladesh represented by the Secretary Ministry of Local Government and others Vs. Md. Fariduddin Talnkder 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 17.

2864

Companies Act, 1913

Citation: 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 129

Case Year: 1913

Subject: Companies Act

Delivery Date: 2018-03-12

Companies Act, 1913

Section 38— Gives wide power to the court for scrutiny of cases of fraud, undue influence and misrepresentation m transferring shares and to give direction for rectification of Share Register—

Evidence Act, 1872— Section 155(3)— Previous statement should be confronted to the witness to impeach his credibility—

Upon an application of person affected the court can examine and scrutinise the records and papers as to any fraud, undue influence or misrepresentation in transferring shares and give direction for rectification of the Share Register. The power of the court under section 38 of the Companies Act, is wide enough. Ahmed Impex (Private) Ltd. and others Vs. Mocjbul Ahmed being dead his heirs Ferdous Ara Begum and another 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 129.

2865

Companies Act, 1994

Citation: 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 432

Case Year: 1994

Subject: Companies Act

Delivery Date: 2018-03-12

Companies Act, 1994

Sections 12 and 13— Confirmation of the change in the object clause of the Memorandum of Association—

The petitioner company for the purpose of running properly and profitably the business of the company brought change in the object clause of the MOA in a Extraordinary General Meeting upon compliance with all the legal requirements which the judge of the High Court Division in company matters confirmed and directed the Registrar Joint Stock Companies to register the same accordingly. Sunirmal Choudhuri, Managing Director, Bayer Crop Science Ltd. Vs. Registrar Joint Stock Companies 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 432.

2866

Companies Act, 1994

Citation: 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 292, 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 369, 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 35

Case Year: 1994

Subject: Companies Act

Delivery Date: 2018-03-12

Companies Act, 1994

Section 81(2) and 85(3)— Power of High Court Division to give direction for holding Annual General Meeting (AGM.)—

The High Court Division in exercise of its power under section 81(2) and 85(3) of The Companies Act, 1994 can direct holding of AGM and in so directing can also give ancillary and consequential direction as it may seem fit. Bangladesh Bank Vs. Sk. Abul Hossain and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 292.

Company Act, 1994— Section 85(3)— Power of the Company Bench of the High Court Division to give directions in ancillary matters—

Law is well settled that the Company Bench of the High Court Division can not interfere with the internal management of the company. In the instant case the Company Bench directed in certain ancillary matters such as the fixing of record date, preparation of fresh balance sheet and fixing the date of AGM. The apex court having found nothing wrong affirmed the impugned order and dismissed the appeals. Reazaul Karim (Mohd.) and others Vs. ABM Khalecjiizzaman and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 369.

Section 95— Dispute relating to matters as contemplated under section 95 being of civil nature are to be decided by the civil court—

Section 2(g) of the Companies Act, 1994 confers jurisdiction upon the civil court to decide disputes under section 95 and as such the Company Court of the x High Court Division can not decide such dispute. Abdul Mohit and others Vs. Social Investment Bank Ltd. and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 35.

2867

Companies Profit (Workers) Participation Act, 1968

Citation: 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 21

Case Year: 1968

Subject: Companies Profit

Delivery Date: 2018-03-12

Companies Profit (Workers) Participation Act, 1968

Section 3—Management of Industrial   undertaking  is  under  the legal   obligation  of  establishing  the workers welfare fund—

Hotel and Restaurant being an industrial undertaking the management thereof is required under section 3 of the Companies Profit (Workers) Participation Act, 1968 to establish the workers welfare fund and implement the scheme thereunder. Labour court has the jurisdiction to decide the dispute relating to the implementation of the scheme under section 34 of the Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969. Hotel Agrnbad Ltd. Chittagong represented by its Managing Director Vs. Chairman First Labour Court, Chiftagong and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 21.

2868

Conduct of Election Rules, 1972

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 383

Case Year: 1972

Subject: Conduct of Election Rules

Delivery Date: 2018-03-12

Conduct of Election Rules, 1972

Rule 9(1)— Use of Election Symbols are not violative of    fundamental rights—

The election symbols such as boat, plough and sheaf of paddy are being used by the major political parties from long past without any objection from any quarter. Since the concerned organisation did not raise any objection against the use of symbols in election the petitioner is held to have no locus standi in the writ petition which is rejected summarily. Sliahadat Hossain (Md.) (Advocate) Vs. Bangladesh  represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs and   others 11 MLR   (2006) (HC) 383.

2869

Constitution of Bangladesh

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 237, 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 316, 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 287, 296, 357, 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 296, 350, 364, 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 299,349, 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 303, 309, 316, 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 308, 309, 330, 15 MLR (2010) (AD

Case Year: 1972

Subject: Constitution of Bangladesh

Delivery Date: 2018-03-13

Constitution of Bangladesh

 

Constitution  (Fourteenth Amendment) Act, 2004— Not violative of basic structure of the constitution—

The provisions of reserved seats for women in Parliament were contained in article 65(3) of the constitution from the very beginning. The constitution (Fourteenth Amendment) Act, 2004 did not introduce in the constitution any new concept and as such it did not change any basic structure of the constitution nor it is violative of fundamental rights. Act No.30 only provides for the procedure of election of women members in the Parliament to the reserved seats on the basis of proportional representation by a single vote and thus is not violative of fundamental rights nor it offends the basic structure of the constitution. Farida Akhter and others Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary Cabinet Division and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 237.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh—

llth Amendment does not oust the jurisdiction of judicial review of actions ratified thereunder and as such the detention of former President H.M. Ershad was held illegal and passed without any lawful authority. The apex court declined to review the judgment after fifteen years. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and another Vs. Mostafizur Rahman 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 316.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh-Preamble and article 7—

The preamble contains the lofty ideals of nationalism, socialism, secularism and democracy as basic principles for which our valiant freedom fighters fought for the independence and millions of them made their supreme sacrifice in laying down their lives by embracing martyrdom. Bangladesh came into being as a sovereign independent state through liberation war. Millions of our valiant freedom fighters were inspired by the high ideals and the framers of our constitution which is the embodiment of the will of the people engrained the said ideals in the constitution as the fundamental and basic features of the constitution. Change of the basic feature tantamouiits to violation of the constitution.

 

Article 7— Supremacy of the Constitution—

The constitution is the embodiment of the will of the people and is the supreme law of the land and all powers shall be exercised under the authority of the constitution and any other lav/ inconsistent therewith is void. Khondaker Dehuar Hossain and others Vs. Bangladesh Italian Marble Works Ltd and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 287, 296, 357.

 

Article 102— Power of the Supreme Court in matters of judicial review—

Supreme Court has the power of judicial review of all administrative actions and or the laws passed by the parliament so far the vires as to their constitutionality are concerned, ibid 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 296, 350, 364.

 

Article 80— Power of the legislature to make law and validate invalid law—

No doubt Parliament has the absolute power to make law in consonance with the constitution. But Parliament can not validate any law which it cannot make, ibid 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 299,349.

 

Martial law

Martial law is black law. It is unknown in our constitution. With the proclamation of martial law the supremacy of the constitution is lost and it is subordinated to the M.L.R, MLOS. This usurpation of power through extra constitutional means and the actions made thereunder are illegal, void and non-est which constitute offence of sedition of worst kind, ibid 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 303, 309, 316.

 

Fifth amendment of the constitution— Its validation—

Waiver and acquiescence by acceptance of the people—

Proclamations made in violation of the constitution are illegal, void and non-est which can not be validated on the basis of the principle of waiver and acquiescence, ibid 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 308, 309, 330.

 

Article 150— Means to protect acts done in transitional period—

Article 150 does not mean to protect the actions done by usurpers in violation of constitution, ibid 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 315, 316.

 

Article 142—

Parliament can add some provisions which are innocuous through the procedure under article 142. But it can not make any law chaning the basic feature of the constitution. Similarily it also can not legalise any such illegal actions, ibid 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 315, 349.

 

Fifth Amendment of the constitution-Basic concepts never intended the Republic to be a theocratic state by omitting the basic feature of secularism, ibid 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 315, 316.

 

Article 9—

Principle of nationalism as Bangladeshi and Bangalee are discussed and Bangladeshi nationalism, is retained, ibid 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 327, 332.

 

Secularism as existed in the constitution on 15.8.1975 will revive and the Orders which changed this basic principle is declared by the High Court Division as illegal void and non-est. ibid 15 MLR (2020) (AD) Page 329.

 

Doctrine of necessity and condonation—

Some acts which relate to welfare of the people are condoned on the principles of doctrine of necessity, ibid 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 351, 352, 358, 359.

 

Condonation allowed by the Appellate Division—

The Appellate Division approved the judgment and orders of the High Court Division with certain modifications enumerated in the last two paragraphs of the judgment, ibid 15 MLR (2010) (AD) Page 367, 368.

 

Articles 18 and 32 — Enshrines in the constitution the obligation of the state to ensure measures for sound health of its citizen and fundamental right to life- Value Added Tax Act, 1991—

The imposition of value added tax on the medical service in the medical institution, Dental care centre and pathological test in the laboratory being in conflict with constitutional provisions are declared illegal and void —

In view of the provisions contained in articles 18 and 32 of the Constitution the High Court Division declared the imposition of VAT on the medical service and pathological test to be paid by the citizen as illegal and unconstitutional. The Appellate Division affirmed the impugned judgment and order and dismissed the leave petition. Chairman, National Board of Revenue (NBR) Vs. Advocate Ziilhasuddin Ahmed and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 457.

 

evvsjv‡`k msweavbt

Aby‡”Q` 18 Ges 32 bvMwiK Rxe‡bi AwaKvi Ges bvMwi‡Ki my¯^v¯’¨ wbwðZ Kib iv‡óªi mvsweavwbK `vwqZ¡t

wPwKrmv †K›`ª, `š— wPwKrmv I c¨v_jwRK¨vj j¨ve‡iUvixi wPwKrmv †mev 1991 m‡bi g~j¨ ms†hvRb Ki AvB‡bi AvIZvfz³Kib msweav‡bi mwnZ mvsNwlK nIqvq nvB †KvU© wefv‡Mi gvbbxq wePvicwZe„›` Dnv A‰ea Ges evwZj ewjqv †NvlYv K‡ib| [15 Gg.Gj.Avi (GwW) 457 c„ôvq wi‡cvU© K…Z iv‡q Avwcj wefvM KZ©…K nvB KvU wefv‡Mi GB ivq envj Kiv nBqv‡Q|]

GW‡fv‡KU Ryjnvm DÏxb Avn‡g` Ms ebvg evsjv‡`k Ms 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 433.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh — Article   21 —  Right   to   life   means meaningful life in healthy environment —

Construction of multi-storied building on the space kept earmarked for open car parking by the Dhaka City Corporation in violation of the master plan and without approval of the plan by the RAJUK is held by the apex court illegal and as such directed demolision of the said construction as being opposed to the spirit of article 21 of the constitution. Sharif Nurul Ambia Vs. Dhaka City Corporation represented by the Mayor and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 288.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh — Article 22 and 102 — Separation of judiciary means functional separation — Writ petitioner    being a retired District Judge and a concious citizen can well invoke jurisdiction of the High Court Division to issue writ of co-warranto—

A judicial officer by reason of performing non-judicial functions on deputation does not cease to be member of the judicial service— Nitimala of 2001 held to have the force of law—

Bidhimala of 2002 clearly provides for filling up exclusively 75% posts of Deputy Secretary, Joint Secretary. Additional Secretary and Secretary of the Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs by the members of the judicial service on deputation. The judicial officers who opted for the service in the Legislative Drafting Wing have already ceased to be members of the judicial service and they are not eligible for appointment and promotion to those reserved posts of the Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs. Like-wise none of the members of the other cadre or non-cadre service is eligible for appointment or promotion to those reserved posts including the post of Secretary. In that view of the position of law the apex court declared the promotion of writ respondent No. 5 Kazi Habibul Awal as Secretary incharge and then as Secretary illegal, without jurisdiction  and  of no  legal effect. Government of Bangladesh and others Vs. Md. Aftabuddin, retired District and Sessions Judge and another 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 41.

 

Article 27 and 29— Right to equal treatment before law— Principle of legitimate expectation does not hold good when the right is waived—

Right to promotion is based on seniority cum merit. When duly qualified before the selection committee and a fitness list is prepared including the name of the petitioner he could legitimately expect to be promoted to the position of General Manager. But before it was exhausted the list was cancelled and the second list was prepared after selection test in which the petitioner appeared and was unsuccessful. By appearing in the subsequent test for preparing the second list and becoming unsuccessful the petitioner waived his right to be promoted on the basis of the 1st list since cancelled. Syed S.M. Hasan Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Finance and another 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 192.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 27 and 102— Equality before law is not always absolute— Classification is permissible-Import Policy of 1997-2000— Article 21— Empowers the authority to relax the conditions—

Import of reconditioned cars of more than 5 years old for personal use and for commercial purpose are two different cases which are distinguishable from the other. While the authority relaxed the conditions for personal use and refused the prayer of the writ petitioner for commercial purpose that does not offend article 27 of the Constitution. Chief Controller of Import and Exports and others Vs. Md. Farnk Ahmed 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 122.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Articles 27 and 102— Interference on ground of discrimination—

The writ petitioner was selected for appointment to the post of Principal of Abdul Malek Degree College alongwith others for similar position having similar qualification by the same committee. The petitioner was not allowed the portion of salary under the M.P.O although those others on similar footing were granted the said salary. Having found the impugned action discriminatory offending the fundamental right of equality under article 27, the High Court Division directed the respondents to pay to the writ petitioner the part of the salary under the M.P.O. The apex court upheld the impugned decision as being perfectly justified and accordingly dismissed the leave petition. Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary Ministry of Education and another Vs. Syed Md. Belayet Hossain 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 512.

 

Article 31 and 42— Right to be treated in accordance with law and the right to own and enjoy property are fundamental rights guaranteed under the Constitution—

The learned judges further held that while passing the impugned order of cancellation and direction of removal of the building the petitioner's fundamental rights guaranteed under article 31 and 42 of the Constitution were violated which eventually warranted intervention of the court. A Roitf Chowdhury and another Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Works and another 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 177.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article  35(2)—  Prohibits   trial  and conviction  of  a  person  twice  for the same offence— General Clauses Act, 1897— Section 26— Contains similar provision against trial and conviction of a person more than once for the same offence—

From the above provisions it is abundantly clear that a person once tried and convicted by a court of competent jurisdiction for a particular offence shall not be tried and punished for the second time for the same offence. The appellant upon conviction by a Special Martial Law court though having no jurisdiction, had already served out the most part of the sentence and was then released on amnesty. The apex court held it inappropriate and against the interest of justice to reopen and restart the case afresh after lapse of long period and in that view set aside the order of the Sessions Judge. Mohammad Ullah Vs. Sessions Judge, Noakhali and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 351.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh-Article 48(3)— Privileged documents are immune from being disclosed or produced before court—

Evidence Act, 1872—

Sections 123 and 162 — Immunity of documents relating affairs of the state — When privilege as contemplated under article 48(3) of the Constitution with regard to certain documents are claimed, the court has to hold inquiry as to the validity of such claim. The apex court set aside the impugned order of calling for the documents as the same was done without holding any such inquiry. Government of Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Law, justice and Parliamentary Affairs Vs. Md. Shamsul Hilda and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 224.

 

evvsjv‡`k msweavbt

msweav‡bi cÖRvZvwš¿K Ges MYZvwš¿K  ˆewkó (basic feature) †Kvb Ae¯’v‡ZB cwieZ©b Kiv hvB‡ebv—

Aby‡”Q` 58 M— Zë¡vveavq miKv‡ii †gqv`Kvj 90 w`b hvnv †Kvb ARynv‡Z ewa©Z Kiv hvB‡ebv—

wbe©vPb Kwgk‡bi Acwinvh© KZ©e¨ Ges `vwqZ¡ msm` fvswMqv hvIqvi 90 w`‡bi g‡a¨ msm` wbe©vPb Abyôvb Kiv—

Aby‡”Q` 141K ewY©Z cwiw¯’wZ‡Z iv÷ªcwZ †`‡k Ri“ix Ae¯’v Rvix Kwi‡Z cv‡ib| Z‡e Dnvi †gqv`Kvj 120 w`‡bi AwaK nB‡e bv|

Ri“ix ¶gZv wewagvjv, 2007

wewa 11(3), 19 (N), 19 (O) A‰ea †Nvlbv Kiv nBqv‡Q

msweavb  I AvB‡bi kvm‡bi †kªôZ¡ KLbB ¶zYè Kiv hvB‡ebv| 102 Aby‡”Q` Abyhvqx AvbxZ ixU gvgjvwU i¶Yxq—

GW‡fv‡KU myjZvbv Kvgvj Ges AviI 2 Rb ebvg evsjv‡`k Ms 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 105.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh —

Article 65(3) — Provision of Reserved seats for women in Parliament is not inconsistent with the basic constitutional scheme — Constitution (Fourteenth Amendment) Act, 2004 — Not violative of basic structure of the constitution —

RvZxq msm` (gwnjv Avmb msiw¶Z) AvBb,

2008 (Act No.30 of 2004)—

Held not violative of fundamental rights nor ultra-vires the constitution — The provisions of reserved seats for women in Parliament were contained in article 65(3) of the constitution from the very beginning. The constitution (Fourteenth Amendment) Act, 2004 did not introduce in the constitution any new concept and as such it did not change any basic structure of the constitution nor it is violative of fundamental rights. Act No.30 only provides for the procedure of election of women members in the Parliament to the reserved seats on the basis of proportional representation by a single vote and thus is not violative of fundamental rights nor it offends the basic structure of the constitution. Farida Akhter and others Vs. Bangladesh represented   by   the   Secretary   Cabinet    MLR (2009) (HC) 1. Division   and   others   11   MLR   (2006) (AD) 237.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 88 (e)— Decretal amount shall be paid from the consolidated fund but only after it is included in the annual financial statement of the appropriation bill—

Decretal dues is a charge against the consolidated fund. The decretal amount shall be paid from the consolidated fund only when the same is included in the annual financial statement of the appropriation bill placed in the Parliament. Bangladesh Bank represented by the Governor Vs. Mrs. Rana Awan and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 302.

 

evvsjv‡`k msweavbt

AvwU©‡Kj 93(1) Ges 58N- msm` Awa‡ek‡b bv _vKv Kvwjb mg‡q Avc`Kvjxb Ri“ix cÖ‡qvRb AÎ Aby‡”Q`vaxb ivóªcwZ†K kZ© mv‡c‡¶ Aa¨v‡`k Rvixi gva¨‡g AvBb cÖbq‡bi mxwgZ ¶gZv cÖ`vb Kiv nBqv‡Q—

Gvbbxq wePvicwZ g‡nv`q cÖ`Ë iv‡q D‡j­L Kwiqv‡Qb †h Zë¡veavqK miKv‡ii Avg‡j wbe©vPb msµvš— wekq, Av`vj‡Zi wb‡`©k ev †Kvb AZ¨vek¨Kxq Ri“ix welq e¨wZZ Ab¨ †Kvb wel‡q ivóªcwZi Aa¨v‡`k Rvixi gva¨‡g AvBb cÖbq‡bi mvsweavwbK †Kvb ¶gZv bvB| Zr†cÖw¶‡Z wZwb ZwK©Z Aa¨v‡`kwU msweav‡bi mwnZ mvsNwl©K nIqvq A‰ea Ges GlwZqvi ewnf©’Z ewjqv †Nvlbv K‡ib|

cxiRv`v ˆmq` kwiqZzj­vn Ms ebvg evsjv‡`k 14  MLR (2009) (HC) 1.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh — Article 102— High Court Division in a writ petition can not grant substantive relief while making an ex-parte interim order at the initial stage —

The apex court deprecated the practice of granting substantive relief at the initial stage of the proceeding while making interim order. In the instant case the High Court Division by an interim order pending the disposal of the writ petition granted all the substantive reliefs which rendered the proceedings redundant with nothing left for adjudication to the great detriment of the right of defence of the respondent. With strong disapproval to such practice the apex court setaside the impugned interim order. Chairman, Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation Vs. S.M. A.H. Imam and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 83.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh — Article 102- Adinterim order granting substantive   relief   in   writ   petition cannot be passed

Law is well settled that the High Court Division cannot grant entire relief sought in a writ petition while passing adinterim order. Agrani Bank and another Vs. Essential Garments ltd. and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 201.

 

Article 102— Writ petition does not lie against judgment and decree of Artha Rin Adalat—

As there is specific provision of appeal under section 41 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 Writ Petition under article 102 of the Constitution does not lie against judgment and decree of Artha Rin Adalat. Anisur Rahman @ K.M. Ziaitl Haque Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 75.

 

Article  102—  Writ  Petition  against judgment  and   decree   of  Artha   Rin Adalat is not maintainable—

Alternative efficacious remedy is available against the judgment and decree of the Artha Rin Adalat by way of appeal as provided under section 7 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain 1990 and as such Writ Petition under article 102 of the constitution does not lie against such judgment and decree. Therefore the law on this point is well settled. Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation (BADC) represented by Chairman Vs. Artha Rin Adalat, Court No. 3 Dhaka and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 308.

 

Article 102— Writ Petition does not lie  against  judgment  and  decree  of Artha Rin Adalat—

Section 7 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain 1990 provides for appeal against the judgment and decree of Artha Rin Adalat upon depositing 50% of the decretal amount. When the writ petitioner contested the suit by filing written statement and was aware of the suit but did not prefer any appeal and thereafter instituted Writ Petition which in the facts and circumstances is held by the apex court not maintainable. M/S Noor Crokaries and another Vs. Islam! Bank Bangladesh Ltd. and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 273.

 

Article 102— Article 117(2)— High Court Division's writ jurisdiction is ousted in respect of matters falling within the jurisdiction of Administrative Tribunals—

As provided under section 4 of the Administrative Tribunals Act, 1980 the Administrative Tribunals have been vested with exclusive jurisdiction to decide all disputes relating to the terms and conditions of a person in the service of the Republic or of the Statutory Authority. The jurisdiction of the High Court Division in such matters is ousted as contemplated under article 117(2) of the Constitution. However the High Court Division can exercise limited jurisdiction only when such matters involve question of determination of vires or constitutionality of any law or rules connected therewith. Merely because the Administrative Tribunal has no power to grant injunction or adinterim order, that does not confer jurisdiction upon the High Court Division to entertain writ petition in such matters. Khalilur Rahman ASP Vs. Md. Kamrul Ahsan and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 5.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Writ Petition does not lie  against  the  decree  of  Artha  Rin Adalat—

Against the decree of the Artha Rin Adalat the petitioner judgment debtor did not prefer appeal but filed the writ petition which having not been maintainable has been summarilv rejected by the High Court Division. The apex court upheld the decision of the High Court Division as one perfectly justified. Saifur Rahman Eman (Md.) Vs. Government of Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Local Govt. and Rural Development and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 190.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article  102—  Writ  Petition  is  not maintainable where there is alternative remedy by way of appeal—

Where the executive committee of the Voluntary Organisation was suspended/cancelled by the Registering Authority after proper inquiry as provided under section 9 of the Ordinance, 1961, the petitioner could seek the remedy thereagainst by way of appeal. Since alternative efficacious remedy is available the application under article 102 of the Constitution is held by the learned judges of the High Court Division not maintainable. Shuddhananda Mahathero Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Social Welfare and others 12 MLR (2007) (HO) 1.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Cancellation of bid on the  ground  of being  non-responsive not based on material  facts declared illegal—

The respondent No. 1 having fulfilled all the necessary requirements, such as technical, financial and professional was factually responsive. The cancellation of the bid of the respondent No 1 by the Review Panel terming the same as non-responsive without any material ground, has been declared by the High Court Division as illegal which the apex court held perfectly justified. St. Electronics (Infor Soft Ware System) Pvt, Ltd. Vs. Patimas International Sdn. Berhad and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 325.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Writ jurisdiction of the High Court Division cannot be invoked in respect of non-statutory contract—

Contracts which are not made in exercise of the sovereign functions of the Government are non-statutory contracts, the remedy for the breach thereof lies in a suit in the civil court but not in the writ jurisdiction of the High Court Division under article 102 of the Constitution. Managing Director WASA Vs. Md. AH and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 361.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Action of the Government in leasing out the Balu Mahal situated within Chundeecherra Tea Estate to a third party during the continuance of the lease is declared illegal—

The appellant took the lease of the Chundeecherra Tea Estate for a term of 35 years within which the disputed Balu Mahal is situated. The sands of the Balu Mahal which are used for construction purposes are held not minerals and as such the apex court declared the disputed lease of the said Balu Mahal illegal and of no legal effect. National Tea Company Limited Vs. Deputy Commissioner, Habiganj and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 189.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article  102-— Writ  petition  against judgment and decree passed in suit by Artha Rin Adalat is not maintainable—

Since there is specific provision of appeal to be preferred against judgment and decree of the Artha Rin Adalat within 30 (thirty) days of the passing thereof upon depositing 50% decretal dues, the writ petition thereagainst is held by the High Court Division as well as the Appellate Division, not maintainable. A.QM Shah Alam Chowdhury Vs. Government of Bangladesh represented by the Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 258.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Power of the Election Tribunal to pass order for recounting ballot papers—

It is well within the competence of the Election Tribunal to pass order for recounting of ballot papers for the purpose of proper adjudication of the dispute. S.M Fazlul Haque Manik Vs. Md. Habibulkh Baher and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 79.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— High Court Division has no power to negotiate price for the auctioned materials—

Evidence Act, 1872— Section 115— Estoppel— When it operates—

The High Court Division can not negotiate price of auction materials which is the exclusive domain of the Government. The writ petitioner upon accepting the auction price of some of the articles has taken delivery of those materials. Thereafter he can not raise objection against fresh auction of the remaining materials and as such he is barred by the principle of estoppel. M/S Ashrafand others Vs. Md. Zahangir Alam and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 87.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh—­Article 102— Maintainability of writ petition—

The apex court held the writ petition perfectly maintainable when the dispute involves interpretation of certain law, no disputed fact needs to be decided and   the   alternative   remedy   is   not efficacious. Commissioner of Customs, Customs House Benapole, ]essore Vs. Cab Express (BD) Limited and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 294.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Writ petition does not lie against the dismissal order of the Principal of recognised Non-Government Madrassa as the same is neither a statutory body nor a local authority—

In the instant case the dismissal order of the Principal of recognised Non-Government Madrassa was passed by the Upazilla Nirbahi Officer as the Chairman of the Governing body. The Madrassa is neither a statutory body nor a local authority and as such their lordships of the judges of the Appellate Division held writ petition does not lie against the impugned order of dismissal. Upazilla Nirbahi Officer Vs. Abu Saleh Md. Harunur Rashid and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 309.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— When no condition is mentioned in the lease order, the writ petitioner is not required to obtain clearance certificate from the Department of Environment—

As there was no terms and conditions in the lease order the High Court Division held the writ petitioner was not required to obtain clearance certificate from the Department of Environment. Appellate Division affirmed the decision of the High Court Division as perfectly justified. Bangladesh and others Vs. Serajuddin Khan 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 312.

 

Article 102— The power of the High Court Division under writ jurisdiction is limited. It can not exercise the power of appellate court in writ jurisdiction— The apex court firmly held that a fugitive in law and justice is not entitled to get the protection of law unless he surrenders in the proper court—

The writ petitioner was convicted and sentenced in a trial held in his absence. Instead of surrendering before the trial court he instituted the writ petition through his authorised agent which the High Court Division entertained and made conflicting orders from time to time with regard to his bail, stay of the operation of sentence, and the manner of surrendering before the proper court by violating the long established principles of law, norms and practice which the apex court deprecated and disapproved in strong words and directed the convict-writ petitioner to surrender before the trial court. Anti-Corruption Commission Vs. Dr. H.B.M Iqbal Alamgir and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 103.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Writ petition to protect the possession of the disputed flat is held maintainable—

' In the instant case the respondent No.5 having found unable to decide the title informed the writ petitioner that the title of the disputed flat can be decided by a civil court of competent jurisdiction. Thereafter the respondent No. 6 issued the impugned letter to the petitioner directing her to vacate the possession of the said flat. The High Court Division as well as the Appellate Division held the impugned letter passed without any lawful authority. Shaid Ha mid and another Vs. Nilufar Moml-nz and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 130.

 

Article 102— Disputed question of facts as to title cannot be decided in writ jurisdiction—

In the instant case the identity of the disputed land is challenged which can not be ascertained without relayment by a survey knowing advocate commissioner  and  as  such  the writ petition is held not maintainable. Sum jit Bose (Raju) Vs. Bangladesh and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 206.

 

Article 102— Writ petition is held not maintainable against stay of all actions for registration of two buses purchased by the loan of the bank—

The impugned action of BRTA croped up out of the proceedings relating to suit for recovery of loan. The High Court Division held the writ petition not maintainable. The Appellate" Division also concurred with the impugned decision of the High Court Division. Monir Hossain Vs. The Artha Rin Adalat No. 4, Dhaka and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 236.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Writ petition for giving direction to pay an unascertained amount of money is not maintainable-Writ petition for giving direction to pay an ascertained amount of money is maintainable. But the writ petition is not maintainable when the amount is unascertained. In the instant case the High Court Division directed to settle the pending bills. The Appellate Division found nothing wrong with the impugned order and as such dismissed the leave petition. Bangladesh Water Development Board (BWDB), represented by its Director General, WAPDA Bhaban and another Vs. Golam Rabbani Khan and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 402.

 

Article   102—   Right   of   legitimate expectation—

When the Chief of the Administration and the Ministries concerned j recommended for transfer of 160 posts of the project under the revenue budget I but the Ministry of Finance transferred 1 only 118 posts to the revenue budget. As I the remaining 42  posts stand  on  the same footings the legitimate expectation of the petitioners has become lawful right to be treated in the same manner. Government of Bangladesh and others Vs. Md. Shahinoor Bari and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 424.

 

Article 102— Writ petition against private institution is not maintainable—

Law is clear that writ jurisdiction can not   be   invoked   against   a   private institution not established by any law. In the   instant   case   the   writ   petition I instituted against the Governing Body of  the Bangladesh Rifles School and College being a non-government institution is held not maintainable. The apex court disposed of the appeal with the observation that the decision of the Education Board is binding upon the appellant school and college and accordingly directed, to reinstate the respondent to his job. Chairman, Governing Body, Bangladesh Rifles School and College and others Vs. Md. Golam Kibria and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 497.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article  102— Writ petition seeking direction to the appellants to execute and register the lease deed—

The respondent Samabaya Samity was granted lease of the disputed land for construction of Hawkers Market by a letter granting lease for 30 years. The respondent accordingly paid the entire salami for the lease and was given delivery of possession thereof. But when the lease deed was in the process of execution and registration, the appellant by the impugned letter stopped the process. In the writ petition instituted there-against the High Court Division directed the appellant to execute and register the deed for permanent lease. The apex court found nothing wrong with the impugned order except the period of lease and disposed of the appeal with the modification of the direction instead of permanent lease, for the period of 30 years for which the lease was granted. Secretary Ministry of Land, Government of Bangladesh and others Vs. Hazrat Baku Shah Hawkers Market Samabaya Samity 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 505.

 

Article 102 and 109— Extra ordinary power of the High Court Division of judicial review—

Under article 102 High Court Division is invested with power of judicial review of certain orders against which there is no provision of appeal or revision. Power of High Court Division under article 109 is of administrative nature. The apex court held the power of High Court Division under article 102 of the Constitution can not be taken away or curtailed by subordinate legislation i.e. the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 and as such the writ petition against interlocutory order passed by Artha Rin Adalat is held quite maintainable. Hanin-or Rashia (Md.) Vs. Piihali Bank Ltd. and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 343.

 

Article 102—Orders reducing the pay scale after long enjoyment without  affording opportunity of showing cause is violative of the principle of natural justice—

Petitioner was duly appointed with the pay scale which he enjoyed for long time thereby acquiring a vested right. The sudden reduction in the pay scale into the consolidated lower amount without affording an opportunity of showing cause is illegal and void as being one violative of the principle of natural justice and as such is declared by the High Court Division to have been passed without any lawful authority and is of no legal effect. Abdur Razzak (Md.) Vs. Bangladesh Represented by the Secretary Ministry of Agriculture and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 57.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh — Article 102- Respondent government officials are duty bound to hand over vacant possession of lease hold land to the petitioner-lessee when the entire lease money were paid long ago-Writ petitioner is legally entitled to get the vacant possession of the lease hold land for which the entire lease money were paid long ago. The petitioner paid extra amount for rehabilitation of the unauthorised occupants on humanitarian ground. The respondents are duty bound to handover vacant possession of the remaining part of the leased land after evicting the illegal occupiers as per provisions of Ordinance No. 24 of 1970. Since the district administration failed to perform their duty as required by law the High Court Division directed them to hand over the vacant possession of the said land within 60 days after evicting the illegal occupiers therefrom. Delta Jute Mills. Ltd. Vs. The Deputy Commissioner, Noakhali and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 89.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Maintainability of writ petition against transfer order of worker on ground of union activities— Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969— Section 47-B— Protection against transfer of worker for trade union activities.

Employment of Labour (Standing Orders) Act, 1960—

Section 25— Grievance against termination of service—

Section 47-B of the Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1965 provides protection of a worker against transfer on ground of trade union activities. When the writ petitioner was singled out and was transferred on ground of union activities, and the High Court Division stayed the operation of the transfer order, and the respondent in violation of the stay order terminated his service which the learned judges held to be malafide and declared both the transfer order and the termination order as illegal and passed without any lawful authority. It is further held that the alternative remedy in the labour court being not efficacious the writ petition is quite maintainable, Faruque Hasan Vs. Titns Gas Transmission and Distribution Company ltd. and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 220.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Writ petition for giving direction to comply with the judgment of another writ petition—

When the respondent did not prefer appeal before the Appellate Division against the judgment of the High Court Division passed in a Writ petition, the same remains binding upon the respondent who is bound to comply with the direction. When the respondents were not complying with the said judgment the learned judges of the High Court Division directed the respondents to hand over the possession of the disputed property to the writ petitioner in a subsequent writ petition. Golam Mostafa (Mohd.) and another Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary Ministry of Housing and Public Works and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 320.

 

Article 102— Private college is not amenable to the writ jurisdiction of the High Court Division—

Private college is not a functionary of the Government, nor it is a stutory body nor a local authority and as such an employee of such college can not invoke writ jurisdiction of the High Court-Division. The application under article 102 of the Constitution is thus held not maintainable. Firozn Begum Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 142.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— A convict petitioner tried in absentia who did not prefer appeal can not invoke writ jurisdiction of the High Court Division for setting aside his conviction and sentence—

When the convict-petitioner was convicted and sentenced under section 4(b)(c) of the Cruelty to (Determent Punishment) Ordinance, 1983 in a trial held in his absence and the trial was held after compliance with all the legal requirements againt which he did not prefer appeal, he can not invoke writ jurisdiction of the Piigh Court Division to set aside the conviction and sentence. Anisur Khan @ Anisnr Idris Khan Vs. Special Tribunal No. 2 Bnrisal and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 144.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Maintainability of Writ Petition against dismissal from service on ground of limitation in seeking relief in the Administrative Tribunal—

When the petitioners who were initially appointed as contingent staff were brought under the revenue establishment and were given the status and privileges of permanent Government servants in which capacity they served for more than 10 years enjoying all the privileges and acquired vested rights which can not be taken away arbitrarily by saying after so long time that their regularisations were not in accordance with law and rules. Moreover the impugned orders were violative of the principle of natural justice as the same were passed without affording any opportunity to the petitioners of being heard. Kazimuddin (Md.) and 14 others Vs. Government of Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Information and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 249.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh-Article  102— Scope of interference with   arbitrary   action   of   the   state functionaries    by    the    High    Court

Division — The High Court Division can well look into    the   propriety   of   orders   and scrutinise that the stale functionaries act fairly and inaccordance with law. The petitioner was appointed Deputy Chief Accountant of Chittagong VVASA pursuant to an advertisement with the pay scale mentioned therein. His pay scale was upgraded from time to time and he enjoyed the benefit thereof for more than 15 years whereby he acquired vested right which can not be taken away arbitrarily. The authority can not reduce his pay scale after such a long time on the ground of non-entitlement without affording an opportunity of being heard. The impugned order being arbitrary and violative of the principle of natural justice the learned judges struck clown the same as one passed without any lawful authority and of no legal effect. Serajiil Azim Khan Vs. Government of Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of LGRD and Co-operatives and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 257.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh—

Article 102— High Court Division is required to see whether the statutory authority acted fairly and in accordance with law— Bangladesh Sheikh Mujib Medical University Act, 1998—

Section 5— Provides for the procedure of appointing teacher after the approval of the Syndicate on the recommendation of the selection committee— Appointment of respondent No 6 as Professor of Neuro Surgery without the approval of the Syndicate and having been made in violation of the set criteria and provision of law has been declared illegal and made without any lawful authority. Dr. Kanak Kanti Banui Vs. B'dngWandfni Sheikh Mnjib Medical University and other 12 MLR (2007) (HO 334.

 

Article 102— High Court Division can well scrutinise the acts of the State-Functionaries as to whether done fairly and in accordance with law and practice— Legal position of legitimate expectation explained—

Legitimate expectation though does not create any enforceable legal right, the court can see that the . state-functionaries must act consistently within the norms of standard practice and in accordance with law and-can direct to refrain from arbitrary action. Sirajul Islam (Md.) others Vs. Bangladesh and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 344.

 

Article  102— Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation (BADC) is a statutory body and writ jurisdiction  can  well  be  invoked  in respect of disputes as to the terms and conditions  of service of its employees-Industrial  Relations  Ordinance, 1969—

Section 34— Employee of BADC is not worker within the meaning of Shops and Establishments and as such Labour Court has no jurisdiction to entertain any dispute relating to employee of BADC Suspension of an employee for long time without drawing up proceedings is held to be illegal and the period of suspension is declared to be. on duty with the entitlement of all the arrear pays and allowances admissible under rules. Transfer of an employee during suspension is held to be illegal. Labour Court has no jurisdiction to decide dispute of employees of BADC and as such its judgment and'order are declared illegal and of no legal effect. Bangladesh Agricultural DevelopmenI Corporation Vs. Chairman 2nd Labour Court and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 401.

 

Article 102— State functionaries however high or low are equal before law and are bound to perform their duties and responsibilities as required under law—

Honourable Members of the Parliament who duly received the allowance for the use of telephone from he public exchequer can not avoid the payment of the outstanding telephone bills over the years. The state functionaries are bound to take appropriate steps for realisation of those outstanding bills failure of which would amount to dereliction of duty on their part. Bangladesh Legal Aid and Services Trust (BLAST) Vs. Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Post and telecommunications and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 233.

 

Article 102 — Writ petition is maintainable when the alternative remedy is not equally efficacious and where the question of law and interpretation of statute is raised —

Government of Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Law, justice and Parliamentary Affairs and others Vs. Iqbal Hasan Mahmood alias Iqbal Hasan Mahmood Tnkn 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 333.

Ievq`yj Mwb ebvg evsjv‡`k miKvi 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 128.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh — Article 102 — Writ jurisdiction can not be invoked where alternative remedy is available —

Bankruptcy Act, 1997 —                                                  

Section 96 — Provides for appeal against judgment and order passed by Bankruptcy Court —

Section 96 of the Bankruptcy Act, 1997 provides for appeal against judgment and order of the Bankruptcy Court which is the alternative remedy. In that view of the matter the impugned order passed by the Bankruptcy court can not be challenged in writ jurisdiction. The writ ' petition having been not maintainable the rule is charged. Mosammat Momina Begum Vs. Additional District judge, Bankruptcy Court, Dhaka and others 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 29.

 

Article 102—

Inter-ministerial correspondence which have no force of law, can not be enforced in writ jurisdiction. Disputed question of fact cannot be decided by the writ court. AminiilJah (Md.) Advocate and another Vs. Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Land and others 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 264.

 

Article 102— Writ jurisdiction can not be invoked to challenge the judgment and decree of Bankruptcy court—

It is well settled that writ petition does not lie against the judgment and decree where there are specific provision of law for appeal thereagainst. Moreover disputed question of fact can not be decided in writ jurisdiction. In that view of the matter the learned judges of the High Court Division held the writ petition not maintainable as section 96 of the Bankruptcy Act, 1997 provides for appeal against the impugned judgment and decree. Niaz Mahnnid (Mir) Vs. Additional District Judge and Bankruptcy Court, Dhaka and others 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 314.

 

Article    102—    Power    to    direct restoration of custody of minor— Family Courts Ordinance, 1985— Section 5— Custody of minor— Best welfare   of   the   child   shall   be   the paramount consideration— According to the Mohamedan Law and also the Guardian and Wards Act, 1890, the father is entitled to the custody of minor son after he has attained the age of 7(seven) years. But this 7 years factor as held, is not the only criteria to determine the custody of a minor boy. It has now been consistently held by the apex courts, that in deciding the custody of the minor boy the seven years age factor shall not be the only criteria. The welfare and best interest of the child shall be the paramount consideration. In that view of the matter the learned judges of the High Court Division directed the boy though aged 10 years to be restored to the custody of the mother during the pendency of the Family Court Suit. Z,ahii1a Ahmed (Liza) Vs. Si/ed Nooruddin Ahmed and another 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 465.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Writ petition against the judgment and decree of Artha Rin Adalat is not maintainable—

There are specific provisions of law for appeal against the judgment, decree or order of the Artha Rin Adalat and as such the writ petition thereagainst is not maintainable. Recommendation of the Cabinet Committee is neither a lav/ nor has the force of law and thus is not enforceable in writ jurisdiction. Edruk Ltd. Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Industries and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 16.

 

Constitution of Aiticle 102— Writ petitions in the fads and c ire li ms lances are hetd maintainable

In the instant eases the Eire arms licence of the writ pe fill oners were csincalled without any show cause notice and for doing any act prejudicial to peace and law order situation. The impugned orders abuse of Ihe power and viola live of the principle1 of nntmal justice are dechred illegal and passed without any taw Fi.il oiithoiity. AK M manjurul Haque and others Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 246.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Arlicle   102 — Writ  petition  of the retired Air Marshal is held maintainable — the promotion of the writ petitioner as Air Marsh made 3 ½ years back  is presumed to be correct and to have been made in accordance, with law. There being no reasonable ground the learned judges declared the impugned order of cancellation illegal and passed without any lawful authority.

Gqvi gvk©vj Rvgvj DwÏb Avn†¤§` (Aet) ebvg evsjv‡`k Ms ( 15 MLR (2010) (HO 233.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh — Article 102 — A person not can not invoke writ juifsdiction —

A^iTini Uank inJiodtK.od c./ir Jo,in scheme for its senior officials for piomotmg its busiiiost;. The writ petitioner has no interest in the matter and as such is no) an person not entitled writ Jurisdiction. Moujur- Miirshed  (Mil.)   15 MLR  (20W).

 

Writ jurisdiction  can   be invoked where there alternative remedy —

En hip instant cvi&L1 the learned judges of the 1 fifth Court Division held thus writ petitioner being the retired government servants can ventilate their grievance before the Administrative Tribunal. Since there is alternative remedy the writ petition is held not maintainable. Matiur Rahman Khan, Retired Store Officer, Government Motor Vehicles Workshop, Dhaka and another Vs. Government of Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Establishment, Secretariat Building, Ramna, Dhaka and others 15 MLR (2020) (HC) 307.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Scope of interference in exercise of writ jurisdiction—

State Acquisition and Tenancy Rules, 1955— Rule 31— Repeated appeals one after another after the disposal on merit of the first one is not maintainable—

In this case some of the writ respondents filed appeals under rule 31 of the Tenancy Rules, 1955 in respect of preparation of record of rights repeatedly one after another, after the disposal of the first one on merit which the Settlement officer entertained. The learned judges of the High Court Division held such practice is not permissible in law. If any party is dissatisfied with the decision he can seek remedy in the civil court but he cannot file appeals one after another on the same matter between the same parties. Azmiri Begum (Most) and others Vs. Government of Bangladesh, Ministn/ of Land, represented by its Secretary and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 400.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh—Article 102— Fugitive from justice has no right to seek remedy against his conviction and sentence before he surrenders in the court concerned—

Law is well settled and it is an age-old practice in the courts in this sub­continent that a fugitive from justice is not entitled to seek any remedy against his conviction and sentence before he surrenders in the court which passed the order of conviction and sentence. The learned judges of the High Court Division found the writ petition ex-facie not maintainable and accordingly discharged the rule. Nazmn Sarwar and otliers Vs. Government of Bangladesh, Ministn/ of Home Affairs, represented by its Secretary and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 412.

 

Article 102(l)(2)(b)(i)—Law in conflict  with  the  constitution    is declared ultra vires— Nari-O-Shishu Nirj atari (Bishesh Bidhan) Ain, 1995—

Section 6(2)— Mandatory sentence curtails the discretion of the judge-Section 6(2) of the Nari-O-Shishu Nirjatan (Bishesh Bidhan) Ain, 1995 prescribed the mandatory sentence of death which curtails the discretion of the judge and makes the judge a rubberstamp. The judge is precluded from exercising his discretion about the surrendering circximstances and the antecedents of the accused. This provision is against the UN Declaration of Human Rights. The state signatory is under the obligation to implement the international covenants. Though the Act of 1995 has been repealed but by the saving clause contained in section 34 of the new Act, the issue is kept alive. Considering all the aspects and having regard to the constitutional provisions the learned judges declared section 6(2) of the Nari-O-Shishu Nirjatan (Bishesh Bidhan) Ain, 1995 ultra vires of the constitution. Bangladesh Legal Aid and Services Trust (BLAST)   and  another   Vs.   Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 145.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102(2)— In a writ of quo warranto any conscious citizen can challenge the propriety of appointment to the highest executive post of the Ministry— "Current Charge" and "in-charge" are two different things—

As provided by the Judicial Service Rules 2002 the post of the Secretary of the Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs has to be filled in by promotion from amongst the senior most members of the Judicial Cadre Service. Respondent No. 5 who is a member of non-cadre service of the legislative drafting wing and who is not eligible has been promoted as the Secretary in-charge of the Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs by violating the mandate of the Judicial Service Rules, 2002 and the opinion of the Supreme Court. The learned judges of the High Court Division having found the impugned appointment and promotion of the respondent No. 5 illegal, declared the same to have been made without any lawful authority and of no legal effect. The learned judges further directed an enquiry to be made as to the conduct of the learned Registrar of the Supreme Court who conveyed the desire of the Supreme Court in respect of the said appointment .though the Supreme Court can not express any such desire for any body's appointment to any particular post. Altab Uddin (Md.) Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 13 MLR (2008), (EC) 105.

 

Article 102 and 117— When the vires of an order passed under the authority of the President is challenged together with the enforcibility of the equality clause of article 27, the jurisdiction of the High Court Division can well be invoked under article 102—

Administrative Tribunal cannot decide constitutionality of an order passed under the authority of the President which has the effect of law and cannot enforce fundamental rights. In that view of the matter the writ petition in the instant case has been held by the apex court perfectly maintainable. Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Finance and others Vs. Md. Shamsul Huq 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 25.

 

Article 102 and 117— Administrative Tribunals have exclusive jurisdiction to decide dispute relating to the terms and condition of a person in the service of the Republic. But when the wrong complained of is inextricably mixed with the question of fundamental rights writ jurisdiction of the High Court Division can well be invoked to prevent injustice—

Though the Administrative Tribunals have exclusive jurisdiction to decide dispute relating to service terms and conditions of a person in the service of the Republic, the High Court Division can well exercise its writ jurisdiction in matters of the wrong complained of when the same involves inextricably the question of violation of'equality clause of fundamental rights with a view to preventing injustice and securing equal protection of law. Government of Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Finance and others Vs. Md. Abdur Rashid and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 47.

 

Article 105— Review of judgment— Review does not mean to reopen the matter   for   rehearing—   When   the grounds      agitated were already answered in the judgment, there is no scope to review the same— Income Tax Ordinance, 1984— Section 29(1)(XXVII)— Payment  of zakat by Bank on behalf of the account-

holders does not fall within the ambit of section 29(1)(XXVII)- As ordained by the divine revelations, to pay zakat is the individual liability of a Muslim having possession of certain wealth. Islami Bank can not collect zakat and make payment thereof on behalf of the account-holders and thus such payment is not exempted from the liability of paying tax under section 29(1)(XXVII) of the Income Tax Ordinance. Islami Bank Bangladesli Ltd. Vs. Commissioner of Taxes 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 337.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 105— Review of judgment—

The Appellate Division set aside the auction sale and directed to invite fresh tender after wide publicity to secure the ends of justice and held public interest shall prevail over individual interest. As there is no substance, the review petition is dismissed. Mahmudul Huq Vs. Mostafa Karnal and otters 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 431.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh-Article   116—    Power   of   posting, promotion and disciplinary actions in respect of judicial officers are to be exercised by the President in consultation with the Supreme Court— Consultation with the Supreme Court means the consultation with the Full Court comprising the Chief Justice and all the judges of the High Court Division. General Administration Committee is not the substitute of the Full Court as such the proposal for placing the writ petitioner under suspension and initiation of disciplinary proceedings against him having not been placed before the Full Court for approval are held by the learned judges of the High Court Division to have been made without any lawful authority and of no legal effect. The learned judges further held that the principle of resjudicata as contemplated under section 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure is not applicable to the writ jurisdiction of the High Court Division. Sontosh Kumar Shaha Senior Assistant JiLdge Vs. Government of Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs and otters 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 373.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 122(2)- Provides for securing the rights of a citizen by enlistment in the Electoral Roll-Electoral Rolls Ordinance, 1982— Section 7~ Provides for maintaining continuity of electoral rolls— Electoral Rolls Rules, 1982— Rule 20- up-dating the voter lists by correction and modification-Preparation   and   up-dating   of   the voters   list   before   the   Parliamentary election   is   the   responsibility   of  the Election Commission.  Decision of the Election Commission means the decision taken by all the commissioners or by the majority of them. The Commission can not discard or ignore altogether the existing voters list but is required to up­date the same by correction and modification on the basis of the existing lists as contemplated under section 7 of the Electoral Rolls Ordinance 1982 and rule 20 of the Electoral Rolls Rules 1982. Election Commission represented by the Chief Election Commissioner Vs. Alhaj Advocate Molmimnad Rahmnt All, MP and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 345.

 

Article 135— Public servant is protected under the article to the effect that he cannot be dismissed or removed from service by an authority lower than his appointing authority—

The law is well settled that a public servant can not be dismissed or removed or reduced in rank by a person lower in rank of his appointing authority as provided under article 135 of the constitution. The delegated authority had no power to dismiss the Writ petitioner which is held by the learned judges of the High Court Division as illegal. Altafur Rahman Talukder (Md.) Vs. Rivet-Research Institute represented by Director General 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 279.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article  140— Prescribes  the  power and  functions  of the  Public  Service Commission—

Public Service Commission has to perform its function fairly, impartially and strictly in accordance with law while recommending persons for appointment in the service of the Republic. It is well settled that the Public Service Commission cannot make recommendation of persons for appointment to the posts more than that is advertised except in case of emergency or exceptional circumstance. Public Service Commission can not make recommendation for appointment to the posts more than those advertised in the running process on the basis of subsequent requisition of the requiring body. The learned judges of the High Court Division found the impugned recommendations illegal and as such declared the same to have passed without any lawful authority and of no legal effect. Mohibnr Rahman (Dr. ) and others Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 15 MLR (2070) (HO 359.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh—

Article 141C(D— Declaration of emergency by the President suspending the enforcement of fundamental rights is not subject of scrutiny by the court—

The Appellate Division held the High Court Division was wrong in disposing of the writ petitions seeking enforcement of fundamental rights during the continuance of the emergency when the fundamental rights were suspended. Declaration of emergency does not come within the scope of scrutiny by the court. The apex court held the Rule 8(l)(dd) of the Bangladesh Civil Service (Recruitment) Rules, 1981 not ultravires of the constitution nor discriminatory or class legislation. Ataur Rahman (Md.) and others Vs. B.M Mahibur Rahman and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 138.

2870

Contract Act, 1872

Citation: 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 241, 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 65, 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 149, 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 153, 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 185, 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 253

Case Year: 1872

Subject: Contract Act

Delivery Date: 2018-03-13

Contract Act, 1872

 

Section 23— Agreement opposed to law is void—

In a case of eviction of tenant under the Premises Rent Control Act, 1991 on ground of bonafide requirement, the choice is with the land lord as to which of the several shops let out he/she requires for his/her use and occupation. Advance payment in excess of one month's rent and an agreement as to non-ejectability of tenant on ground of taking advance being opposed to the provisions of section 10 of the Premises Rent Control Act, 1991 and section 23 of the Contract Act, 1872 are void and can not defeat the ejectment of tenant as provided under the law. Jahanara Khatun (Most.) Vs. Md. Nurul Mam 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 241.

 

Section 23— Agreement opposed to public policy is void—

The Bangladesh Telecommunication Regulatory Commission (BTRC) is empowered under sections 89 and 90 of the Bangladesh Telecommunications Act, 2001 to amend any condition of licence or licence agreement which are inconsistent with the provisions of the Act. The co-exclusivity agreement of the World Tel for 4 years in the Dhaka Multi-Exchange area in disregard of the huge unmet demand of the customers having been found opposed to public interest has been cancelled by the BTRC in exercise of its power under the law. The High Court Division upon scrutiny of the relevant provisions of the law held the impugned order of cancellation perfectly justified. The Appellate Division having found nothing wrong in the findings and decision upheld the judgment and order of the High Court Division and dismissed the civil petition for leave to appeal. World Tel Bangladesh Ltd. Vs. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary Ministry of Post and Telecommunications and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 65.

 

Section   73—   Suit   for  damage   or compensation for breach of contract—

The terms and conditions of service of the petitioner are governed by the appointment which is in fact a contract. The relationship between the petitioner and the defendant is that of a master and servent for the termination of which without showcause notice the plaintiff petitioner is entitled to realize compensation in terms of his appointment. Alimuzzainan Khan (Md.) Vs. Mohammad Golam Kibria 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 149.

 

Section 73— Counter claim based on remote and indirect consequence is not admissible—

The dispute in the instant case was referred to a three-member arbitration tribunal which made the impugned award. The third member gave a dissenting note as he was not given the -opportunity of participation in the deliberation. The Arbitration Tribunal did not allow the counter claim based on remote and indirect consequences as provided under section 73 of the Contract Act, 1872 with which the apex court concurred, but held that in order to be sustainable the award must be by majority upon participation of all the members of the tribunal which is the requirement of law. As the impugned award has not been passed in accordance with law and is opposed to public policy the High Court Division set-aside the same which the Appellate Division upheld. Saudi Arabian Air Lines Corporation, represented by its Conn try Manager Vs. M/S Saudi Bangladesh Services Company Ltd, represented by its Managing Director 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 153.

 

Section  73—  Not  attracted   in  the instant case—

The appellant claimed compensation on account of delay in completion of the project. The Arbitration Tribunal did not allow compensation on account of the delay. The District Judge refused to set aside the award as there was no such ground as enumerated under section 43 of the Arbitration Act, 2001. The High Court Division held section 73 of the Contract Act, 1872 is not attracted in the instant case. It is further held arbitral award can only be set aside when it is opposed to law and public policy, excessive, malafide and not based on materials on record. As the arbitral award does not suffer from any infirmity the learned judges of the High Court Division dismissed the appeal. Bangladesh Power Development Board and others Vs. M/s Arab Contractors (BD) Ltd. and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 185.

 

Section 74— Forfeiture of earnest money in a contract for sale of property by auction sale on failure to deposit the consideration/bid money within stipulated time—

In a process of sale of property by auction the contract becomes absolute upon the acceptance of the offer and as such the purchaser is bound to make the payment of consideration money as per stipulation of contract and on the failure of the purchaser to pay the consideration money within the specified time, the seller can well forfeit the earnest money for breach of the contract. Mesbahiiddin  Ahmed   Vs.   M/S  nines Finlay 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 253.

2871

Cooperative Societies Act, 2001

Citation: MLR (2009) (AD) 34
