Case Year: 2001

Subject: Cooperative Societies Act

Delivery Date: 2018-03-14

Cooperative Societies Act, 2001

mge¨q mwgwZ AvBb, 2001

 

Section 22 — Suspension of Elected Managing Committee without any show cause notice is illegal-

Suspension of the elected Managing Committee of the Cooperative Society without affording any opportunity of hearing being violative of the principle of natural justice is held by the apex court illegal and the constitution of the Ad-hoc Committee of no legal effect.

 

S.M. Ddwar Hossnin and others Vs. Government of Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Local Government, Rural Development and Cooperatives and others MLR (2009) (AD) 34.

2872

Court Fees Act, 1870

Citation: 16 BLD (HCD) 195, 18 BLD(HCD)269

Subject: Court Fees

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 

 

Court Fees Act, 1870

(VII OF 1870)

 

Section—7(VI-A)

Article—17 (VA) of Schedule II

A simple suit for partition is to be filed with a fixed court fee under Article 17 (VA) of schedule II of the Court Fees Act when the plaintiff asserts that he is in possession of the suit property. But when a suit is filed for partition and for recovery of possession then he is required to pay advalorem court fee on the value of his share of the suit property under Section 7 (VT-A) of the Court Fees Act. Even if the plaintiff claims to be in possession of his share of the suit property but he prays for declaration of his title and partition then also he is required to pay advalorem court-fee on the value of his share of the suit property under Section 7 (IV) (C) of the Court-Fees Act.

Mahmudul Huq and others Vs Nowab Au Chowdhury and ors, 16 BLD (HCD) 195.

 

Sections—7(XI), 8C and 8D

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, Order VII Rule 10

Return of Plaint

Section 7(XI) of the Court-Fees Act provides an objective standard for valuation of a suit for eviction of a monthly tenant by the landlord. In such a case, the subjective satisfaction of the plaintiff is of no avail.

Under Order VII Rule 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure the Court may return a plaint to the filing Advocate when it finds that he has no jurisdiction, either pecuniary or otherwise, to entertain and try the suit. A plaint cannot be returned on the ground of incorrect valuation of the suit or for want of adequate court fees. If it appears that the suit has not been properly valued and sufficiently stamped, the Court is required to make an enquiry either by himself or by any other person appointed by him on that behalf to determine the correct valuation of the suit in terms of sections 8C and 8D of the Court Fees Act, The learned Assistant Judge clearly erred in law in returning the plaint to the filing Advocate ignoring the express provisions of law regulating the return of the plaint and the valuation of the suit.

Didar ali  and others Vs. Naziur Rahman, 18 BLD(HCD)269

Ref: 19DLR287(Special Bench)—Cited

 

2873

Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1958

Citation: 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 103

Case Year: 1958

Subject: Criminal Law Amendment

Delivery Date: 2018-03-14

Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1958

 

Section 10— Provides for alternative remedy by way of appeal—

Constitution of Bangladesh—

Article 102— The power of the High Court Division under writ jurisdiction is limited. It can not exercise the power of appellate court in writ jurisdiction—

The apex court firmly held that a fugitive in law and justice is not entitled to get the protection of law unless he surrenders in the proper court—

The writ petitioner was convicted and sentenced in a trial held in his absence. Instead of surrendering before the trial court he instituted the writ petition through his authorised agent which the High Court Division entertained and made conflicting orders from time to time with regard to his bail, stay of the operation of sentence, and the manner of surrendering before the proper court by violating the long established principles of law, norms and practice which the apex court deprecated and disapproved in strong words and directed the convict-writ petitioner to surrender before the trial court. Anti-Corruption Commission Vs. Dr. H.BM Iqbal Alamgir and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 103.

2874

Customs Act, 1969

Citation: 5 MLR (2010) (AD) 227, 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 290, 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 211, 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 437, 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 294

Case Year: 1969

Subject: Customs Act

Delivery Date: 2018-03-14

Customs Act, 1969

 

Section 25— Assessment of customs duty and VAT on the basis of the S.R.O operative at the time of opening the letter of credit—

In the instant case the High Court Division held the writ petitioners are entitled to assessment of custom duty and VAT for the imported good of secondary quality as per the S.R.O in force at the time of opening the letter of credits. The Appellate Division up held the impugned decision and dismissed the appeals. Mainmunal Islam and others Vs. The Collector of Customs and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 227.

 

Section 25 and 30— Importer does not acquire any vested right under S.R.O prevalent at the time of opening the letter of credit—

The apex court held the importer did not acquire vested right under the S.R.O in force at the time of opening the letter of credit as to assessment of the customs duty on imported goods. It is further held that the customs authority was perfectly justified in assessing the duty on the tariff value as per the subsequent S.R.O prevalent at the time the bill of entry was presented. Collector of Customs, Customs House Chittagong and others Vs. M/S Sumi Enterprise 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 290.

 

Section 25B— Assessment of customs duty and other charges on the yellow book value of the imported reconditioned vehicles—

Consequent upon exclusion of pre-shipment requirement, the apex court held in a number of cases consistently that the assessment of customs duty of the imported reconditioned vehicle shall be made on the basis of the yellow book value. Monzurul Islam (Md.) Vs. National Board of Revenue and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 211.

 

Section  30(b)—  Assessment of custom duties on the goods imported under letter of credit-Law is well settled that the custom duties on the goods imported under letter of credit shall be assessed on the basis of the rate prevalent on the date the bill of entry is presented before the customs authority—

In the instant case the custom duty was assessed at the rate of 5% although on the date the bill of entry was presented the duty on the goods in question was 0%. The learned judges of the High Court Division having regard to the settled principle of law declared the impugned assessment illegal and of no legal effect.] Shnbnnni Vegetable Oil Industries Ltd, Chittagong Vs. Commissioner of Custom (Import), Chittagong and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 437.

 

Section 193— not a bar to invoke writ jurisdiction—

Constitution of Bangladesh— Article 102— Maintainability of writ petition—

The apex court held the writ petition perfectly maintainable when the dispute involves interpretation of certain law, no disputed fact needs to be decided and the alternative remedy is not efficacious. Commissioner of Customs, Customs House Benapolc, ]e.ssore Vs. Cab Express (ED) Limited and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 294.

2875

Defence of Pakistan Rules, 1965

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 261

Case Year: 1965

Subject: Defence of Pakistan Rules

Delivery Date: 2018-03-14

Defence of Pakistan Rules, 1965

 

Enlistment of enemy/vested property after 16th February, 1969 is invalid— The Defence of Pakistan Rules, 1965 was repealed on 16th February 1969 and as such thereafter no property could be enlisted afresh as enemy property. Moreover when it is found that the owner of the property never left the country before 16th February, 1969 there was no reason to include his property in the enemy property list. When the Magistrate was not examined by the Court his enquiry report was not admissible in evidence. Abdul Majid Moll a Vs. Biswnjit Chandra (Minor) and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 261.

2876

Dhaka City Corporation Ordinance, 1983

Citation: 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 256

Case Year: 1983

Subject: Dhaka City Corporation

Delivery Date: 2018-03-14

 

Dhaka City Corporation Ordinance, 1983

we‡iva wggvsmv ( †cŠi GjvKv) AvBb 2004

 

The we‡iva wggvsmv ( †cŠi GjvKv) AvBb 2004 does not apply to the city corporation area. Moreover there is no provision in the Dhaka City Corporation Ordinance, 1983 empowering the Ward Commissioner to decide the land dispute. Having regard to the position of law the learned judges of the High Court Division declared the impugned decision given by the Ward Commissioner in land dispute as illegal and passed without jurisdiction and lawful authority.

 

Faroque Reza Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 256.

2877

Disturbed Persons Rehabilitation Ordinance, 1964

Citation: 15 MLR (2020) (AD) 1

Case Year: 1964

Subject: Disturbed Persons Rehabilitation

Delivery Date: 2018-03-14

Disturbed Persons Rehabilitation Ordinance, 1964

(Ord No.l of 1964)

 

Sections 4, 6 and 6A— Declared ultravires the Constitution— The Ordinance No.l died a natural death on the expiry of certain period—

Since sections 4, 6 and 6A of the Ordinance No.l of 1964 were declared ultravires of the Constitution in Chitta Ranjan Sutar's case, the purported forfeiture of the suit land was void abinitio and the settlement given pursuant thereof was invalid. Mohiuddin Khan and others Vs. Shihamul Haque being dead his heirs Hasina @ lla Begum and others '15 MLR (2020) (AD) 1.

 

2878

Easement Act, 1882

Citation: 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 242, 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 89

Case Year: 1882

Subject: Easement

Delivery Date: 2018-03-14

Easement Act, 1882

 

Section 15— Acquisition of easement right of pathway by virtue of continuous and uninterrupted use for more than twenty years—

Easement right acquired by continuous, peaceful and uninterrupted use of pathway by the users for more than twenty years cannot be denied or obstructed. Kadam All Bhuii/an (Md.) being dead his heirs Vs. Begum Syeda Nur and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 242.

 

Section 52 and 56— Licence does not confer title to the property— It is neither heritable nor transferable—

As provided under sections 52, 56 and 59 of the Easement Act, 1882 grant of licence defined thereunder does not create any title to the property and such right is personal of the licencee, it is not transferable nor heritable. The defendants claimed title on the basis of licence as well as by virtue of adverse possession. The plaintiff failed to prove the grant of licence by their predecessor and the defendants also failed to bring on record evidence as to the essential requirements such as the time from which they claim adverse possession. In that view of the matter the appellate court below observed that the issue of adverse possession may be decided in a properly framed suit. The learned judge of the High Court Division agreed with the observation and findings of the court of appeal below with regard to the findings on adverse possession and accordingly discharged the rule with the observation that the findings of the trial court on the plea of adverse possession being premature and unwarranted shall not have any bearing on the future decision in the properly framed suit where the issue of adverse possession may be decided. Abdiis Samad and others Vs. Fein Hossain and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 89.

 

2879

East Bengal Tenancy Rules, 1955

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 226

Case Year: 1955

Subject: East Bengal Tenancy

Delivery Date: 2018-03-14

East Bengal Tenancy Rules, 1955

 

Rule 42A and 44— Director of Land Records and Surveys has no authority to interfere with the judgment of a settlement officer passed under rule 31— Director of Land Records and Surveys though is the head of the department is deemed to be a Revenue Officer having all the powers of a Settlement Officer and as such he has no power to amend or set-aside judgment passed in appeal under rule 31 of the East Bengal Tenancy Rules, 1955 except on ground of an entry in the record of rights obtained by fraud. The impugned orders are declared by the learned judges of the High Court Division as passed without any lawful authority and are of no legal effect. A/tab All Sheikh (Md.) Vs. Director, Land Records and Surveys and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 226.

2880

Electoral Rolls Ordinance, 1982

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 345

Case Year: 1982

Subject: Electoral Rolls

Delivery Date: 2018-03-15

Electoral Rolls Ordinance, 1982

 

 

Section 7- Provides for maintaining continuity of electoral rolls—

 

Preparation and up-dating of the voters list before the Parliamentary election is the responsibility of the Election Commission. Decision of the Election Commission means the decision taken by all the commissioners or by the majority of them. The Commission can not discard or ignore altogether the existing voters list but is required to up-date the same by correction and modification on the basis of the existing lists as contemplated under section 7 of the Electoral Rolls Ordinance 1982 and rule 20 of the Electoral Rolls Rules 1982.

 

Election Commission represented by the Chief Election Commissioner Vs. Alhaj Advocate Mohammad Rahmat Ali, MP and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 345.

 

Electoral Rolls Rules, 1982 Rule 20- up-dating the voter lists by correction and modification—

 

Preparation and up-dating of the voters list before the Parliamentary election is the responsibility of the Election Commission. Decision of the Election Commission means the decision taken by all the commissioners or by the majority of them. The Commission can not discard or ignore altogether the existing voters list but is required to up-date the same by correction and modification on the basis of the existing lists as contemplated under section 7 of the Electoral Rolls Ordinance 1982 and rule 20 of the Electoral Rolls Rules 1982.

 

Election Commission represented by the Chief Election Commissioner Vs. Alhaj Advocate Mohammad Rahmat AH, MP and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 345.

 

2881

Electricity Act, 1910

Citation: 12 MLR (2007) (HO 82

Case Year: 1910

Subject: Electricity Act

Delivery Date: 2018-03-15

Electricity Act, 1910

 

Section 26(6)— Dispute as to incorrect recording of electricity consumed, by the meter has to be decided by Electrical Engineer and by proper enquiry, assessment and verification— Section 39— Allegation of fraud in tampering with the meter'falls under section 39 calling for penal action.—

Supplementary penal bill not based on any enquiry and assessment by the Electrical Engineer prepared and submitted on conjecture and surmise held by the learned Judges of the High Court Division arbitrary and of no legal effect. Modern Cold Storage Ltd., Feni Vs. Secretary Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources and others 12 MLR (2007) (HO 82.

2882

Emergency Acquisition of Property Act, 1948

Citation: 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 89

Case Year: 1948

Subject: Emergency Acquisition of Property

Delivery Date: 2018-03-15

Emergency Acquisition of Property Act, 1948

 

Section 8B— Land acquired under the Town Improvement Act can not be released under this law— Moreover the  Government  cannot release   the  land  after payment of compensation-Judgment per incuriam constituting precedent-explained—

Land acquired under section 93A of the Town Improvement Act, 1953 vests in the RAJUK free from all encumbrances and as such the Appellate Division held the Government cannot release the same under any other law or under section 8B of the Emergency Requisition of Property Act, 1948. Sufia Khatoon (Most) Vs. Mrs Mahabnba Rahman and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 89.

2883

Emergency Requisition and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act, 1948

Citation: 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 106

Case Year: 1948

Subject: Emergency Requisition and Acquisition of Immovable Property

Delivery Date: 2018-03-15

Emergency Requisition and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act, 1948

 

Section 8B— Land acquired under the Town Improvement Act, 1953 can not be released under section 8B of 1948 Act-Town Improvement Act, 1953 and the Emergency Requisition and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act, 1948 are two distinct legislations and they operate in different field and different perspective. Land acquired under the Town Improvement Act, 1953 absolutely vests in the RAJUK free from all encumbrances which the Government can not release from acquisition by resort to section 8B of the Emergency Requisition and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act, 1948 or any other law. In that view of the matter the learned judges of the High Court Division declared the impugned notifications illegal, passed without any lawful authority and of no legal effect. Rajdhani LInnayn Kartripakha (RAJLIK) Vs. Secretary, Ministry, of Land and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 106.

2884

Emergency Requisition of Property Act, 1948

Citation: 23 MLR (2008) CMC) 73, 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 183, 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 222, 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 177

Case Year: 1948

Subject: Emergency Requisition of Property

Delivery Date: 2018-03-15

Emergency Requisition of Property Act, 1948

 

Section 3— In a requisition case, order under section 3 is essential—

Ownership of the land and building under requisition remains with the owner. De-requisition becomes effective as soon as the order therefor is passed. It does not depend on the handing over of possession to become operative. When the disputed land and building was de­requisitioned and there was in fact no valid LA case pending the impugned auction sale notice has been declared by the learned judges of the High Court Division illegal, without jurisdiction and of no legal effect. Jahangir Mohammad Adel and others Vs. Government of Bangladesh represented In/ the Secretary, Ministry of Education and others 23 MLR (2008) CMC) 73.

 

Emergency Requisition of Property Act, 1948— Section 5(7)— Acquisition of property for public purpose and the extinction of the right, title and interest of the owner—

Once the notice under section 5(7) of the Emergency of Property Act, 1948 for acquisition of land for public purpose is served the right, title and interest of the owner therein are extinguished. The preparation of the Khatian in his name thereafter does not improve his position. Similarly the fact of remaining the part of the land so acquired unutilised does not create any right in favour of the original owner for releasing the said land from acquisition. Bangladesh represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Land and others Vs. Nowab Abdul Malek Jute Mills Ltd 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 183.

 

Emergency Requisition of Property Act, 1948— Section 5(7)— Acquisition of property for public purpose— Subsequent transfer does not confer any title and interest upon the transferee— Property acqviired can not be enlisted as vested property—

Law is clear that once a property is acquired for public purpose and notice under section 5(7) of the Emergency Requisition of Property Act, 1948 is served, it vests in the Government free from all encumbrances and the right, title, interest of the owner are extinguished. Subsequent purchaser from the original owner having no saleable interest, does not acquire any right, title, interest in the said land. Law does not empower the Government to release any such property in favour of the original owner on ground of remaining part of the same unutilised. Further more the property so acquired can not be enlisted as enemy property/ vested property. Wega Fashion Sweater (Pvt) Ltd. Vs. Si/edn Sajeda Hossain and others 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 222.

 

Emergency Requisition of Property Act, 1948— Section 5(7)—

On the publication of final notification the right title and interest of the previous owner in the said property are extinguished and the same absolutely vest in the Government and thereafter the property so acquired cannot be returned/released. Secretary, Ministry of Agriculture and others Vs. Rabia Khatoon and others "14 MLR (2009) (AD) 177.

2885

EMERGENCY REQUISITION OF PROPERTY ACT, 1948

Citation: 1BLD (AD)75, 1BLD (HCD)30, 2BLDAD) 34, 9 BLD (HCD)97, IBLD(HCD)407, 10 BLD (AD)110, 8BLD(HCD)357, 4 BLD (AD) 283, 6BLD (AD) 342.

Case Year: 1948

Subject: EMERGENCY REQUISITION OF PROPERTY

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 

 

EMERGENCY REQUISITION OF PROPERTY ACT, 1948


Section—3

Requisition of property—To justify requisition for accommodation of Government office a case of unavailability of alternative accommodation has to be made out.

Accommodation to a Government office is no doubt a public purpose—but to justify such an order a case is to be made out that alternative accommodation is not available and it is essentially required for providing accommodation to the Government Office.

Mansurul Aziz and another Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Land Administration and Land Reforms and others; 1BLD (AD)75

 

Section-.3

 

Requisition of property

The order of requisition should contain the description of the Government Officer or the Government Office for whom the property is requisitioned.

Mansurul Aziz and another Vs. Secretary, Ministiy of Land Administration and Land Reforms and others; 1BLD (AD) 75

 

Section—3

An order of requisition for collateral purposes cannot he sustained.

Mansurtil Aziz and another Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Land Administration and Laud Reforms and others; 1BLD(AI))75

 

Section—3

Requisition of property—public purpose—A school must fit in with the national education policy in order that accommodation of such school may be a public purpose or in public interest.

Establishment and accommodation of a school as such may advance the cause of public purpose and public interest provided it conforms to the fundamental principles of statt policy upon which such school must be based—In order to categorise a school to serve public purpose and public interest as referred to in section 3 of Emergency Requisition of Property Act, reference will have in be madeas to whether such school fits in with the national education policy pursuant to the fundamental principles of state policy enshrined in the Constitution itself and the laws made accordingly from time to time.

Mrs. Winifred Rubie and others Vs. Bangladesh and others; 1BLD (HCD)30

 

Scction—3

Requisition of property—public purpose—Requisition for accommodation of a private school is for public purpose—Oblique limits and vague grievarces cannot dislodge the purpose—Enquiry as to public purpose by reference to the fundamental principles of state policy not warranted by the Constitution—Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Articles 8 and 17.

Bangladesh Vs. Mrs. Winfred Rubie and others; 2BLDAD) 34

(Mrs. Winifred Public Vs. Bangladesh, reported in 1 BLD (HCD) 30 has been reversed) Ref: 14 DLR 486; A.I.R. 1914 (PC) 21; 14 I) LR 634—Cited.

 

Section—3

Mandatory injunction—Such injunction requiring the authority to start a valid acquisition proceeding whether sustainable—The authority has no right to possess the property in question as a mere requisitioned property for an indefinite period—They have either to dc-requisition the property and hand over vacant possession thereof to the owners or they have to complete the acquisition proceedings in accordance with law—The mandatory iniunction given under the circumstances is the most appropriate decree.

Govt. of Bangladesh and ors. Vs. Basarutullah being dead his heirs and successors Fazie Kari,n and ors., 9 BLD (HCD)97

 

Sections—3 and 5

Requisition of land—public purpose— Requisition and acquisition of land for a cooperative society is not per se an acquisition for a public purpose—Constructing of dwelling houses cannot be considered per se to be a public purpose—Construction of houses as per common plan and campus for those members of a co-operative society who have rio land or house in Dacca city may serve as a public purpose.

Md. Ismail and others Vs. Bangladesh and others; IBLD(HCD)407

Ref: 14 DLR 604; A.I.R. 1959 Punj 478—Cited.

 

Section—5(1)

Public notice—Presumption of service of such notice—Public notice for acquisition of property being an official act a presumption is available under the Evidence Act that it has been regularly performed unless the contrary is proved—Evidence Act, 1872 (1 of 1872). S. 114(e).

Government of Bangladesh, represented by the Deputy Commissioner, Dhaka and others Vs. Basharatuliah being dead his heirs and successors: Fazie Karim and others; 10 BLD (AD)110

(Govt of Bangladesh and others Vs. Fazie Karim and others, reported in 9 BLD(HCD)97 has been reversed)

 

Section—5(1 a)

Public notice—Such notice by requisitioning authority to acquire property—Whether causing a public notice to be given is a service of .notice’—The public notice to be given at convenient places on or near the requisitioned property does not mean that this public notice is not meant to be a service of notice—It is a mode of service of notice upon all the owners of the requisitioned property indicating the mind and intention of the requisitioning authority—It is not a personal notice, but a collective notice meant for the owners also.,

Government of Bangladesh and others Vs. Basaratullab being dead his heirs and successors Fade Karim and others; 9 BLD (HCD) 97

[This case has been reversed by Appellate Division in the case of Government of Bangladesh Vs. Bashartullah and others, reported in 10BLD (AD) 110.1

Section—5(3)

 

Time for answering notice—15 days time limit for answering a personal notice relating to acquisition of property when not strictly necessary—Notice was served on the plaintiff on 23.4.73 requiring them to appear on 30.4.73—Admittedly, the gazette notification on the acquisition was made on 25.6.73 about 2 months after the said notice—In the circumstances it cannot be said that the plaintiffs have been deprived of a reasonable opportunity to appear due to shortage of time.

Government of Bangladesh, represented by the Deputy Commissioner, Dhaka and others Vs. Basharatullah being dead his heirs and successors: Fade Karimn and others; 10BLD (AD) 110

(Govt of Bangladesh and others Vs. Fazie Karim and others, reported in 9BLD (HCD)97 has been reversed).

 

Compensation—Compensation for acquisition of land—When the value of the land was increasing but that of money was decreasing the compensation to be paid on the valuation of the year when notice for acquisition was served would cause substantial injury to the land owner—There should be some proximity between the date of notice for acquisition and that of actual acquisition.

Government of Bangladesh represented by the Deputy Commissioner, Dhaka and others Vs. Basharatullah being dead his heirs and successors: Fade Karim and others; 10BLD(AD) 110

(Govt. of Bangladesh and others Vs. Fazle Karim and others, reported in 9BLD (HCD)97 has been reversed.

Ref: 4BLD(AD)283—Cited.

 

Section—7(b)

Arbitrator—Whether an Arbitrator appointed under Ordinance II of 1982 is a Court—Such an Arbitrator essentially conducts an inquiry into the amount of compensation that a person may reasonably receive in respect of his acquired land and structures—This is a limited inquiry which is investigative in nature—He does not exercise a judicial function in course of such an inquiry, although he is expected to act within judicial norms—The provision deeming his award to be a decree and his statement of grounds to be a judgment does not elevate him to the status of a Civil Court—Acquisition and Requisition of immovable Property Ordinance (II of 1982) Ss. 10,27,32 and 36—Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908) Ss. 2(2)(9), 34, Or. 39 Rules 1 and 2.

Begun Lutfunnessa Vs. Nizamnuddin Ahmed and others; 8BLD(HCD)357

Ref: 38 DLR(AD)172: 20 l)LR 599 (S.B.); 25 DLR 440; 26 DLR 265: —Cited.

 

Section—7(e)

Computation of compensation for acquisition of land—Period of twenty four months whether to precede the date of notice for acquisition or actual date of acquisition— Average value of the land during twenty four months preceding the date of notice of acquisition rather than the date of actual acquisition of land is to be taken in computing compensation—The date of acquisition is immaterial for the purpose of determining the value of the land acquired—When value of the land was increasing but that of money was decreasing the compensation to be paid now on the valuation of the year 1962 would cause substantial injury to the land owner—There should be some proximity between the date of notice for acquisition and that of actual acquisition.

Abdul Gafur Khan and another Vs. Government of Bangladesh and othemw; 4 BLD (AD) 283

 

Section—14A

Jurisdiction—Ouster of jurisdiction of the Civil Court—When lack of competence of the requisition authority or non—conformity with the provisions of the Act or violation of the fundamental principles of judicial procedure is not in question ouster clause of the jurisdiction of the civil court in the Act cannot he avoided—Section 14A of the Emergency Requisition of Property Act in clear and unmistakable terms put an express embargo on entertainment of suits or application against any order or action under the Act—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908(V of 1908), S. 9.

Nur Muhammad and others Vs. Moulvi Mainuddin Ahmned and others; 6BLD (AD) 342

Ref: 37 DLR(AD) 161—Cited.

 

Section—14A

Bar of suit—When such a bar in special statute does not apply—When a statutory authority acts without jurisdiction or in a manner without following a procedure provided in the statute itself, then it is not an act under the statute and the bar of suit does not apply—Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908). -

Government of Bangladesh and others Vs. Basaratullah being dead his heirs and successors Fade Karim and others, 9 BLD(HCD) 97.

[This case has been reversed by Appellate Division in the case of Govt. of Bangladesh Vs. Bashartullah and others, reported in 10 BLD(AD)110]

 

2886

Employment of Labour (Standing Orders) Act, 1960

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 220

Case Year: 1960

Subject: Employment of Labour

Delivery Date: 2018-03-15

Employment of Labour (Standing Orders) Act, 1960

 

Section    25—    Grievance    against termination of service—

Section 47-B of the Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1965 provides protection of a worker against transfer on ground of trade union activities. When the writ petitioner was singled out and was transferred on ground of union activities, and the High Court Division stayed the operation of the transfer order, and the respondent in violation of the stay order terminated his service which the learned judges held to be malafide and declared both the transfer order and the termination order as illegal and passed without any lawful authority. It is further held that the alternative remedy in the labour court being not efficacious the writ petition is quite maintainable. Farucjue Hasan Vs. Titas Gas Transmission and Distribution Company Ltd. and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 220.

 

2887

Employment of Labour (standing orders) Act, 1965

Citation: 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 317, 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 417, 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 427

Case Year: 1965

Subject: Employment of Labour

Delivery Date: 2018-03-15

Employment of Labour (standing orders) Act, 1965

 

Section 25— Dismissal of workers without affording reasonable opportunity of defence is held illegal and setting aside the same by the Labour Court as perfectly justified—

The Regulations of the Bangladesh Film Development Corporation do not supersede the Employment of Labour (standing orders) Act, 1965 and while dispensing with the service of its workers, the minimum opportunity of defence must be afforded and the rules of procedure shall have to be followed, failure of which renders the impugned order of dismissal denude of any Segal effect. Bangladesh Film Development Corporation Vs. the Chairman, First Labour Court, Dhaka and another 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 317.

 

Employment of Labour (Standing Orders) Act, 1965— Section 25(1) (b)-— Applicable to workers of commercial and industrial concerns—

Bangladesh Water Development Board is a creation of statute and as such its employees are not worker and the Employment of Labour (Standing Orders) Act, 1965 is not applicable to the Bangladesh Water Development Board. Bangladesh Water Development Board and others Vs. Chairman, Divisional Labour Court, Khutna and another 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 417.

 

Employment of Labour (Standing Orders) Act, 1965— Section 25(l)(b)— Termination of service of worker for trade union activities is not sustainable in law—

Though termination order does not contain any stigma, when it is passed for trade union activities of the worker, it is held not sustainable as contemplated under section 25(l)(b) of the Employment of Labour (Standing Orders) Act, 1965. When the industrial dispute failed due to inaction on the part of the trade union and the employer, the complaint under section 25 of the Act of 1965 is held maintainable. BRAC Pi-inters Vs. Chairman, First Labour Court and another 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 427.

2888

Enemy/Vested Property Law

Citation: 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 349

Case Year: 1965

Subject: Enemy/Vested Property Law

Delivery Date: 2018-03-15

Enemy/Vested Property Law

 

No property can be enlisted as enemy or vested property after the repeal of Ordinance No. 1 of 1965—

The disputed property has been enlisted as enemy/vested property in 1997 long after the Ordinance No. 1 of 1965 was repealed on 23.3.1.974. The writ-petitioner is found to be the owner in possession of the said property. The High Court Division declared the impugned V.P case grossly illegal and of no legal effect which the apex court upheld. Government of Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Land and others Vs. Dhaka Menon Anjuman 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 349.

2889

Environment Conservation Act, 1995

Citation: 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 389

Case Year: 1995

Subject: Environment Conservation

Delivery Date: 2018-03-15

Environment Conservation Act, 1995

 

Section 7— Provides for conservation of environment and ecological balance for healthy and better living of the people—

Act No. XXXVI of 2000 provides for punishable offence for violation of the environmental law—

 

The High Court Division directed the writ respondents to take appropriate measures to remove the encroachments in the river Buriganga, Shitalakha, Turag after ascertaining the boundaries by survey. The authorities concerned issued notices upon the appellants to remove the illegal structures. The apex court found the directions of the High Court Division perfectly justified and accordingly the leave petitions are dismissed. City Sugar Industries Ltd. and others Vs. Human Rights and Peace for Bangladesh and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 389.

 

2890

Evidence Act, 1872

Citation: 13 mlr (2008) (HC) 184, 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 158, 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 2460, 5 MLR (2010) (AD) 485, 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 172, 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 317, 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 449, 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 97, 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 300, 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 100, 11 MLR (2006) (

Case Year: 1872

Subject: Evidence

Delivery Date: 2018-03-15

Evidence Act, 1872

 

Photostat copy of document without authentication is not an evidence—

Original documents were never produced before the court. Instead only the photostat copies of those documents without any authentication were produced which the learned judges of the High Court Division held carry no evidentiary value under the Evidence Act. Alhaj Abdul Maleque Gazi Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 13 mlr (2008) (HC) 184.

 

Section 32— Dying declaration as to the cause of death of the deceased may form the basis of conviction— The quality but not the quantity of evidence which matters—

Circumstantial evidence unerringly pointing at the guilt of the accused can safely form the basis of conviction. Similarly as in the case of husband of a wife killing case, the wife has also equally the same liability to explain as to how her husband met his death when they were residing in the same house at the time of the occurrence.

 

Section 32— Dying declaration voluntary and true has great importance and evidentiary value which can alone form the sole basis of conviction—

A dying declaration has special sanctity in view of the fact that a dying person under the pangs of death can not tell lie. When a dying declaration is found by the court to be voluntary and true this can form the sole basis of conviction without any corroboration. Touhid and others Vs. The State 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 158.

 

Section 35— Presumption of public documents as to their correctness—

Voter list and Kabinnama duly registered under the Muslim (Marriages and Divorce) Registration Act, 1974 are public documents and have presumption of their correctness so long such presumption is not rebutted, these are admissible in evidence. From these public documents it is found that the age of the defendant was about 22 years at the time of the disputed marriage and as such the defendant can not repudiate his marriage with the plaintiff on ground of minority and accordingly the learned judge of the High Court Division upheld the impugned judgment of the appellate court below which decreed the suit by reversing the judgment and decree of the trial court. Azizur Rahman (Md.) Vs. Mosamnwt Nazmun Nahar 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 2460.

 

Section 65— Admissibility of secondary evidence—

Section 110— Possession of the plaintiff has presumption of title—

Objection against admission of secondary evidence must be taken at the earliest point of time before the court of first instance. Once admitted into evidence objection thereagainst can not be raised and such evidence can not be ignored sub-sequently. Possession of the plaintiff in the suit land has the presumption of title. Abul Hossain (Hajee) and others Vs. Md. Amjad Hosain and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 485.

 

Section 73— Though the court can compare disputed handwriting with the admitted one but such comparison has been discouraged by the apex court—

As the science and technology has advanced and the disputed handwritings can best be examined and compared by expert by use of scientific methods, the apex court in such circumstances discouraged the comparison of disputed handwritings by the court as contemplated under section 73 of the Evidence Act, 1872. Status quo order has no binding effect on the Ad-hoc Managing Committee which is not a party to the proceedings and as such the appointments of the teachers made by the Ad-hoc committee are held by the Appellate Division legal and valid. Sarder Md. Hashim Zaman and others Vs. Thana Nirbahi .Officer, Mithapukur, Rangpur and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 172.

 

Section 73— Comparison of disputed handwriting by court—-

In appropriate case additional evidence may be accepted at the stage of appeal in order to advance the cause of justice—

Though section 73 of the Evidence Act, 1872 empowers the court to compare by itself disputed handwriting and signature, yet the apex , court discouraged such practice as unsatisfactory and insisted upon getting the disputed signature and handwriting examined by handwriting expert. The learned judges of the High Court Division also opined that in view of the continuing advancement of the science and technology of examination of handwritings, it is the safe course to obtain the opinion of the expert on the disputed signature and as such upheld the impugned order passed by the appellate court below allowing examination of the disputed documents by expert. Abdur Rashid Miah and another Vs. Md. Zami Shah Newaz and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 317.

 

 

Section 73— Power of the court to compare the handwritting tinder dispute—

In the instant case the trial court dismissed the suit for specific performance of contract on the ground the disputed signature wTas not examined by handwritting expert. In appeal the appellate court himself compared the disputed signature with the specimen signature and decreed the suit. The learned judges of the High Court Division found nothing wrong with the impugned judgment and decree and as such dismissed the revision. Abu Tarn (Most.) Vs. Md. Abdur Rahim Khan and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 449.

 

Section   90—   Presumption   as   to genuineness   of  document  30  years old-Section 90 of the Evidence Act, 1872 provides  for presumption  as  to  its execution and contents of document 30 years old when the same is produced from proper custody. When an unregistered Heba deed is impounded under section 35 of the Stamp Act and is admitted into evidence the same can not be subsequently thrown out of consideration. S.A. Khatians and rent receipts are held to be evidence of possession which follows from title. Title is perfected on the basis of adverse possession for over a statutory period. Nurjahan Begum Vs. Nur Rahman and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 97.

 

Section 91— Finding of court as to inadvertent wrong mention of plot number of suit land does not offend section 91—

When from the evidences it was found that the number of plot in the deed of agreement for reconveyance was mistakenly noted, the finding of the trial court to this effect is held by the apex court not violative of the provisions of section 91 of the Evidence Act. Abu Alam (Md.) Vs. Zarina Begum and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 129.

 

Section 91— Documentary evidence prevail over the oral evidence—

Plea of benami purchase fails when not established by cogent evidence—

In the instant case the defendant failed to establish her plea of benami purchase of the suit land and the trial court decreed the suit which the learned judges of the High Court Division up­held. Meheron Nessa alias Most Meheronessa Khanorn Vs. All Ahmed Khan and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 197.

 

Section 100— Burden of proof lies on he who asserts the existence of certain thing—

 

Specific Relief Act, 1877—

Section 42— In a suit for declaratory decree the plaintiff must prove his title and possession—

Where the plaintiff's earlier suit is dismissed which the plaintiff did not challenge in higher court, he is debarred from instituting subsequent suit on the same cause of action. Shafiuddin Prag (Md.) Vs. Md. Klwlilur Rahman Khamaru 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 300.

 

Section 101— Burden of proof lies upon the person who asserts the existence of certain thing—

Mollah's Mohammedan Law—

Section 252— Prescribes certain essential requirements of a valid Muslim Marriage—

Muslim marriage is a socio-religious contract which the party claiming must prove by cogent evidence. In the instant case the plaintiff claims for decree for realisation of dower money and maintenance. But the defendant flatly denied the existence of any marriage of the plaintiff with him. The plaintiff could not produce the original kabinnama of the marriage and she could not also produce any witness of the marriage nor even the Nikah Registrar to prove the marriage. Since the plaintiff miserably failed to establish her marriage with the defendant the learned judge of the High Court Davisort held there was no valid marriage in between the parties and accordingly set aside the impugned judgment   and   decree   of  the  courts below. Shnhidul Islam (Md.) Vs. Most Anwara Begum 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 100.

 

 

Section 101— Burden of proof lies upon he who asserts the existence of certain things—

Unless shifted to the other side in the circumstances mentioned under section 103 the burden of proof lies upon he who asserts the existence of certain thing as required under section 101 of the Evidence Act, 1872.

 

The plaintiff in order to get a decree must prove his own case. He cannot succeed on the weakness of the defence. Rent receipt is evidence of prossession and title follows possession. Abul Hossain and others Vs. Habibullah Mia and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 305.

 

Section 102— Burden of proof of certain thing lies upon he who alleges the existence thereof—

Section 67 and 68— Presumption of the contents of registered deed—

Earlier deed prevails over the subsequent deed—

Concurrent findings of fact of the appellate court as well as the trial court are binding upon the High Court Division unless the same is perverse or suffers from misconstruction of material document or non-consideration of material evidence on record. Shushil Chandra Nath Vs. Shanjib Kanti Nath and another 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 273.

 

 

Section 103— Burden of proof lies upon the person who asserts the existence of certain thing—

Section 67 and 68— Documents when not proved in accordance with law cannot be admitted into evidence—

Transfer of Property Act, 1882—

Section 48— Transfer earlier in point of time takes precedence over the subsequent one—

Findings of facts of the appellate court when do not suffer from any legal infirmity do not call for interference by the revisional court. Except copies of the judicial records all other documents in order to be admissible in evidence, shall have to be proved in the manner as provided under the law. When the original Kabala deeds are not produced and are not proved in accordance with law the copy thereof can not be admitted into evidence. Rent receipts, mutation khatian and record of rights may be evidence of possession but they do not create any title.  As provided under section 48 of the Transfer   of   Property   Act,   1882  the  transfer earlier in point of time shall prevail over the subsequent one. Tajul Islam and others Vs. Chini Miah and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 1.

 

Section 114(e)— Presumption of correctness of registered document-As provided under section 114(e) of the Evidence Act, 1872, an instrument duly registered has presumption that its contents are correct until the contrary is established. Plaintiff who is a party to the document can not avoid such document without a decree for cancellation thereof. Aslam Khnn (Md.) Vs. Haji Abdiir Rniiini and others 72 MLR (2007; (AD) 149.

 

 

Section 114(f)— Summon/notices sent to the defendant/respondent by registered post with acknowledgement due slip but returned by the postal peon with the endorsement "refused" has the presumption of due service as contemplated under section 27 of the General Clauses Act, 1897—

When the defendant or the respondent challenge the correctness of the service of summons or notices, it is the defendant or the respondent as the case may be/ who has to rebut the presumption of service by adducing evidence to the effect that the same was not sent to the correct address or it was never tendered to him. or there was no reason for him to refuse to accept the same. Abdur Rob Mollah Vs. Sahabuddin Ahmed and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 319.

 

Section 114(g)— Non-examination of material witness raises the adverse presumption against the genuineness of the prosecution case—

 

Narcotics Control Act, 1990—

Section 19(3)— Offence of possession of ganja plants held not proved when the prosecution led no evidence as to the land where from the ganja plants recovered belongs to the convict-petitioner—

Convict-petitioner was convicted for the offence under section 19(3) of the Narcotics Control Act, 1990 and the conviction and sentence were also affirmed by the Sessions Judge in Appeal. The learned judge of the High Court Division set aside the order of conviction and sentence in view of absence of any evidence on record showing that the land wherefrom the ganja plants were recovered actually belongs to the convict-petitioner. Shamsher AH (Md.) Vs. The State 12 MLR (2007) (HO 38.

 

Section  115—  Estoppel—  When  it operates—

The High Court Division can not negotiate price of auction materials which is the exclusive domain of the Government. The writ petitioner upon accepting the auction price of some of the articles has taken delivery of those materials. Thereafter he can not raise objection against fresh auction of the remaining materials and as such he is barred by the' principle of estoppel. M/S Ashraf and others Vs. Md. Zahangir Alam and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 87.

 

Section 115— Estoppel by waiver and acquiescence—

When by act, conduct or consent, express or implied a person allows another person to proceed in doing certain act or transactions with bonafide belief, such conduct or consent constitute waiver and acquiescence and the person so allowing is estopped from claiming any right in respect therewith subsequently against the person who acted under such assurance. Major (Retd.) Quazi Hasna Hena Begum Vs. Lt. Col. Kazi Monsurul Islam and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 65.

 

Section  115—  Promissory  estoppel and equity—

When a person makes promise to another person who acts thereunder, subsequently the person so making the promise cannot be allowed to fall back from his promise. In the instant case though the Chittagong Port Authority (CPA) did not make any promise to the writ petitioner to grant lease of .075 acre land, but the CPA persuaded the petitioner to make payment of Tk 7,68,722.47 on behalf of the Amin Agency which the CPA accepted under the expectation of getting lease of the land in question. Moreover the writ petitioner filled up the low lying area and the ditch within the knowledge of the CPA. The apex court held in the facts and circumstances and in equity-the writ petitioner is entitled to get lease of the .075 acre land from the CPA. Abul Hashem Vs. International Oil Mills Limited and others 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 117.                    

 

Sections 123 and 162— Immunity of documents relating affairs of the state—

When privilege as contemplated under article 48(3) of the Constitution with regard to certain documents are claimed, the court has to hold inquiry as to the validity of such claim. The apex court set aside the impugned order of calling for the documents as the same was done without holding any such inquiry. Government of Bangladesh, represented by the Secretary, Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs Vs. Md. Shamsul Hilda and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 224.

 

Section 155(3)— Previous statement should be confronted to the witness to impeach his credibility—

Upon an application of person affected the court can examine and scrutinise the records and papers as to any fraud, undue influence or misrepresentation in transferring shares and give direction for rectification of the Share Register. The power of the court under section 38 of the Companies Act, is wide enough. Ahmed Impex (Private} Ltd. and others Vs. Mocjbul Ahmed being dead his heirs Ferdous Ara Begum and another 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 129.

2891

Family Courts Ordinance, 1985

Citation: 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 167, 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 33, 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 465, 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 213, 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 434, 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 246, 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 100, 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 427, 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 51

Case Year: 1985

Subject: Family Courts

Delivery Date: 2018-03-15

Family Courts Ordinance, 1985

 

Sections 3 and 5— Family Court has exclusive jurisdiction to decide the suit for    maintenance    of    the    parties

irrespective of their faith— In the instant case both the parties are members of Hindu faith according to whose customs there is no provision of divorce. The trial court decreed the suit for past and future maintenance which both the High Court Division and the Appellate Division upheld. Jibon Sharma (Sree) Vs. Sree Siibasini Sharrna and another 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 167.

 

Section 5— Liability of the husband to pay the dower and maintenance to his wife on the dissolution of marriage—

When the marriage is admittedly dissolved by talak at the instance of the husband and the husband failed to establish the payment of the dower as claimed, the wife is legally entitled to realise the dower money as well as the maintenance during the period of her iddat. Shahid Ha mid Vs. Niliifar Momtaz 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 33.

 

Section 5— Custody of minor— Best welfare of the child shall be the paramount consideration—

According to the Mohamedan Law and also, the Guardian and Wards Act, 1890, the father is entitled to the custody of minor son after he has attained the age of 7(seven) years. But this 7 years factor as held, is not the only criteria to determine the custody of a minor boy. it has now been consistently held by the apex courts, that in deciding the custody of the minor boy the seven years age factor shall not be the only criteria. The welfare and best interest of the child shall be the paramount consideration. In that view of the matter the learned judges of the High Court Division directed the boy though aged 10 years to be restored to the custody of the mother during the pendency of the Family Court Suit. Zahida Ahmed (Liza) Vs. Si/ed Nooruddin Ahmed and another 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 465.

 

Section 5— Suit for maintenance of wife during subsistence of marriage—

Muslim Family Laws Ordinance, 1961— Section 7(1)— Notice of divorce shall be given to the chairman in whose jurisdiction the wife resides at the relevant time—

As required under section 7(1) of the Muslim Family Laws Ordinance, 1,961 the notice of divorce shall be sent to the chairman in whose jurisdiction the wife was residing at the time of pronouncement of the divorce.- When the notice is not properly served the divorce does not become valid and the marriage between the husband and wife subsists and as such the wife so long remains loyal is entitled to maintenance. Kazi Rashed Akhter Shahid (Prince) Vs. Most Rokshana Chowdhury (Sanda) 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 213.

 

Section 5— Custody of minor child— Entitlement of divorced mother when she is remarried to a second husband—

Law is well settled that a mother even after her divorce, is entitled to the custody of her male child until he completes the age of seven years and a female child till she attains her puberty. Mother loses her right to the custody of such child when she is remarried to a second husband. In determining the custody of a minor child, the best interest and welfare of the child shall be the paramount consideration. Sefina Ferdousi @ Shimla and another Vs. Jaohar Kabir and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 434.

 

Section 5— Dispute as to solemnisation of marriage can well be decided by the Family Court—

Evidence Act, 1872—

Section 35— Presumption of public documents as to their correctness—

Voter list and Kabinnama duly registered under the Muslim (Marriages and Divorce) Registration Act, 1974 are public documents and have presumption of their correctness so long such presumption is not rebutted, these are admissible in evidence. From these public documents it is found that the age of the defendant was about 22 years at the time of the disputed marriage and as such the defendant can not repudiate his marriage with the plaintiff on ground of minority and accordingly the learned judge of the High Court Division upheld the impugned judgment of the appellate court below which decreed the suit by reversing the judgment and decree of the trial court. Azizur Rahman (Md.) Vs. Mosammat Nnzmun Nnhar 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 246.

 

Section 5— The Family Court is required to decide whether there is any valid marriage when it is flatly denied by the defendant—

Evidence Act, 1872—

Section 101— Burden of proof lies upon the person who asserts the existence of certain thing—

Mollah's Mohammedan Law—

Section 252—Prescribes certain essential requirements of a valid Muslim Marriage—

Muslim marriage is a socio-religious contract which the party claiming must prove by cogent evidence. In the instant case the plaintiff claims for decree for realisation of dower money and maintenance. But the defendant flatly denied the existence of any marriage of the plaintiff with him. The plaintiff could not produce the original kabinnama of the marriage and she could not also produce any witness of the marriage nor even the Nikah Registrar to prove the marriage. Since the plaintiff miserably failed to establish her marriage with the defendant the learned judge of the High Court Davison held there was no valid marriage in between the parties and accordingly set aside the impugned judgment and decree of the courts below. 'Shahldnl Islam (Md.) Vs. M.ost Amvara Begum 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 100.

 

Section 17— Appeal against the judgment and  decree  of  the  Family Court-Muslim Family Laws Ordinance, 1961—

Section 10— When mode of payment of dower is not specifically mentioned in the Kabinnama, the entire dower is presumed to be payable on demand—

 

Marriage between the plaintiff and the defendant is admitted. The wife though not taken to the house of the husband, claims to have their marriage consummated which is supported  by consistent evidence. There is presumption to the effect that the marriage was consummated and the wife is entitled to the entire dower. Wahcd AH (Md.) Vs. Moshma Khatun 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 427.

 

Section 17— Appeal against judgment, decree or order of the family court — is a statutory right-Appeal shall lie to the District Judge against  judgment,   decree   or order passed by the Family Court which is a statutory right and as such no precondition for admission  of appeal can be attached. Arif Hossain (Md.) Vs. Mosammat Binci Akhtar 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 51.

2892

Forest Act, 1927

Citation: 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 147

Case Year: 1927

Subject: Forest Act

Delivery Date: 2018-03-15

Forest Act, 1927

 

Section 2, 4, 29 and 34— Notification declaring certain land as protected and reserved forest— Subsequent settlement not tenable in law—

In the instant case notification was published in the official Gazettes dated 12th January, 1934, 17th July 1937 and 13th April 1955 declaring the suit land as protected and then as reserved forest. Thereafter the Bhawal Court of Wards Estate had no authority to settle the suit land. The apex court found the settlement improbable and illegal in the face of inconsistencies of the claim of the plaintiffs with the records and accordingly allowed the appeal. Government of Bangladesh, represented by the Deputy Commissioner, Gazipur and others Vs. Abdur Rahman and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 147.

 

2893

General Clauses Act, 1897

Citation: 5 BLC 528, 1 BLC 158.

Case Year: 1897

Subject: General Clauses

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 


General Clauses Act [X of 1897]


Section 6—

Earlier Division Bench of the High Court Division while quashing the proceedings of the Special Tribunal Case did not take into consideration the applicability of section 6 of the General Clauses Act to a case of a repealed statute. The learned Judges of the High Court Division while delivering earlier judgment did not take into consideration two leading decisions wherein it has been held that where an Act repeals an earlier Act, and a different intention appears, the repeal shall not affect any liability incurred or punishment incurred in respect of any offence committed against any enactment so repealed and hence the earlier judgment of the High Court Division was given “per incuriam”.

Abul Kalam Khan vs Reaz Morshed and another 5 BLC 528.


Section 6—

From the savings clause in section 29 (2)(3) of the Nari-o-Shishu Nirjatan (Bishes Bidhan) Am, 1995 there is nothing in the language from which it can be concluded that only the cases pending for trial before any Special Tribunal or pending investigation under the Cruelty to Women (Deterrent Punishment) Ordinance, 1983 in its restricted meaning have been saved. If such restricted interpretation is accepted then the accused persons who have committed offence under such repealed enactment will get premium without facing trial which could not be intention of the legislature. The repealing Act does not indicate any intention of destroying the liability or penalty incurred under the repealing Act. In the repealing Act, there is specific mention of only cases which were under investigation or under trial but it does not appear from the repealing Act that the offences, which were committed under the repealed Act which are covered by section 6(b)(c) and (d) of the General Clauses Act, would be deemed to have been destroyed. Section 6 of the General Clauses Act will be applicable unless the new legislation manifests an intention incompatible with or contrary to the provisions of the section. Such incompatibility would have to be ascertained from a consideration of all the relevant provisions of the new law.

Abul Kalam Khan vs Reaz Morshed and another 5 BLC 528.


Section 6—

An accused is to be tried in accordance with procedure prevailing on the day trial commenced and if the procedure is changed by the time trial commenced the accused cannot claim vested right to be tried in accordance with the provisions of the repealed procedure.

Sultan Ahmed and others vs State 1 BLC 158.

 

2894

Government and Autonomous Bodies Employees Benevolent Fund and Group Insurance Ordinance, 1982

Citation: 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 62

Case Year: 1982

Subject: Government and Autonomous Bodies Employees Benevolent Fund and Group Insurance

Delivery Date: 2018-03-15

Government and Autonomous Bodies Employees Benevolent Fund and Group Insurance Ordinance, 1982

 

Section 23— Entitlement to the benefits of Benevolent Fund and Group Insurance is governed by the law inforce at the time when the right accrued— General Clauses Act, 1897— Section 6— Right accrued under the law  is   not   affected   by   the   repeal thereof—

In the instant ease the right to Benevolent Fund and Group Insurance accrued under the law of 1969 and as such the respondents were entitled to the benefits under the previous law inforce at the relevant time. They cannot claim the benefit under the subsequent law although the claim was settled during the continuance of the new law. Director and Secretary, Ministry of Establishment and Board of Trustees and others Vs. Md. Hossain and others 14 MLR (2009) (AD) 62.

 

Government policy not to accord permission to new college within the vicinity of 300 yards Government Servants (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1985

 

Rule 7(6)— Provides for serving second show cause notice upon the accused in departmental proceedings as to the proposed penalty, as mandatory requirement of law—

Statutory body in the absence of its own disciplinary rules may adopt the Government Servants (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1985. But when adopted such statutory body must follow the Rules fully and not partly. In the instant case the Comilla Education Board did not serve the second show cause notice upon the accused with the copy of the enquiry report and was not allowed the statutory period to make his reply which vitiated the proceedings and rendered the penalty of dismissal from service illegal. The learned judges of the High Court Division upon considering the illegalities as mentioned above declared the impugned order passed without any lawful authority and is of no legal effect. Shafiqiil Islam Vs. Board of Intermediate and Secondary Education, Comilla, represented by its Chairman and others 15 MLR (2010) (HC) 345.

2895

Government Servants (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1985

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 210

Case Year: 1985

Subject: Government Servants

Delivery Date: 2018-03-18

Government Servants (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1985

 

Rule 11(3)— Provides for suspension of a Government servant whose dismissal, removal or compulsory retirement is setaside by Court or tribunal when the authority decides to hold further inquiry—

The authority is empowered under Rule 11(3) of the Government Servants (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1985 to hold further inquiry after dismissal or removal or compulsory retirement of a Government Servant is setaside or declared invalid by a court or tribunal. When the authority decides to hold further enquiry, the said Government servant shall be deemed to have been placed under suspension from the date of dismissal or removal or compulsory retirement. No formal order for that will be necessary. But when the authority allowed the delinquent Government servant to join and continue to serve for a considerable time, the authority thereafter can not decide to hold further enquiry which right is lost to the authority by waiver.

 

Government of Bangladesh and others Vs. A.K.M. Fazlul Haque 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 210.

 

 

2896

Hindu Law

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 22, 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 43, 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 8, 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 334, 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 507

Subject: Hindu Law

Delivery Date: 2018-03-18

Hindu Law

 

Diety has its perpetual entity and an idol is always a minor and should be represented by shebayet—

A property once made a debattor property and is dedicated to a diety it remains as such and never can be turned into a secular property. Record of rights of the C.S. Khatian have the presumption of correctness. Debattar property cannot be treated as enemy property. Abdul Aziz and another Vs. Hindu Diety Luxmi Gobinda Jew and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 22.

 

Transfer of ejmali property by a member of Hindu joint family—

A member of Hindu joint family governed by Dayabhaga school can dispose of his undivided ancestral property by sale, will or gift even though the same were not partitioned by metes and bounds. No vested property case with regard to the Hindu property can be started after 23.03.1974 on which date the Ordinance No.l of 1969 was repealed. A lessee on year to year basis lease of vested property has no locus-standi to challenge the impugned decree or prefer an appeal thereagainst. Aroti Rani Paul (Sreetnati) Vs. Sree Shudarshan Kumar Paul and others 11 MLR (2006) (AD) 43.

 

Shebayet—  Rights and responsibilities—

Shebayet of a Hindu deity is a manager of the debattar property and he performs the sheba puja. He has no title or heritable right to the said property. When the Shebayet left for India he ceases to be Shebayet and he has no authority to appoint Ramesh Chandra Barman as Shebayat by a power of attorney which is of no legal effect. Ramesh Chandra Barman Vs. Sree Sree Kala Charan Jieu TJwkur and another 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 8.

 

Right of Hindu widow to transfer immovable property on ground of legal necessity—

In the instant suit a Hindu widow transferred her husband's property by registered deed for some legal necessity some 30 years before the reversioners transferred the suit land. The learned judge of the High Court Division held the transfer made by the widow for legal necessity perfectly valid where-by the transferee acquired good title, interest and possession. The subsequent transfers by the reversioners did not create any title and interest in the suit land. Rahima Khatun (Mst.) and another Vs. Sree Monoranjan Saha and others 13 MLR (2008) (HC) 334.

 

An idol is considered minor and has to be always represented by next friend— Religious Endowment Act, 1863— Section 14—Removal of Trustee—

Any person in the Hindu community having interest in the worship of the diety can bring suit for the removal of the trustee or the shebayet on ground of misconduct in the management of the debattar property. Pores 7 Chandra Biswas Vs. Srec Sree Shashan Kali ma ta Idol, represented by Hindu Inhabitants 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 507.

2897

Hindu Women's Right to Separate Residence and Maintenance Act, 1946

Citation: 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 23

Case Year: 1946

Subject: Hindu Women's Right to Separate Residence and Maintenance

Delivery Date: 2018-03-18

Hindu Women's Right to Separate Residence and Maintenance Act, 1946

 

Section 2— Right of a Hindu wife to separate residence and maintenance— Hindu   marriage   is   a   sacrament and inseparable. If the husband tortures and neglects his wife and her living with the husband  is not safe, she is entitled to separate residence  and maintenance. Copal Chandra Vs. Mitali Rani Chandra 15 MLR (2010) (AD) 23.

2898

House Rent Control Act, 1991

Citation: 14 MLR (2009) (HC) 425

Case Year: 1991

Subject: House Rent

Delivery Date: 2018-03-18

House Rent Control Act, 1991

 

Section   27—   Application   of   the House Rent Case is not a plaint and as such the provisions of Order 7 rule 11 C.P.C does not apply— As the application of a House Rent case before the House Rent Controller is not a plaint, the Order 7 rule "11 of the Code for rejection of the application in such case is not applicable. Mniniil Haqne Bhuiyan Vs. Md. Akkas Miah '14 MLR (2009) (HC) 425.

2899

Import Policy of 1997-2000

Citation: 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 122

Subject: Import Policy

Delivery Date: 2018-03-18

Import Policy of 1997-2000

 

Article 21— Empowers the authority to relax the conditions—

Import of reconditioned cars of more than 5 years old for personal use and for commercial purpose are two different cases which are distinguishable from the other. While the authority relaxed the conditions for personal use and refused the prayer of the writ petitioner for commercial purpose that does not offend article 27 of the Constitution. Chief Controller of Import and Exports and others Vs. Md. Fanik Ahmed 12 MLR (2007) (AD) 122.

2900

Income Tax Ordinance, 1984

Citation: 14 BLD (HCD) 607, 13 BLD (HCD) 460, 20 BLD (AD) 79, 22 BLD (HCD) 356, 21 BLD (HCD) 145, 19 BLD (HCD) 611, 22 BLD (HCD) 59, 20 BLD (HCD) 480, 22 BLD (HCD) 59, 22 BLD (HCD) 59, 19 BLD (HCD) 220, 20 BLD (HCD) 38, 19 BLD (AD) 104.

Subject: Income Tax

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 

 

Income Tax Ordinance, 1984

 

Sections—1(86), 83(1), 89 and 90

Income Tax Act, 1922, Section—23(6)(4)

The Income Tax Ordinance, 1984 came into force with effect from 1st July, 1984. For assessment of any income prior to the coming into operation of this Ordinance, the Income Tax Act, 1922 and the Rules made thereunder would continue to apply as if this Act has not been repealed. This has been clearly spelt out in Section 1(86) of the Ordinance. In the instant case the assessment period ending on 30-6-1984 is to be regulated by the provisions of Income Tax Act, 1922.

The Commissioner of Taxes, Rajshahi Zone, Rajshahi Vs. Mr. Md. Abdul Motaleb Miah, 14 BLD (HCD) 607.

 

The Company under liquidation as per provisions of Income Tax Ordinance, 1984, is a unit of assessment and its income is assessable to tax. Hence the demand made by the Deputy Commissioner of taxes is to be satisfied.

The Official Liquidator is under legal obligation to pay the tax which is assessed on the income of the Company arising out of interest upon deposit.

Dhaka Electricity Development Co. Ltd. (In Liquidation) And In the Matter of Affidavit of Facts in support of Summons taken out by Mr. Abdul Matin, Official Liquidator for direction., 13 BLD (HCD) 460.

 

Paragraph 27 of Part A of Sixth Schedule

The petitioner is an indigenous hillman and his business activities in supplying the rice under contracts to the Government is an economic activity. But for supply of rice outside the hill districts under the contract the petitioner is not entitled to exemption of payment of income tax as the income derived by the petitioner is from the economic activity carried on outside the hill districts.

Sampriti Chakma Vs Commissioner of Customs and others, 20 BLD (AD) 79.

 

Section—31

The transfer of land and building jointly owned by the assessee and his wife to a company against shares in the company is not a business transaction but an investment in their business. Even if the value of the property is more than that shown in the deed of transfer, the transfer did not give rise to any profit or gains assessable as capital gains of the assessee.

Md. Harasat Ullah v. The Commissioner of Taxes, 22 BLD (HCD) 356.

Ref: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Publix Industries 1969 PTD 622; M/s. A. K. Khan Plywood Co., Chittagong v. The Commissioner of Income Tax, East Pakistan 25 DLR(SC) 65; William Richard Doughty v. Commissioner of Taxes AIR 1927(PC)76.

 

Section—46A(1)

Subject to the provisions of the Ordinance, profits and gains of an industrial undertaking, tourist industry or physical infra. structure facility set-up in Bangladesh between the 1st day of July, 1995 and 13th day of June, 2000 (both days inclusive) shall be exempt from the tax payable under this Ordinance.

Homeland Footwear Limited Vs Chairman, National Board of Revenue and others, 21 BLD (HCD) 145.

 

Sections—79 and 85(1)

Since petitioner did not file any certificate or any material in support of her statement in the income tax return, contention that the appellate authority as well as the revisional authority acted illegally and without jurisdiction in not sending back the case to the Deputy Commissioner of Taxes for fresh consideration appears to us is not well founded one in that the certificate so filed in support of the loan shown in the income tax return being from a different person has rightly been left out of consideration by the income tax authorities.

Ms Maliha Banu Vs The Deputy Corn. missioner of Taxes and others, 19 BLD (HCD) 611.

 

Section—82

Income Tax Rules 1984, Rule—64A

If it was the consistent finding of the Deputy Commissioner of Taxes that income tax returns for the assessment years were duly audited and certified by a chartered accountant as required under section 82 of the Income Tax Ordinance 1984, it cannot be said after a lapse of years that the returns were not submitted properly, correctly or in accordance with the requirements of law. If there was any illegality or irregularity, the same could have been raised by the Deputy Commissioner of Taxes before accepting the returns.

American Express Bank lid. v. Chairman, National Board of Revenue and others, 22 BLD (HCD) 59.

 

Section—84

It appears that a return was filed by the assessee which was duly received by the department and in that view of the matter the Assistant Commissioner of Taxes ought to have considered the same in assessing the income of the assessee applicant. Therefore, the impugned order of the Appellate Tribunal cannot be sustained and it suffers from legal infirmities.

M/S. Union Corporation, Vs The Commissioner of Taxes, 20 BLD (HCD) 480.

 

Section—93

Once returns accepted by a competent authority certified that the returns are in order, unless otherwise found definite, the Deputy Commissioner of Taxes is not competent to serve notice under section 93 of the Ordinance upon the assessee asking him to submit fresh returns, holding the returns already assessed and accepted as under-assessed.

American Express Bank Ltd. v. Chairman, National Board of Revenue and others, 22 BLD (HCD) 59.

 

Section—121

Where a notice does not meet the requirements of section 93, a writ petition under Article 102 of the Constitution is maintainable instead of approaching the Commissioner for revising the order under section 121.

American Express Bank lid. v. Chairman, National Board of Revenue and others, 22 BLD (HCD) 59.

 

Section—144

There is absolutely nothing to show that the petitioner has a permanent establishment in Bangladesh and that they were actually doing business in this country and that they themselves sold their products to any person in Bangladesh. If any profit is earned by the petitioners principal office in Korea under the convention they will be taxed in Korea. But they cannot be taxed for their earnings in Korea in Bangladesh which is protected under the convention which is a solemn document entered into between the two Government and which has the backing of section 144 of the Ordinance.

M/s Hyundai Corporation Vs. The Deputy Commissioner of Taxes, Dhaka and another, 19 BLD (HCD) 220.

 

Section—160

On perusal of the impugned order it appears that the Tribunal has allowed the gift made by Keramat Ali but disallowed the gift made by Md. Abul Kashem on the ground that the letter addressed to him by the Deputy Commissioner of Taxes came back unserved but in disallowing this gift the Taxes Appellate Tribunal lost sight of the fact that the assessee applicant in support of his contention submitted the certified copy of the statement of account of the donors and it further appears that the Deputy Commissioner of Taxes himself confirms that these gifts have been shown by the donors in their respective wealth statements. But this aspect of the case was overlooked by the Taxes Appellate Tribunal in disallowing the gift made by Md. Abdul Kashem. Thus, the order passed by the Taxes Appellate Tribunal do not withstand the scrutiny of law and as such the High Court Division held that the Taxes Appellate Tribunal, Additional Bench—2, Dhaka was not justified in disallowing the gift made by Md. Abul Kashem on the ground of non service of letter addressed to him by the revenue authority.

Md. Serajul Hoque Vs The Commissioner of Taxes Intelligence and Investigation Zone, Dhaka, 20 BLD (HCD) 38.

 

Rule—17A(b)

Collection of tax from importers

The Collector of Customs or any other appropriate officer shall, for the purpose of making a collection of tax under section 53 of the Ordinance, in the case of any importer of goods, including those under the Wage Earners scheme, collect an amount calculated at the rate of [2.5%J of the value of the imported goods:

Provided that this rule shall not apply in the case of import of goods specified below:

(a)  ... … …

(b)  raw materials for industries approved by the Bangladesh Small and Cottage Industries Corporation.

Provided further that where the Board is satisfied that an importer is not likely to have any assessable income during the year or the income is otherwise exempted from payment of income tax under any provisions of the Ordinance; it may, on application by such an importer, exempt such person from payment of tax under this rule.

Clause (b) of first proviso to Rule 17A of the Rules clearly contemplates that provision of Rule 17A shall not apply in case of raw materials for the industries only approved by the Bangladesh Small and Cottage Industries Corporation. The petitioners are not entitled to import any quantity of raw materials beyond their maximum utilization and production capacity of their respective industrial units as approved by Bangladesh Small and Cottage Industries Corporation.

M/s Musa Textile and others Vs Secretary, Ministry of Finance, Government of Bangladesh and ors., 19 BLD (AD) 104.

 

2901

Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 386, 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 21, 13 MLR (2008) (HO) 275, 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 401, 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 220,

Case Year: 1969

Subject: Industrial Relations

Delivery Date: 2018-03-18

Industrial Relations

Ordinance, 1969

 

Section 18— Not applicable to dispute regarding cancellation of membership of the workers union—

Dispute relating to cancellation of the membership of the petitioner of the workers union does not fall within the purview of section 18 of the Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969 and as such the suit in the civil court is held to be quite maintainable. Nasiniddin Ahmed Vs. G.M. Shahabuddin and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 386.

 

Section 34— Labour Court has the jurisdiction to decide the dispute relating to establishment of workers welfare fund—

Companies Profit (Workers) Participation Act, 1968—

Section 3— Management of Industrial undertaking is under the legal obligation of establishing the workers welfare fund—

Hotel and Restaurant being an industrial undertaking the management thereof is required under section 3 of the Companies Profit (Workers). Participation Act, 1968 to establish the workers welfare fund and implement the scheme thereunder. Labour court has the jurisdiction to decide the dispute relating to the implementation of the scheme under section 34 of the Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969. Hotel Agrabad Ltd. Chitlagong represented by its Managing DircctorVs. Chairman First Labour Court, Chittagong and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 21.

 

Section 34— Provides for enforcement of rights created or guaranteed by or under any law—
